about-me/volkan-özçelik.html.title: Volkan Özçelik
about-me/volkan-özçelik.html.description:
Hello, I’m Volkan.I’m a developer, speaker, streamer, creator, connector, and writer. I like tinkering with systems, and I’m not afraid to break stuff.
As an engineer, I solve problems: The context, the origin, or the nature of the problems are orthogonal to the approaches I take in solving them.I’m a big believer in asking questions—It’s the curiosity that matters.
I live-stream code on Twitch.
I podcast at the Deer in the Valley.
I mentor turtles at Kampus.
I am  on the “”volkanozcelikpro birdsite.
I post technology rants on the anti-birdsite).
contains the most up-to-date information about mevolkan.io
And is where I blog occasionallyzerotohero.dev
Currently, I’m a Senior Principal Engineer (Master) at Broadcom , reinventing Virtual Private Cloud) as you know it.
I am very active in the zero-trust security space. And, related to that, I am a chair at the SPIFFE Steering Committee, where I help drive the strategic direction and growth of all projects under the SPIFFE umbrella.Well, that’s me in a nutshell: I’m a pragmatist nerd who gets $#!% done.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: VLAN
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
A VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network) is a logical segmentation of a Layer-2 network that allows multiple independent broadcast domains to coexist on the same physical switching infrastructure. A VLAN lets you pretend one physical network is many separate networks. Devices in different VLANs behave as if they are on different switches, even when plugged into the same one.
VCF uses both VLAN and VXLAN, whilee VXLAN (via NSX) is the primary and modern networking model. VLANs → for the underlay (physical network connectivity) VXLAN → for the overlay (tenant / workload networking)
Workloads never live directly on VLANs. They live on VXLAN-backed logical networks provided by NSX. This is the real physical fabric — switches, routers, NICs. Uses traditional VLANs Carries:
ESX management traffic
vMotion
vSAN
NSX transport traffic (VTEP traffic) Designed to be simple, scalable, and stable This is where actual tenant and workload networking happens. Implemented using VXLAN
Managed by NSX Provides: Logical switches Distributed routing Microsegmentation NAT, LB, firewalling, etc. VXLAN is used to: Create L2 networks over L3 infrastructure Allow massive scale (up to ~16 million segments vs 4096 VLANs) Decouple network topology from physical constraints In VCF: Every workload network = VXLAN-backed logical segment Encapsulated inside UDP packets Carried across the underlay VLANs So effectively:VM / Pod ↓ Logical Switch (VXLAN) ↓ NSX Transport Node ↓ VLAN-backed physical network Here is a comparison table:Without VLANs: Every device hears every broadcast Security boundaries are weak Networks don’t scale cleanly With VLANs: Broadcast traffic is contained Security and isolation improve Networks become modular and scalable Each VLAN is identified by a VLAN ID (typically 1–4094) VLAN ID = logical network identity Access Port Carries traffic for one VLAN Frames are untagged Typical for end devices (servers, VMs, appliances) Trunk Port Carries traffic for multiple VLANs Frames are tagged with VLAN IDs Used between switches, hypervisors, routers On trunk links, Ethernet frames include: VLAN ID Priority bits (QoS) This is how a switch knows which logical network a frame belongs to.One VLAN usually maps to one IP subnet — but they are not the same thing. Devices in the same VLAN can communicate directly Devices in different VLANs require a router or L3 switch This is called inter-VLAN routing In VMware-based environments: VLANs are used for underlay networking Examples: Management
vMotion
Storage (vSAN)
Overlay transport (NSX TEPs)
NSX overlays (segments) may sit on top of VLAN-backed transport networks.So, VLANs are still foundational, even in overlay-driven designs. VLAN = logical Layer-2 network Provides broadcast isolation Uses tagging on trunk links Distinct from IP subnets Still critical in modern virtualized and cloud platforms
Let’s move up a few levels up the stack and observe VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: Management Domain
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
![[workload-domain-b8d5ddd7-899b-4c34-8947-4acbd57f8f72.webp]The Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process by the VCF Installer. It contains the management components of the VCF Instance and, for the first VCF Instance, VCF Operations and VCF Automation.In addition to the components that are common for each VCF Domain, the management domain includes the 
SDDC Manager Appliance and the Fleet Management Appliance, that adds workflows for infrastructure management automation to the VCF Operations instance for the VCF Fleet. Management Domain: is created first hosts VCF Control Plane components:
SDDC Manager
vCenter
NSX Manager
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: VCF Domain
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
A VCF Domain is a core VMware Cloud Foundation platform construct.
It is defined and lifecycle-managed by VCF itself (via SDDC Manager).
VCF Automation consumes it for tenant self-service and provisioning.
VCF Operations observes it for monitoring, health, and capacity.
A VCF Domain is an isolated SDDC unit inside VCF with its own full stack:Each domain is independently lifecycle-managed (upgrade cadence, patch windows, scaling).
A VCF Domain in a VCF Instance consists of the following components:
One vCenter instance.
One or more vSphere Clusters with vSphere HA and vSphere DRS enabled.
At least one vSphere Distributed Switches per cluster for system traffic and NSX Segments for workloads.
Dedicated NSX Manager instance, either specifically for the VCF Domain or shared between VCF Domains, for configuring and implementing software-defined networking.
Optional: One or more NSX Edge Clusters, added after you create the Workload Domain, that connects the workloads in the Workload Domain for logical switching, logical dynamic routing, and load balancing. One or more shared storage allocations as principal or supplemental storage. There are two types of VCF Domains:
Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process.
Workload Domain runs consumer workloads on Day 2.
Management Domain and Workload Domain gives further context about VCF Domains.
You might also want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.sourcePath: VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Architectural Constructs/VCF Topology/VCF Domain/VCF Domain.md

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: Workload Domain
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
You create Workload Domains in VCF Operations to run consumer workloads.
For the first workload domain in your environment, VCF Operations deploys a vCenter instance and an NSX Manager instance in the Management Domain. For each additional workload domain, VCF Operations deploys an additional vCenter instance.New Workload Domains can share the same NSX Manager cluster with an existing Workload Domain or you can deploy a new NSX Manager cluster.
Workload domains cannot use the NSX Manager cluster for the Management Domain.A Workload Domain (or VI (virtual infrastructure) Workload Domain)
is created after Management Domain hosts customer workloads Typical separation: Prod vs non-prod Regulated vs unregulated Performance-sensitive vs general A VCF Domain is to VCF what a Kubernetes cluster is to Kubernetes-based platforms.It gives you: Failure domain isolation Security boundary Upgrade blast-radius control Operational independence Without VCF Domains, everything would be patched, upgraded, and potentially broken together.
In VCF Automation: A VCF Domain is a backing infrastructure boundary It is mapped to:
Organizations
Projects
Supervisor Namespaces VCF Automation never creates or upgrades domain: It only consumes them.
In VCF Operations: A VCF Domain is an observed object Used for: Capacity planning Health scoring Performance analytics Alerting Operations has zero authority over its lifecycle. VCF Domain is a foundational VCF concept Defined and lifecycle-managed by SDDC Manager Not a VCF Automation concept Not a VCF Operations concept BUT both products depend on it, yet neither owns it Primary purpose: isolation, lifecycle control, and scalability
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: SDDC
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
Within VMware Cloud Foundation, an SDDC is the foundational architectural model that virtualizes all core data-center resources (compute, storage, networking, and management) and delivers them as software services.
Think of SDDC as the “what”, while VCF is the “productized implementation” of that model.In an SDDC:
No hardware-specific configuration is required by tenants. Everything is expressed as policies, APIs, and declarative intent.If you think of SDDC as an interface, VCF is an implementation of that interface.Or in mor simpler terms, You cannot “install an SDDC”. You deploy VCF, and the result is an SDDC.As a very simplistic analogy: SDDC → “Cloud computing” VCF → “AWS (but for private cloud)” Inside VCF, SDDC enables: Uniform resource abstraction
A VM workload and a Kubernetes workload are both “workloads” Policy-driven behavior
Placement, HA, security, backups are rules, not scripts Lifecycle coherence
Upgrade ESX, NSX, vSAN together, safely and repeatably Multi-tenancy
Organizations, Projects, namespaces, quotas, RBAC Cloud-like operations on-prem
Self-service, APIs, Governance, chargeback SDDC is not: A single product Just virtualization Just Kubernetes A UI A vCenter feature It is the system-level design philosophy that VCF enforces.VCF’s value proposition is: “You don’t assemble an SDDC yourself anymore: We ship one.” That’s why: VCF has strict BOMs VCF enforces lifecycle orchestration VCF tightly integrates ops + automation + infra This is intentional: freedom at the top, rigidity at the bottom. SDDC = architecture VCF = implementation of that architecture In VCF, everything (compute, storage, network, ops) is software-defined SDDC enables cloud-like behavior on private infrastructure You deploy VCF, and you get an SDDC: That simple.
VCF Private Cloud could be a topic of interest to look at right after SDDC.

headers.heading: 3. What an SDDC gives you in practice

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: VCF Edge
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, VCF Edge refers to the extension of the VCF platform model to edge locations—sites that are geographically distributed, resource-constrained, and often operationally remote, but still need enterprise-grade consistency, security, and lifecycle management.In short: VCF Edge brings “the VCF way” to thousands of small, remote sites—without turning each site into a snowflake.
Edge sites typically have constraints that central data centers do not: Small host counts (often 2–4 nodes) Limited on-site staff (or none) Intermittent or high-latency connectivity (an edge-site not having Internet connectivity for a month is not uncommon) Strict uptime requirements Local data-residency or latency needs VCF Edge is about operating under those constraints without abandoning platform discipline.However, even at the edge, the core VCF principles remain: Centralized lifecycle control Validated configurations Strong isolation and security Declarative operations Consistent operational model What changes is scale, footprint, and placement—not the philosophy.Central / Regional Site ├── Management Domain (SDDC Manager, vCenter, NSX) ├── Automation & Ops │ └── Edge Sites (many) ├── Small Workload Domain (or cluster) ├── Local workloads (VMs / K8s) ├── Local networking & security └── Centrally managed lifecycle So: While, management stays centralized execution happens at the edge Depending on use case: Telco workloads (RAN, core, MEC) Retail store systems Factory / OT workloads Branch office services Latency-sensitive apps These workloads: Run locally Are managed remotely Must survive site isolation
SDDC Manager governs lifecycle Platform admins operate from a hub Edge sites follow validated patterns Workloads keep running if disconnected Local failover is possible Management resumes when connectivity returns This balance is critical for an edge site.VCF Edge supports: Single-tenant edge (most common) Logical multi-tenancy via:
Projects
Namespaces
NSX Segmentation But: Physical isolation per tenant is less common at edge Operational simplicity is prioritized Edge is where: Hyperscalers struggle with footprint and latency Enterprises need consistency across thousands of sites Telco and regulated industries dominate Unlike a traditional cloud or data center (where workloads are centralized to regions), edge is decentralized, and geographically spread. This is topologically opposite to a typical cloud deployment.
VCF Core → Headquarters data center VCF Edge → Branch offices or cell sites (for Telco)
SDDC Manager → Central IT command center Edge clusters → Remote, self-sufficient execution zones
Essentially, the same VCF Governance rules apply, but with different topological constraints, different connectivity requirements, at a smaller, but vastly-distributed scale. VCF Edge extends VCF to remote, constrained sites Management remains centralized Workloads run locally and survive disconnection Edge is a pattern, not a separate product It prioritizes consistency over customization
Looking at VCF Domain, and specifically Management Domain, and Workload Domain could be the next venue to explore from here.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: VCF Management Components
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
VCF management components are the platform control-plane services responsible for lifecycle management, networking, security, observability, and automation of the entire VCF instance, and are deployed exclusively in the Management Domain.
Here are the management components of VCF:
vCenter Server Inventory Cluster logic Resource scheduling API surface for everything else
ESX hosts (management cluster) Run the Management VMs Often capacity-isolated
NSX (NSX Manager + control plane) Networking for management workloads Overlay, routing, firewalling Required even if workload domains use different topologies
SDDC Manager Lifecycle orchestration Domain creation Upgrade coordination Configuration drift control These are management components even though they feel “optional”:
VCF Operations (formerly vRealize / Aria Operations) Telemetry ingestion Capacity planning Health modeling Alert correlation VCF Operations for Logs (if deployed) Centralized logging Audit & forensic workflows
These belong in the Management Domain because: They observe everything They are trusted with cross-domain data They are not tenant-scoped
VCF Automation (formerly vRealize / Aria Automation)
Tenant abstraction (Organization / Project) Approval flows Policy enforcement
Blueprint execution Self-service APIs Even though it models consumer behavior, it is still a management component because: It enforces platform policy It brokers infrastructure authority It is not itself a tenant workload Often overlooked, but these are part of the management plane too: Identity Integration AD / LDAP
OIDC (vIDB, external IdP) Certificates Internal PKI Trust distribution Secrets and credentials Platform credentials Not tenant secrets These may not be a single product, but they are a functional plane of the management domain.A good litmus test: If a tenant can delete it without breaking the cloud, it is not a management component.
Other topological constructs such as Workload Cluster, Management Cluster, or VCF Edge are all good options to dive from here.

headers.heading: Operations and Observability Plane (typically first instance only)

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.title: VCF Private Cloud
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/arc.description:
#tenancy
A VCF Private Cloud is the highest level of management and consumption for the underlying SDDC resources. A VCF Private Cloud can contain one or more VCF Fleets.
VCF Private Cloud is the customer-operated private cloud deployment model built on VMware Cloud Foundation.
It delivers cloud-like operations, Governance, and lifecycle management on customer-owned or customer-controlled infrastructure (on-prem or dedicated colocation). VCF Private Cloud = “You run the cloud, using VMware’s cloud platform.” VCF Private Cloud is opinionated and integrated:
Single lifecycle authority (SDDC Manager)
Validated stack (ESX, vCenter, NSX, vSAN) Declarative operations Strong separation of platform vs tenant Built-in multi-tenancy
Day-0 → Day-2 automation This is fundamentally different from “installing vSphere and calling it a cloud.”These components are installed, upgraded, and validated as one system.VCF Private Cloud is deliberately split: Runs in the Management Domain / Management Cluster Controls lifecycle, upgrades, topology
Used by Tenants
Exposed via Organizations, Projects, policies
Runs workloads in Workload (VI) Domains / Clusters This mirrors public cloud responsibility boundaries.VCF Private Cloud supports enterprise-grade multi-tenancy:
Organizations → business tenants
Projects → sub-tenants (teams, environments)
Namespaces / Resource Pools → execution boundaries
NSX Segmentation → network isolation
Domains / clusters → failure & lifecycle isolation
Tenancy is logical and policy-driven, not per-cluster by default.VCF Private Cloud can be deployed on: On-premises data centers Dedicated colocation Partner-hosted environments
What matters is control, not location. VCF optimizes for control and predictability, not infinite elasticity: VCF Private Cloud ≈ “like AWS, but you run AWS yourself”
SDDC Manager ≈ Cloud provider internal control plane
Organizations / Projects ≈ Accounts and subscriptions
Workload Clusters ≈ Capacity pools VCF Private Cloud is customer-operated cloud infrastructure
Built on VMware Cloud Foundation Strong separation of platform vs tenant
Enterprise-grade Multi-Tenancy and lifecycle Cloud outcomes without giving up control
You might want to check out Management Cluster and Workload Cluster, as they are important topology elements in VCF Private Cloud.

headers.heading: Where Does VCF Private Cloud Run

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.title: Blueprint
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.description:
A Blueprint is a declarative deployment template that defines what can be requested, how it is configured, where it may land, and under which policies and approvals.A VMware Cloud Foundation Design Blueprint is a prescriptive end-to-end design for a VCF Fleet in a commonly requested architecture topology, created to help accelerate time to value when building a new VMware Cloud Foundation platform.A Blueprint has a prescriptive selection of deployment models chosen from the design library to conform to the design profile of the Blueprint.A Blueprint an be deployed as is, with no alterations, or can be used as template where any of the deployment models can be substituted for alternatives from the same category within the design library. 
A Blueprint reflects the initial deployment of a VCF Fleet and supports expansion in a variety of ways to support the needs of your organization.A Blueprint provides a set of planning, implementation and design elements (requirements and recommendations) based on the chosen deployment models.
Blueprints in VCF Automation are governed deployment templates that define allowed workload patterns, configuration inputs, placement constraints, and approval policies. They orchestrate resource creation but are not part of the runtime execution layer.Once a deployment is created, the Blueprint can be deleted and the workload keeps running: It’s not part of the runtime layer.User ↓ Blueprint ← governance + intent ↓ Project ← who / where / policy ↓ Supervisor Namespace ↓ vSphere / Kubernetes runtime Kubernetes YAML answers: “How do I create this thing?” Blueprints answer: “Who is allowed to create which thing, under what rules, and with whose approval?”
Organization: business boundary (e.g. Verizon)
Project: governance scope (e.g. US-East)
Blueprint: allowed patterns inside that scope Organization: Verizon └── Project: US-East ├── Blueprint: Standard App VM ├── Blueprint: GPU Pod └── Blueprint: 3-Node K8s Cluster Each Blueprint: targets specific Supervisor Namespace(s) enforces constraints hides complexity from requesters Typically it defines:Examples: A VM A vSphere Pod A Guest Kubernetes cluster A multi-tier app (VM + LB + storage) CPU / memory sizes Environment variables Image versions Feature toggles Secret references (not secret values)
Which Supervisor Namespace(s) are allowed Which storage policies are allowed Which networks are allowed Size limits Placement rules Who can request it Who must approve it Lease duration Cost visibility / chargeback tags
In VMware Cloud Foundation, the terms template and blueprint are related but not interchangeable. They operate at different abstraction layers and serve different purposes in the lifecycle of infrastructure and workloads. A template defines what a single resource looks like A blueprint defines how multiple resources come together. A template is a reusable, preconfigured artifact that represents one resource, typically: VM Template A golden VM image (OS + patches + base software) Used to rapidly deploy identical VMs OVF/OVA Templates Portable packaged virtual appliances Content Library Templates
Shared across vCenter instances and VCF Domains Infrastructure-level Static Low abstraction No logic, no dependencies Consumed by automation tools (not orchestrating anything themselves) A Template says: “This is what a machine looks like when it’s born.” In contrast, a single Blueprint can define these following components: 2 application VMs 1 database VM A load balancer A network segment Placement rules Lifecycle actions That entire topology is deployed as one logical unit. Blueprints consume templates. Here is possible flow: Template: Ubuntu 22.04 VM with hardened baseline Blueprint: Uses that template Defines how many instances Attaches networks Applies policies Adds lifecycle logic So: Templates = building blocks Blueprints = architectural plans In Kubernetes terms (for intuition): Template ≈ Container Image Blueprint ≈ Helm Chart / Application Manifest Understanding this distinction prevents common mistakes: ❌ Treating templates as reusable environments ❌ Expecting templates to handle lifecycle logic ❌ Trying to encode business logic inside VM images Correct mental model: Templates are static Blueprints are dynamic and declarative As a quick comparison: Template → A reusable VM or image → Low-level, static, infrastructure-focused Blueprint → A declarative application/environment definition → High-level, orchestrated, lifecycle-aware
You might want to check concepts like Organizations, or Projects, which are related to Blueprints.

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.title: Organization
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.description:
#tenancy
See also: Project

In VCF Automation, an Organization is not a technical runtime boundary—It is a business-facing logical entity that defines who is allowed to consume cloud capabilities, under which rules, and with which visibility.An Organization is the top-level administrative boundary.It is used to: Group users, projects, and resources Apply policies and governance Define ownership and access boundaries Support multi-tenant separation An organization typically maps to a business unit or tenant.Organizations exist only in VCF Automation, not in Kubernetes.It is the outermost “contract boundary” for consumption, not execution.An Organization is a logical tenant boundary that groups identity, policy, quotas, visibility, and approval flows for consuming infrastructure and platform services.It answers: Who is consuming? What are they allowed to consume? Under which business rules? —not how workloads actually run.
Because Supervisor Namespaces are the actual enforcement boundary, a single Organization can define multiple tenants.But those “tenants” are operational tenants, not consumption tenants.There are two different kinds of tenancy in VCF:They are deliberately decoupled.
A Supervisor Namespace enforces: RBAC Resource quotas Network isolation Storage policies Pod security boundaries Runtime blast radius This is where: Kubernetes says “no” vSphere enforces limits Workloads are actually prevented from crossing boundaries Namespace = hard enforcement boundary
Organizations define intent and Governance. An Organization: Defines who is allowed to create tenants Defines how many tenants Defines under which rules Defines approval and lifecycle policies It’s closer to: “Who is allowed to mint isolation boundaries?” not: “Where isolation happens.” A single Organization can own: Multiple Projects Each Project can map to:
One Supervisor Namespace Or several namespaces (depending on policy / model) Organization: Acme Corp ├── Project: Acme-Prod → ns-acme-prod ├── Project: Acme-Stage → ns-acme-stage ├── Project: Acme-Dev → ns-acme-dev └── Project: Acme-Analytics → ns-acme-analytics
Each namespace is a real tenant boundary.But from a business standpoint: Acme Corp is still one customer: One billing entity One governance envelope One policy domain This construct enables the following scenarios (which would have been impossible otherwise).Classic need: Dev / Stage / Prod Regulated vs non-regulated Different trust zones All under: One contract One identity plane One catalog Example: Organization = “Platform Team” Projects = internal product teams Namespaces = per-team isolation This would break if Organization == Namespace.Example: Organization = External customer Projects = customer environments Namespaces = actual enforcement boundaries Same model works for: Internal IT SaaS providers Telco multi-tenant platforms If something must be isolated, it must be isolated at the namespace level.Anything above that:
Is governance Is visibility Is policy Is economy Organizations define who may create tenants; namespaces are the tenants.Similar to: AWS Account Azure Subscription (with Management Groups layered above) GCP Project (with Org/Folder hierarchy) But in VCF, it’s explicitly framed as consumption-first, not infrastructure-first. Separates consumers (e.g., companies, business units, external customers) Enforces isolation in: Identity and Access Visibility Quotas and Limits Chargeback / showback Organizations are where policies attach, such as: Who can request what Approval workflows Budget limits Lease durations Allowed regions / environments Allowed workload types (VM, Kubernetes, services) These policies then flow downward.Everything inside an Organization is: Visible only to that Organization (unless shared) Governed consistently This includes: Projects Blueprints / templates Catalog items Requests Cost views Organization ├── Projects │ ├── Policies │ ├── Quotas │ ├── Users / Groups │ └── Workload requests │ └── (maps indirectly to) └── Cloud Zones └── Infrastructure (vSphere, Supervisor, VKS, etc.) Infrastructure never belongs to an Organization Consumption always does Organization deliberately hides infrastructure topology.From the Organization’s point of view:
There is no ESX No cluster No datastore
No vSphere Supervisor There is only: “What can I request?” “What am I allowed to use?” “Who approves this?” “How much does it cost?” This abstraction enables: Multi-tenant platforms Internal private clouds Managed services SaaS-like experience on top of VCF If Organization is “who is the customer”, then Project is “what they are working on”.Typical mapping:Organization: Acme Corp ├── Project: Acme-Prod ├── Project: Acme-Stage └── Project: Acme-Dev Projects: Scope quotas Bind to cloud zones
Eventually map to Supervisor Namespaces or runtime constructs Organizations never do.
Organization = Governance + visibility It exists to model consumption, not execution It owns policy, identity, and economics It deliberately abstracts away infrastructure
Everything technical happens below it, via Projects and Cloud Zones
Check IaaS as a concept, or jump back to VMware Cloud Foundation.

headers.heading: Organization is “Logical”, Namespace is the Real Boundary

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.title: Project
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.description:
#tenancy
See Also: Organization
In VMware Cloud Foundation, a Project is a logical, tenant-scoped construct used for workload organization, Governance, and self-service consumption.It exists at the automation and policy layer, not the virtualization layer.A Project is a logical grouping within an organization.Projects: Represent application teams or environments
Contain one or more VKS clusters
Are mapped to one or more Supervisor Namespaces Define resource entitlements and policy boundaries Key properties: Projects can be renamed Projects cannot be deleted if they contain VKS clusters A VKS cluster belongs to exactly one Project
A Supervisor Namespace cannot span multiple Projects Projects act as the bridge between organizational intent and infrastructure execution.Projects group workloads, users, quotas, policies, and lifecycle controls under a common administrative boundary. It is “a governed slice of cloud capacity” exposed to consumers.
Projects live primarily in VCF Automation (formerly vRealize Automation / Aria Automation).It is not: A vSphere cluster A Kubernetes cluster A resource pool
A Supervisor Namespace (though it may map to one) Instead, it is a control-plane abstraction that binds together multiple lower-level constructs.VCF Instance └── Organization └── Project ├── Users & Roles ├── Policies & Quotas ├── Cloud Zones ├── Workload Deployments └── Supervisor Namespaces / VKS Clusters
A project represents a tenant or sub-tenant: Different teams Different applications Different environments (prod, staging, dev) Each project is isolated from others by policy.Projects define who can do what:
Project Administrator
Project User
Project Advanced User
Project Auditor These roles govern: Who can deploy workloads
Who can modify Blueprints Who can see usage or costs Projects define where workloads can land: Which Cloud Zones they can use Resource quotas (CPU, memory, storage) Network constraints Storage policies This prevents a single tenant from exhausting shared infrastructure.Projects are the context in which users deploy:
Virtual Machines Kubernetes clusters (e.g., Supervisor-backed) Application blueprints
Day-2 operations (scale, update, destroy) Everything a user deploys is always within a project.A Project maps to:
A Supervisor Namespace One or more Kubernetes clusters A set of Kubernetes namespaces inside those clusters But the Project itself is not Kubernetes-native. It’s a management abstraction above Kubernetes.Think of it as: “A governance wrapper around Kubernetes and VM resources.”
VCF Automation supports both one-to-one and one-to-many mappings between Projects and Supervisor Namespaces; the choice is an architectural pattern, not a platform constraint.Very common, very clean:Organization: Coca-Cola ├── Project: Coke-Prod → ns-coke-prod ├── Project: Coke-Stage → ns-coke-stage └── Project: Coke-Dev → ns-coke-dev This provides: Clean blast-radius isolation Clear RBAC and quotas per environment Easy mental model Common in regulated / prod-heavy setups This is a design choice, not a platform requirement.(Equally valid, also common in larger deployments)Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke ├── ns-coke-dev ├── ns-coke-stage └── ns-coke-prod This provides: Shared governance (same people, same blueprints) Environment separation handled at namespace level Easier cross-env promotion workflows Fewer projects to manage
In VMware Cloud Foundation: A Project is a logical tenant boundary It governs who can deploy what, where, and how It sits above infrastructure and below the organization It is the unit of consumption for developers and teams
It enables Multi-Tenancy, Governance, and self-service
You might want to check out Blueprints.
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/con.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.title: VCF Fleet
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.description:
VCF Fleet is an environment that is managed by a single set of fleet-level management components:  VCF Operations
and VCF Automation
A VCF Fleet contains one or more VCF Instances and might contain one or more standalone vCenter instances, managed by the VCF Operations instance for the fleet.The components of a VCF Fleet are:
VCF Instances
vCenter Instances
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains nicely compares and contrasts how Fleet, Domain, and Instances relate to each other.
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.sourcePath: VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Fleet and Domain Model/VCF Fleet.md

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.title: VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, these three terms describe different scopes of control, stacked hierarchically from largest (fleet) to smallest (domain).
If you only remember one thing: Fleet → Instance → Domain Management across clouds → One cloud → Parts of that cloud
A VCF Fleet is a logical grouping of multiple VCF Instances that are managed, observed, or governed together.It is a meta-layer, not a runtime construct. Multiple data centers Multiple regions Core + Edge Possibly different purposes (prod, DR, sovereign, etc.) Fleet-wide visibility Cross-instance posture (versions, compliance, drift) Centralized operations and governance Consistent policies and standards Fleet = “My private cloud estate”
A VCF Instance is one deployed VCF system:
One SDDC Manager
One Management Domain One lifecycle authority This is the unit of deployment and lifecycle. Independently installed Independently upgraded Independently failed / recovered Self-contained control plane Examples: One on-prem private cloud One regional cloud One large edge aggregation site
A Domain is a logical partition inside a VCF Instance, used to separate management concerns, workload types, or failure domains.There are two major kinds: Created first Hosts:
SDDC Manager
Management vCenter
NSX Managers Runs the platform itself One or more per instance Host: Tenant workloads
Application clusters (i.e., Guest Clusters) Independently scalable and isolatable Domain = “A major subsystem within a Cloud” VCF Fleet │ ├── VCF Instance (DC-West) │ ├── Management Domain │ ├── Workload Domain – Prod │ └── Workload Domain – Dev │ ├── VCF Instance (DC-East) │ ├── Management Domain │ └── Workload Domain – Prod │ └── VCF Instance (Edge-Region-1) ├── Management Domain └── Workload Domain – Edge Each level has different responsibilities and blast radius. Fleet → Multiple clusters managed centrally Instance → One cluster + control plane Domain → Node pools / system vs workload separation Because customers now have: Many private clouds Many edge clouds
A need for consistent Governance at scale So VMware had to separate: Where lifecycle happens (instance) Where workloads run (domains) Where governance is coordinated (fleet)
VCF Fleet = multi-cloud / multi-site management scope
VCF Instance = one complete VCF deployment
VCF Domains = functional partitions inside an instance Lifecycle authority lives at the instance Isolation and scale happen via domains
Governance and visibility roll up to the fleet
You might want to look at VCF Advanced Services.

headers.heading: What Happens at the Fleet Level
VCF Domains—“Functional Partitions Inside a Cloud”
Management Domain
Workload Domains

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.sourcePath: VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Fleet and Domain Model/VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.md

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.title: VCF Instance
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.description:
VCF Instance is the compute, storage, networking virtual infrastructure that runs business workloads. A VCF Instance consists of VCF Domains: a Management Domain and Workload Domains.The components of a VCF Instance are:
SDDC Manager
NSX
vCenter
ESX
VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains nicely compares and contrasts how Fleet, Domain, and Instances relate to each other.
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/fle.sourcePath: VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Fleet and Domain Model/VCF Instance.md

vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/vcf.title: VCF Advanced Services
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/vcf.description:
VCF Advanced Services provide additional add-on functionality to the platform.The following sections summarize some of the *VCF Advanced Services.VMware Live Recovery is used to build powerful cyber and data resiliency for VCF.It provides ransomware and disaster recovery in a unified management experience, accelerated recovery, and simplified consumption.You can use Data Services Manager to build enterprise-hardened data services with high availability, performance, backup, and monitoring.
You can use VMware Private AI Foundation to run NVIDIA NIM microservices on VCF, which support AI models from NVIDIA and others in the community, and NVIDIA AI tools and frameworks.
You can use vDefend for built-in zone and application microsegmentation, threat detection and response, lateral security, ransomware and APT protection, reduced attack surface, and zero trust enforcement across VCF environments.
VMware Avi Load Balancer is a software-defined platform deeply integrated with VCF private cloud, delivering local and global load balancing, Kubernetes ingress, web application and API security and application analytics.
Network Observability extends the VCF management capabilities with end-to-end visibility into the network overlay, underlay, and applications hosted in a public or hybrid cloud.The solution provides actionable insights to automatically pinpoint problems, resulting in lower internal resource costs and faster issue resolution, quickly getting end-users back to revenue-producing activities.
How about checking out consumption abstractions such as Organization, Project, and Blueprint.
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/vcf.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/concepts/design-and-abstractions/vcf.sourcePath: VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/VCF Capabilities/VCF Advanced Services.md

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/g.title: Governance
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/g.description:
#tenancyGovernance in VCF is the set of mechanisms that decide who is allowed to request which platform capabilities, under what constraints, with what approvals, and for how long — before anything is created.
VCF Automation governs entitlement and lifecycle decisions, including lease expiry and grace periods, but vSphere Supervisor remains the execution authority and only acts when Automation explicitly requests a change. VCF-A governance is front-door, human-aware, policy-driven It’s about entitlement, approval, and lifecycle It is not a security monitoring system It is not a Terraform-style reconciler It is exactly what service providers and large enterprises need to avoid chaos What Governance is NOT:Governance does not watch workloads. It decides whether they are allowed to exist in the first place.Governance (VCF Automation) ├── Organizations ├── Projects ├── Blueprints ├── Entitlements ├── Approvals ├── Quotas └── Leases Execution (vSphere / Supervisor) ├── Namespaces ├── Resource pools ├── Networks └── Workloads Nothing in the execution layer knowns governance exists. Governance defines who may open the door. Execution decides what happens after they are inside the house. In other words, governance is “pre-creation” control, not runtime policing.
From here, Policy, Policy as Code, and STIG are all good candidates to check out.
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/g.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/s.title: STIG
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/s.description:
STIGs are prescriptive, detailed, and comprehensive hardening guides for US Department of Defense systems, based on DoD and NIST requirements.Fair point. Here is the clean, corrected summary, using VCF 9+ terminology only, with no historical justifications.
STIG (Security Technical Implementation Guide) is a DISA / U.S. DoD–defined security hardening standard.STIG is: Not a VCF feature Not a VCF policy type Not a VCF control plane primitive Yet, STIG is a compliance baseline that VCF environments may be required to meet.DISA STIGs (external authority) ↓ VCF-managed infrastructure ↓ VCF Automation → applies hardening VCF Operations → observes and reports posture Used to:
Apply STIG-aligned configuration during VCF Day 0 Tasks / VCF Day 1 Tasks
Enforce hardened baselines via Blueprints, policies, or Workflows
Automate remediation actions when drift is detected
VCF Automation implements STIG requirements; it does not define them.Used to: Monitor configuration drift against hardened baselines Surface compliance posture (pass/fail, deviation) Feed evidence into audit and compliance workflows
VCF Operations observes STIG alignment; it does not certify compliance.VCF does not: Author or publish STIGs Certify STIG compliance Act as a DoD compliance authority Continuously enforce STIG by itself External compliance tooling and audits remain required.
VCF provides the machinery. STIG defines the rules.
VCF Automation applies them.
VCF Operations watches them. STIG is external to VCF and owned by DISA/DoD In VCF:
VCF Automation applies STIG-aligned hardening
VCF Operations monitors and reports posture STIG compliance is intentional configuration + validation, not default behavior
You might want to look at VCF Roles and Permissions.

headers.heading: Which VCF layers are Typically STIG-Hardened
What VCF Does not do with STIG

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/s.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/multi-tenanc.title: Multi-Tenancy
vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/multi-tenanc.description:
#tenancy
In a VCF-based platform, tenant isolation is realized through vSphere Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the enforced execution boundary for workloads.
A single tenant may be associated with one or more Supervisor Namespaces, typically aligned to Projects within an Organization.
Supervisor Namespaces provide hard isolation for compute, networking, storage, and identity, while VCF Automation operates above this layer to deliver governance, policy enforcement, and self-service without weakening those isolation guarantees.
In VMware Cloud Foundation, multi-tenancy is the ability to securely host multiple independent consumers (tenants) on the same physical cloud infrastructure, while preserving isolation, governance, and lifecycle safety.
VCF does not implement multi-tenancy at a single layer. It is layered, intentional, and asymmetric:Where it lives
Workload Domains
Clusters
NSX Segments
Resource Pools Who owns it Platform / Cloud Admins What it provides Strong isolation Failure-domain separation Compliance boundaries Important Infrastructure tenancy is coarse-grained Tenants do not see this layer “Which hardware and fabric does this workload ultimately land on?” Where it lives
Organizations
Projects Policies, quotas, approvals
This layer is primarily owned by VCF Automation.
Organizations Top-level tenant boundary Represents a company, business unit, or customer Defines identity, access, quotas, and governance
Projects Sub-tenants within an organization Environment—or team—scoped (Dev / Test / Prod, Team A / Team B) This is where true SaaS-like multi-tenancy exists.Depending on workload type: vSphere constructs Backed by resource pools, folders, NSX isolation
Supervisor Namespaces Mapped (typically) 1-to-1 with Projects
Enforced by vSphere + Kubernetes RBAC Key subtlety
Supervisor Namespaces are execution boundaries, not business tenants. They implement tenancy; they are not the tenant itself. VCF Infrastructure (shared) │ ├── Organization: Acme │ ├── Project: Acme-Prod → Supervisor Namespace ns-acme-prod │ ├── Project: Acme-Dev → Supervisor Namespace ns-acme-dev │ └── Project: Acme-Test → Supervisor Namespace ns-acme-test │ ├── Organization: Globex │ ├── Project: Globex-Prod → Supervisor Namespace ns-globex-prod │ └── Project: Globex-Dev → Supervisor Namespace ns-globex-dev
Organizations = business tenants
Projects = operational sub-tenants
Namespaces = runtime enforcement Isolation is compositional, not singular. Strong isolation without hardware duplication Clear separation of duties Supports enterprise and service-provider use cases Preserves lifecycle determinism Conceptually complex Multiple abstractions to understand Requires discipline in mapping orgs/projects/namespaces
VCF optimizes for large-scale, regulated environments, not minimalism.
In VMware Cloud Foundation, multi-tenancy does not mean soft separation within a shared runtime. Instead, it is defined by: Explicit tenant boundaries Platform-enforced isolation No cross-tenant visibility or control Lifecycle independence between tenants This design prioritizes predictability, security, and supportability over maximal flexibility.VCF intentionally separates administrative constructs from enforcement points.
Organizations and Projects define who can do what
Supervisor Namespaces define what can actually run and where
While Organizations and Projects are essential for governance and delegation, isolation becomes real only at the Supervisor Namespace layer.At this boundary, VCF enforces: Resource allocation and limits Network segmentation Storage policy enforcement Identity and access scoping A common tenant layout in VCF looks like this:
One Organization represents a tenant (i.e. Coca Cola)
One or more Project exists within that Organization (i.e. Dev / Staging / Prod)
Each Project (typically) maps to one Supervisor Namespace (but can map to more than one) A tenant may therefore own multiple namespaces, often separated by: Environment (dev / stage / prod) Application domain Regulatory or compliance boundary This model allows tenants to scale horizontally without eroding isolation.
VCF Automation provides the control plane for consumption, not the enforcement layer.It is responsible for: Self-service access to platform capabilities
Policy-driven approvals and quotas
Governance and auditability Abstraction of underlying platform complexity
VCF Automation:
Does not bypass Supervisor Namespace isolation Does not weaken platform guardrails Does not act as the isolation mechanism itself It governs access to platform-enforced boundaries—it does not replace them.If we think in layers:
Infrastructure layer: Hosts, clusters, networking, storage (operated outside VCF Automation)
Isolation layer: Supervisor Namespaces (hard tenant boundary)
Governance layer: Organizations and Projects (who can consume what)
Workload layer: VMs, Kubernetes clusters, and services Multi-tenancy in VCF emerges from the composition of these layers, not from any single construct. Multi-tenancy in VCF is layered
This layered design is foundational to VCF’s security and supportability This design balances power, safety, and scale
Organizations and Projects define business tenancy
Organizations and Projects provide governance, not isolation
Supervisor Namespaces enforce runtime isolation Supervisor Namespaces are the hard isolation boundary in VCF Tenants may span multiple namespaces
Workload Domains protect lifecycle and failure domains
VCF Automation governs consumption without compromising isolation
From here, Administrative Roles in VCF would be a next complementary concept to check out.

headers.heading: The Role of VCF Automation

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/multi-tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/tenants-in-s.title: Tenants in Supervisor
vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/tenants-in-s.description:
#tenancy
In vSphere Supervisor a tenant is namespace-bound. There is no separate tenant object inside Kubernetes.
A Supervisor Namespace is the tenant boundary at the vSphere-Kubernetes interface. If you assume: Tenant = Project → you’ll design the wrong thing Tenant = Kubernetes namespace → you’ll under-secure Tenant = Supervisor Namespace → things line up “tenant namespace” is an informal shorthand for supervisor namespace. Organizations and Projects are governance overlays. They do not define the tenant.Kubernetes namespaces inside guest clusters are secondary scopes.
In vSphere Supervisor each tenant is realized as one (or more) Supervisor Namespaces.
VCF Automation sits above, provides governance (Organizations, Projects, quotas) and self-service, but does not define tenancy by itself.This is sometimes “informally” expressed as “tenant namespaces”. What is meant by it is a Supervisor Namespace.Or more precisely: In a Supervisor Cluster tenant == supervisor namespace (there is a 1-1 relationship).
In vSphere Supervisor, tenancy is realized through Supervisor Namespaces, which serve as the execution and isolation boundary for tenants.When people say: “tenant namespace” “project namespace” “customer namespace” They almost always mean: A Supervisor Namespace allocated to that tenant. Kubernetes does not have a separate construct for this: It is a vSphere concept, projected as a namespace.A Supervisor Namespace can contain:
Pods
VMs
Entire guest Kubernetes clusters Tenant └── Supervisor Namespace ├── VM workloads ├── Pod workloads └── Guest K8s Cluster └── many Kubernetes namespaces
This is the vSphere Layer of tenancy.VCF Environment └── vSphere (vCenter) └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace ← TENANT BOUNDARY At this layer: Supervisor Namespace Has: Resource limits Storage policies Network segments RBAC bindings Is created and owned by vCenter Maps to: Resource pools NSX constructs Datastore permissions This is where hard multitenancy lives.
This is logical tenancy, not execution tenancy.It is the automation and consumption layer.Organization └── Project └── Deployment / Blueprint └── (Targets a Supervisor Namespace) Organization Business / administrative grouping Project Quota + governance container These map downwards, but they don’t execute workloads themselves.
Supervisor Namespace defines a tenant from a runtime and security perspective.
At VCF Automation, Organizations and Projects define: Ownership Billing
Governance Access workflows But not execution boundaries. VCF Environment (Rackspace) └── Supervisor Cluster ├── ns-cocacola ← Tenant: Coca-Cola ├── ns-pepsi ← Tenant: Pepsi └── ns-pizzahut ← Tenant: Pizza Hut Each tenant is a supervisor namespace.
For Coca-Cola (example): Fixed CPU / memory quota Dedicated or isolated NSX segment Approved storage policies RBAC scoped to Coca-Cola admins Ability to run: Pods VMs Guest Kubernetes clusters That namespace is the tenant boundary. Layer VCF automation on top of this:Organization: Coca-Cola └── Project: Coke-Prod └── Deployments → targets ns-cocacola Organization: Pepsi └── Project: Pepsi-Shared └── Deployments → targets ns-pepsi Organizations and Projects map to Supervisor Namespaces — they do not replace them.Automation gives: Self-service catalogs Approval workflows Policy as code Lifecycle orchestration But the tenant still “lives” at the Supervisor Namespace. Note that the company and product names used in this section are for illustrative purposes—to give realistic analogies—only. Scope vCenter Supervisor Cluster NSX Storage policies Responsibilities Create Supervisor Namespaces Set quotas Attach networks Bind tenant identities Enforce platform guardrails Power level God-mode Not visible to customers Scope One Supervisor Namespace (e.g., ns-cocacola) Kubernetes API within that namespace Responsibilities Manage workloads Deploy guest clusters Configure service Delegate access internally Cannot See other tenants Modify quotas Escape namespace This is who you hand the kubeconfig to. Scope Kubernetes RBAC inside tenant (supervisor) namespace Possibly inside guest clusters Responsibilities Deploy apps Manage services Consume secrets No infrastructure privileges Scope Automation policies Catalogs Projects Approvals This role: Often held by Rackspace Sometimes delegated partially to tenants Secrets do not cross Supervisor Namespaces Identity trust roots often terminate there Network policy enforcement happens there Audit logs are scoped there So when you say tenant == Supervisor Namespace, then: Security Compliance Billing Automation all align clearly.
You can shift gears and check out some basic concepts such as what a Virtual Appliance is, or VCF Roles and Permissions.
vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/tenants-in-s.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/virtual-appliance/virtual-a.title: Virtual Appliance
vcf/concepts/virtual-appliance/virtual-a.description:
see also: VCSA A vSphere Appliance is a prepackaged, hardened virtual machine that bundles an OS, application, configuration, and lifecycle tooling into a single deployable unit.A VMware-style appliance typically includes: A minimal, locked-down OS The application(s) Configuration defaults Upgrade mechanisms Health checks Backup/restore hooks Support boundaries (“only change things this way”) The key idea is: You manage the appliance as a product, not as a general-purpose OS. Usually yes, but conceptually they can be:
One VM (vCenter) Multiple tightly-coupled VMs (some NSX / telco components) But still treated as one product unit From the operator’s perspective: You deploy “the appliance” You don’t manage its internals individually Once you accept that: vCenter is a VM Supervisor components are appliances Then the stack becomes very consistent:
ESX runs everything
vCenter Server orchestrates everything
Appliances are how VMware ships control planes Kubernetes is just another control surface layered on top Multiple VMs ≠ Appliance unless:If you deploy 3 random VMs and wire them together yourself — that’s not an appliance.
Check out VMware Cloud to see how cloud looks like from the lens of VMware Cloud Foundation.

headers.heading: How Does This Differ from Just Deploying Multiple VMs

vcf/concepts/virtual-appliance/virtual-a.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/vmware-cloud/vmware-cloud.h.title: VMware Cloud
vcf/concepts/vmware-cloud/vmware-cloud.h.description:
VMware Cloud is the umbrella brand and strategy for VMware’s cloud-delivered offerings, covering public cloud, hybrid cloud, and managed private cloud use cases.It is not a single product.Think of VMware Cloud as the distribution and consumption model, while VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is the core platform architecture underneath many of those offerings. VMware Cloud is how VMware delivers and operates VMware platforms as a service across public, private, and hybrid clouds. VCF is often the engine; VMware Cloud is the service wrapper.Examples include: VMware Cloud on AWS VMware Cloud on Azure VMware Cloud on Google Cloud VMware Cloud on OCI These provide: Native VMware stacks Operated as managed services Tight integration with hyperscaler services From the customer’s point of view: “I get vSphere/NSX/vSAN without running the platform myself.” This is where things look very similar to VCF: VMware (or a partner) runs VCF on your behalf Can be hosted: On your premises In a partner data center You consume it as a cloud service Regardless of flavor, VMware Cloud aims to deliver: Consistent VMware operational model Reduced platform operational burden Predictable lifecycle management Enterprise-grade security and compliance Hybrid portability (move workloads across clouds) It is not: A replacement for Kubernetes-native clouds A single UI or API A single SKU Always customer-operated It is a portfolio strategy, not a monolith.VMware Cloud = “VMware runs it for you” VCF = “The platform being run” vSphere/NSX = “The building blocks” Or in cloud terms: VMware Cloud ≈ AWS Managed Services VCF ≈ AWS internal platform (you don’t see it directly) vSphere/NSX ≈ EC2 / VPC equivalents Customers want cloud economics But need enterprise control And want to reuse VMware skills and tooling VMware Cloud is VMware’s answer to: “Give me cloud without forcing me to rewrite everything.” VMware Cloud is a service model, not a product It spans public, private, and hybrid clouds
VCF is often the underlying platform VMware Cloud reduces operational responsibility
You might want to check out VMware Validated Solutions too.

headers.heading: VMware Cloud vs VMware Cloud Foundation
What All VMware Cloud Offerings Have in Common

vcf/concepts/vmware-cloud/vmware-cloud.h.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/vmware-validated-solutions/.title: VMware Validated Solutions
vcf/concepts/vmware-validated-solutions/.description:
The purpose of VMware-Validated Solutions is to deploy a VMware-designed SDDC to deliver common business use cases.
VMware Validated Solutions (VVS) are prescriptive, end-to-end solution blueprints built on top of VMware Cloud Foundation that combine architecture, configuration, workflows, and lifecycle guidance into a tested and supportable outcome.A VMware Validated Solution is a known-good way to solve a concrete problem on VCF — designed, tested, and supported as a whole.They answer a very practical question:
“Given VCF, how do I implement this specific enterprise capability correctly and safely?” A VVS is more than documentation. It typically includes: Component topology Trust boundaries Network flows Failure domains Scale assumptions Exact settings (not suggestions) Supported variants Guardrails and constraints Explicit “do / don’t” guidance
Day-0 (deployment)
Day-1 (onboarding, enablement)
Day-2 (upgrade, scale, recover) How the solution evolves with VCF upgrades What breaks compatibility What is safe to automate Everything is validated together, not in isolation.
VCF is a platform, not an opinionated solution by default.Enterprises, however, want outcomes, such as: Secure multi-tenancy Kubernetes at scale Identity-integrated access Backup, DR, or compliance alignment Without validated solutions: Every customer invents their own pattern Outcomes vary wildly Support becomes guesswork Validated Solutions reduce design risk and support friction.
Here, VCF is a programmable substrate, and Validated Solutions as approved programs.While names and scope evolve, common categories include: Secure Cloud Infrastructure Identity and Access Integration Kubernetes Platform Enablement Multi-tenant Cloud Architecture Business Continuity / DR Compliance-aligned deployments Each one narrows a broad platform into a specific, repeatable design.They are not: Reference “ideas” Whitepapers One-off examples Mandatory architectures You can deviate—but once you do, you own the risk. For architects and platform owners, Validated Solutions provide: Faster time to value Reduced design ambiguity Predictable upgrades Clear escalation paths Less freedom Opinionated choices Slower adoption of bleeding-edge features This trade-off is deliberate. VMware Validated Solutions are prescriptive, supported blueprints They sit above VCF, not beside it They reduce risk by constraining choice They align architecture, operations, and lifecycle Deviating is allowed—but unsupported paths are yours to own
You might want to check out VCF Roles and Permissions, Governance, Policy, or Policy as Code as the next few concepts to explore.

headers.heading: What Does a Validated Solution Contain
How Do VMware Validated Solutions Relate to VCF Components

vcf/concepts/vmware-validated-solutions/.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/sddc-manager/sddc-man.title: SDDC Manager
vcf/control-planes/sddc-manager/sddc-man.description:
SDDC Manager is the foundational lifecycle-management and orchestration engine of VMware Cloud Foundation.It is responsible for deploying, configuring, upgrading, and maintaining the entire VCF stack as a single, validated system rather than as independent products.
If you think of VCF as a factory-built private cloud, SDDC Manager is the factory control system that ensures every component is installed correctly, stays in a supported state, and evolves safely over time.

UI Deprecation Warning In VCF 9.0+, Broadcom’s docs state that SDDC Manager UI is being deprecated and that SDDC Manager workflows can now be found in VCF Operations and vSphere Client—so many “platform lifecycle” workflows show up there now. ([ This is SDDC Manager’s primary job.SDDC Manager performs end-to-end lifecycle operations across the VCF stack:
ESX (hypervisor)
vCenter Server
NSX
vSAN Other optional components. Key characteristics: Uses validated upgrade bundles Enforces component compatibility Executes sequenced, automated upgrades Provides rollback and precheck logic This is not just patching: It is system-level lifecycle orchestration.SDDC Manager is responsible for: Initial VCF bring-up Creating: Management Domain
VI (Workload) Domains Adding: Hosts
Clusters
Workload Domains Ensuring: Correct networking Correct certificate trust Correct inventory alignment Without SDDC Manager, you do not have VCF: That simple!—You will only have a loosely assembled VMware products.SDDC Manager acts as the system-of-record for: What components exist Their versions Their relationships Their lifecycle state
vCenter manages virtualization. SDDC Manager manages the cloud system itself.SDDC Manager enforces: Supported topologies Supported versions Supported upgrade paths If you try to: Upgrade NSX independently Modify components outside supported flows You risk breaking VCF supportability.
This is intentional: VCF favors predictability over freedom.It is not: A tenant portal A developer platform A policy engine A workload orchestrator A replacement for vCenter, NSX Manager, or Kubernetes APIs
Those functions live elsewhere (VCF Automation, vSphere Supervisor, vCenter Server, NSX, etc.). SDDC Manager manages the cloud itself; everything else manages what runs inside that cloud. Without SDDC Manager: Enterprises would manually assemble components Version skew would be common Upgrades would be risky and expensive Supportability would collapse With SDDC Manager:
VCF becomes repeatable Lifecycle becomes deterministic VMware/Broadcom can guarantee outcomes This is why SDDC Manager is non-optional in VCF. SDDC Manager is the backbone of VCF It owns lifecycle, topology, and compatibility It enforces validated, supported states It is infrastructure-centric, not tenant-centric Without it, VCF does not exist as a product
Since we are onto management and provisioning, VCF Installer can be the next topic to dive into.
vcf/control-planes/sddc-manager/sddc-man.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.title: Cloud Services
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.description:
VCF Automation provides a set of cloud services which are accessible on a self-service basis using multiple interfaces, including UI, CLI, and API.
With this interface, users can provision the following types of workloads: VMs Kubernetes workloads Networking Volumes Secret stores Databases Harbor Container registries External DNS Certificates AI workloads
Additionally, application teams can also provision resources on a self-service basis from Catalogs which are backed by pre-configured workload templates.These self-service options help developers focus on application development instead of managing the underlying infrastructure.
← Back to “VCF Automation”
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/cloud-.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/provid.title: Provider Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/provid.description:
#tenancy
IT teams and Cloud Service Providers can model Multi-Tenancy by using the concept of Organizations in VCF Automation.This approach allocates resources and manages users specific to each Organization.This capability provides isolated environments with dedicated network setup. IT Teams and CSPs can monitor resource usage, control permissions, and provide managed services while ensuring security through comprehensive network isolation.
← Back to “VCF Automation”
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/provid.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Organization Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
#tenancy
VCF Automation improves Governance for users and resources by enabling Organization Administrators create and assign projects and vSphere Namespaces tailored for different application teams.
Organization Administrators can set resource limits and policies while delegating network management through Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) for application teams.
Additionally, Policy as Code enables organization administrators to enforce instance-centric policies for Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) resources from a central location for compliance and reducing the risk of human error.
In, VCF Automation, an Organization is a top level entity that represents a line of business or a tenant. Each organization operates in a secure and isolated environment where users can access only allocated services and resources.
Organizations consume resources and cloud services from a shared pool of resources. The resources allocated to organizations can be further allocated to application teams which are modeled in VCF Automation as Projects.
Organizations have users with varying levels of permissions depending on their role and duties.
Organizations in VCF Automation are created by the Provider Administrator in the VCF Automation Provider Management Portal.
Each Organization has its own Organization Portal where users log in to consume resources and services. Every organization has its own identity source that they connect to and can import users from.
Organizations enable line-of-business or tenant [Organization Administrator]]s to further organize and govern resources that are allocated to them among application teams through the following capabilities:
Resource management for Project teams.
Centralized content management for the Organization. Policy-based governance on usage of resources. Quota-based management of networking resources.
Workflow orchestration and extensibility through event subscriptions.
Integration with identity providers of their choice.
← Back to “VCF Automation”
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/Organization Management/Organization Management.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: VCF Identity Broker
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
#tenancyVCF Identity Broker (vIDB) is the identity-federation service used by VCF Single Sign-On (SSO) to provide a unified authentication configuration across multiple components in a VCF environment.vIDB centralizes authentication across the major VCF infrastructure components so that administrators and users can sign in once and seamlessly access those systems using a corporate identity provider (IdP) of choice.A practical way to think of it: vIDB = the “SSO engine” VCF SSO = the fleet-level “SSO product experience” that drives vIDB configuration and pushes/coordinates it across components In real deployments, vIDB is positioned as the central place where you integrate with upstream identity sources (for example AD/LDAPS, or “corporate IdPs” such as Okta/Entra/ADFS), and then VCF components are configured to trust/use that SSO configuration.
At a high level, VCF Identity Broker is an identity federation/intermediary service that sits between your enterprise identity provider (e.g., Okta, Microsoft Entra ID/Azure AD, Ping Identity, ADFS, LDAP/OpenLDAP) and the VCF platform services (like vCenter Server, NSX Manager, and the VCF Operations/VCF Automation stack).It: Accepts authentication from an external IdP using modern protocols (e.g., SAML 2.0, OpenID Connect) or directory services (LDAP/AD). Issues federated/standard tokens to VCF components to enable central SSO across the environment. Provides user and group provisioning integration (SCIM, Just-In-Time provisioning, LDAP sync) so that IdP users and groups can be mapped into VCF RBAC. vIDB acts as a universal “identity broker” in a federation chain—it trusts your enterprise IdP and then vouches for those identities to VMware Cloud Foundation services.The vIDB service is described in the field as supporting at least: Embedded mode (configured inside the management domain’s vCenter context; no separate deployment)
Runs inside the Management Domain’s vCenter Server (VCF management cluster). Easier to deploy, ideal for smaller or single-instance VCF environments. Doesn’t require a separate appliance.
Appliance mode (a stand-alone vIDB appliance cluster) Deployed as a stand-alone appliance cluster (often a three-node cluster for high availability). Recommended for larger, production, or fleet-wide SSO use cases. Provides scalability and resilience across multiple VCF instances.
Once enabled, VCF SSO aims to make authentication consistent across VCF components.Instead of logging separately into:
vCenter Server
NSX Manager
VCF Operations / VCF Automation UI VCF Operations for Logs, Networks, etc. you authenticate once via your enterprise IdP, and VCF Identity Broker handles the rest, issuing tokens and enabling access to all components with a common identity.
By centralizing authentication, VCF reduces administrative overhead (no separate local accounts to manage on each component) and supports modern enterprise identity standards.VCF Identity Broker supports a range of identity sources: Modern cloud IdPs: Okta, Ping Identity, Microsoft Entra ID / Azure AD, ADFS. Traditional directory services: Active Directory via LDAP, OpenLDAP. Centralized authentication and SSO—better user experience and reduced login friction. Integrates with corporate IdPs—enables MFA, policy enforcement, and audit logging from your enterprise identity layer. Scalable deployment options—embedded for simplicity, appliance for scale/resilience. Adds an additional component to deploy and manage (especially in appliance mode). Requires careful role mapping and RBAC planning so that IdP groups/roles map correctly to VCF permissions. Legacy components may not participate in SSO the same way — they might still require local accounts even after VCF Identity Broker is configured. A very real operational problem in multi-tenant systems is: Users get recreated/reidentified when you switch identity providers (or change claims, subject formats, etc.). If a tenant starts on IdP-A and later moves to IdP-B, you want a controlled way to preserve user access and authorization mappings. Remapping is the “bridge” that avoids breaking RBAC simply because the upstream identity changed. Remapping is usually about reconciling user identities inside the platform’s internal user store / directory representation when the upstream IdP changes. It’s not “magic federation”—it’s an administrative identity-correlation operation. Upstream IdP (Okta/Entra/ADFS/LDAP-backed federation) Authenticates the human. Issues identity assertions / tokens. vIDB (VCF Identity Broker) Provides VCF SSO: consistent auth configuration across VCF components. VCF Automation OIDC Services / IdP Proxy Provides tenant-aware OIDC proxying for relying parties and/or for tenant-specific auth experiences inside the Automation/Cloud Director plane.
VCF Identity Broker is the central identity federation and Single Sign-On facilitator in VCF It integrates your chosen identity provider with VCF components, allowing a single set of credentials and seamless access across services.
Supports modern authentication protocols and multiple IdP types, helping enterprises align VCF with corporate identity strategies. vIDB is the identity federation service underpinning VCF SSO, aimed at consistent login across VCF components VCF Automation as an OIDC IdP proxy is a separate capability (vCloud Director lineage) that enables tenant-aware OIDC proxying. User remapping between IdPs exists to preserve access/RBAC continuity when tenants change upstream identity sources.
API access tokens in VCF Automation are commonly handled via exchanging a refresh token at .../oauth/provider/token.
PKCE matters for modern public clients; VCF Automation-related guidance explicitly calls for “public OIDC client with PKCE enabled” in some integration scenarios.
VCF Operations or Security Management are two tangentially-related topics that you can navigate from here.

headers.heading: Unified Identity Across the VCF Stack
Remapping Users Between External Upstream IdPs
