vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/VCF Identity Broker/VCF Identity Broker.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/vcf-au.title: VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/vcf-au.description:
#tenancyVCF Automation enables IT teams and cloud service providers to deliver a self-service private cloud for AI, Kubernetes, and VM-based applications.
The solution simplifies the process of provisioning and scaling a multi-tenant private cloud with out-of-the-box Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) offerings, accelerating the time to market for applications while maintaining control using policy-based governance.
VCF Automation provides Governance at the request and lifecycle level—controlling who can deploy which patterns, under what constraints and approvals—while runtime security, drift detection, and continuous enforcement are handled by downstream platforms.VCF Automation has the following capabilities:
Cloud Services: Provides a set of cloud services to meet the needs of application teams
Provider Management: Supports IT teams and cloud service providers to effectively manage, deliver, and scale cloud services across multiple vCenter and VCF instances.
Organization Management: Provides capabilities that enable the organization administrator of a Line of Business or a tenant to further organize and govern resources allocated to them among application teams.
vSphere Supervisor: Provides the capability to run Kubernetes workloads directly on ESX hosts and to create upstream Kubernetes clusters within dedicated namespaces.
From here, you can jump to Cloud Services, Provider Management.
Also, User Roles and Project Management are other good candidates to explore. Or, dive directly into vSphere Supervisor.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/vcf-au.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.title: FinOps and Capacity
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.description:
Cost management helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses. In this way, you can identify areas that are most suitable to use capacity management for optimal utilization of your resources.You can use the FinOps or Cost Management capabilities to monitor infrastructure-related costs and associated services or license expenses with greater precision.Capacity Management consists of 3 sets of capabilities: assess, optimize and plan.Capacity optimization helps you right-size or reclaim any underutilized or wasted resources.
Workload Placement lets you optimize virtual machines and storage across clusters to reduce resource contention and maintain optimum system performance. By using What-If Analysis, you can plan for an increase or decrease in workload or capacity requirements in your virtual infrastructure.
← Back to VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Capacity and Cost Optimization/FinOps and Capacity.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.title: Workload Placement
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.description:
Workload Placement in VCF is the coordinated outcome of automation intent, vSphere scheduling (DRS), networking availability (NSX), storage policy (CNS), and runtime mobility (vMotion).
vMotion is the mechanism, not the decision-maker.Workload Placement is a pipeline, not a switch—shaken, but not stirred:Intent → Eligibility → Initial Placement → Continuous Optimization → Recovery Each stage is owned by a different layer of VCF.Answers: “what am I allowed to run, and where?”
VCF Automation (formerly Aria Automation) The user requests a workload (VM, Kubernetes cluster, pod) Constraints are applied:
Organization / Project Quotas and approvals
Target workload domain / cluster Storage policy Network intent There is no vMotion here: This is just pre-placement filtering.Answers: “Which clusters can even accept this?”
vSphere
NSX
vSAN Cluster compatibility HA admission control
Resource Pool limits Storage policy compatibility
NSX Segment & transport availability Anything that fails here is never considered for placement.
This is where DRS takes the helm.
DRS Chooses the best host at power-on time Considers: CPU & memory headroom
NUMA alignment
Resource Pool shares Affinity / anti-affinity rules This happens before the VM ever runs. This is placement — not vMotion.
This is where vMotion appears.
DRS + vMotion
vMotion Load imbalance Hotspots Policy drift Host entering maintenance
vMotion is: How VMs move NOT *why they move HA Host fails
HA re-places VMs on surviving hosts
DRS may later rebalance This is reactive placement, NOT optimization.
NSX matters more than what’s seen on the surface.
NSX Manager / VCF Edge Placement is invalid if: Segment is not available on target host Transport zone mismatch Edge capacity insufficient (north–south) Networking can veto otherwise valid placements.
Especially for Kubernetes (CNS)
vSAN
CNS (for K8s) Placement requires: Policy-compatible datastore Accessibility from host Topology alignment (for StatefulSets, etc.) For Kubernetes: PVC → StorageClass → Storage Policy
CNS enforces this during placement So things are a tad bit more involved than “VCF places workloads using vMotion”.VCF places workloads using DRS decisions; vMotion is only the transport. Workload placement in VCF is layered and collaborative
DRS decides, vMotion moves
HA re-places after failure
NSX and storage can block or shape placement
VCF Automation governs who can ask for what
← Back to VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/capaci.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Capacity and Cost Optimization/Workload Placement.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 0 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 0 tasks are everything required to prepare and bootstrap the platform before any tenant, workload, or higher-level automation exists.
Think of Day 0 as laying the concrete and pouring the foundation—after this, you can build floors (VCF Day 1 Tasks) and move people in (VCF Day 2 Tasks). Day 0: Make the platform exist Day 1: Configure and extend the platform Day 2: Operate workloads on the platform VCF is very opinionated: nothing meaningful can happen until Day 0 is clean and correct.These are outside VCF but mandatory. Rack & cable hosts Power, cooling, BIOS/firmware NTP, DNS, IPAM VLANs / MTU (often jumbo frames) Out-of-band management (iDRAC / iLO) If this is wrong, everything later becomes “mysteriously flaky.”
Before VCF can orchestrate anything, ESX must exist.
Install ESX on all hosts Apply compatible firmware and drivers Validate hardware against VCF BOM Configure basic networking (vmnics, MTU) These hosts are raw compute, not yet part of any SDDC.This is the true start of VCF.
Deploy SDDC Manager Appliance Connect it to: DNS NTP Identity source Verify reachability to all ESX hosts From this point on, VCF owns lifecycle.This creates the core control plane SDDC.Includes automated deployment of:
vCenter Server
NSX Manager
vSAN
ESX Management Cluster This is where VCF becomes a self-hosting platform.After this, you no longer treat components individually.Baseline platform networking is established.
NSX fabric initialization Transport zones Edge nodes (management edges) Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways Initial firewall policies This defines how everything can talk later.Foundational access control.
Integrate vCenter / SDDC Manager with: LDAP / AD / Identity Provider Define platform admin roles Secure service accounts Without this, automation has no authority.Often underestimated, always painful if skipped. CA strategy (internal vs external) TLS certificates for:
vCenter
NSX
SDDC Manager Trust alignment across components This is where future mTLS, OIDC, and zero-trust efforts live or die.This is about future safety. Validate VCF BOM Enable lifecycle management workflows Confirm patching & upgrade paths Confirm supportability state
If skipped, VCF Day 2 Tasks turns into firefighting. No tenants No projects No Supervisor Namespaces No Kubernetes workloads No automation pipelines No business logic Day 0 is pure platform plumbing. VCF Day 0 = platform existence It is non-negotiable and opinionated Focuses on infrastructure, identity, network, and lifecycle No tenants, no workloads, no business logic
Done right → VCF Day 1 Tasks and VCF Day 2 Tasks feel boring (the best outcome)

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 0 Tasks

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Day-N Operations/VCF Day 0 Tasks.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 1 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 1 tasks start after the platform exists and focus on making it usable, consumable, and policy-driven—without yet running real business workloads.If Day 0 pours concrete, Day 1 frames the building and installs utilities. Day 0 → Platform exists Day 1 → Platform is configurable & consumable Day 2 → Platform is used & operated Day 1 is where intent, policy, and abstraction appear.This is where business structure enters the system.
Define Organizations
Define Projects Map projects to: Supervisor Namespaces Resource boundaries Define quotas and limits This is not Kubernetes yet—it’s VCF’s business abstraction layer.From “admins only” to multi-role access. Define administrative roles Map identity groups to roles Separate:
Organization Administrators (colloquially known as Platform Admins)
Project Administrators (colloquially known as Tenant Admins) Developers Enable delegated self-service
This is where “secure Multi-Tenancy” becomes real.Networking shifts from fabric to consumption. Project-level networking Tenant Tier-1 gateways NAT, routing, firewall policies Load balancer enablement Network isolation per project Infrastructure networking (Day 0) becomes tenant networking.Turn raw storage into governed capacity. Define storage policies (performance, availability)
Assign policies to Projects
Enable vSAN / NFS / VMFS consumption Set quotas and constraints This prevents noisy neighbors and capacity abuse.Expose compute without exposing chaos. Define resource pools Assign clusters to projects Enable placement policies
Configure HA / DRS behavior Compute becomes schedulable capacity, not hardware.This is where container platforms appear.
Enable vSphere Supervisor Configure:
Supervisor Namespaces Kubernetes versions CNI / CSI integration
VKS clusters
Kubernetes exists because Day 1 enabled it, not because ESX magically does containers.Where humans stop clicking.
Enable VCF Automation
Define Blueprints Approval flows Day-1 actions exposed as APIs
Service Catalog creation This is the front door for tenants.This is preventative control, not enforcement after damage. Quotas Naming standards Placement constraints Lifecycle constraints Compliance policies Day 1 policies determine how painful Day 2 is.Before workloads, you need visibility. Enable logging pipelines Metrics collection Alert baselines Capacity visibility You can’t operate what you can’t see. No real business workloads No app-specific tuning No scaling incidents No break/fix operations Day 1 is still design-heavy, not ops-heavy. VCF Day 1 = platform enablement
Introduces tenancy, policy, automation No real workloads yet Sets the rules for everything that follows Good Day 1 → boring, predictable Day 2
Check out VCF Day 2 Tasks to see what comes after day one, where theory and preparation meets the challenges of real-world production workloads.

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 1 Tasks

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Day-N Operations/VCF Day 1 Tasks.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.title: VCF Day 2 Tasks
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation Day 2 tasks begin once real workloads exist. This is where theory meets entropy: failures happen, usage grows, humans make mistakes, and the platform must keep working anyway.If: Day 0 pours the concrete Day 1 frames the building Day 2 is living in it for years Or: Day 0 → Existence Day 1 → Enablement Day 2 → Sustainment Day 2 is continuous, not a phase you “finish”.This is the obvious part—but it’s only the surface. Deploy workloads (VMs, Pods, clusters) Scale up/down Start / stop / suspend Migrate workloads Retire workloads Day 2 starts the feedback loop. Platform health monitoring Workload health monitoring Capacity tracking Performance baselines Alert tuning (noise reduction) Bad alerts = ignored alerts = outages.The real test of architecture. Host failures Network partitions Storage degradation Control plane issues Application outages Includes: [HA] / [DRS] behavior Failover validation Backup & restore DR testing
If this fails, Day 0 and Day 1 didn’t matter.Security shifts from design to enforcement. Certificate rotation Secret rotation Credential revocation Firewall rule changes Vulnerability remediation Audit and compliance reporting One of VCF’s core promises. [] patching
vCenter upgrades
NSX upgrades Kubernetes version upgrades Firmware alignment (BOM compliance) All while: Workloads are running SLAs are enforced This is why VCF is opinionated.Reality: resources are finite. Capacity planning Quota adjustments Overcommit tuning Chargeback / showback Cluster expansion This is where finance meets engineering.Day 1 defines policies. Day 2 fights drift. Detect misconfigurations Enforce standards Handle exceptions Reconcile “special cases” Without this, entropy wins.Day 2 success is measured socially, not technically. Self-service reliability Automation success rates Time-to-resource Support ticket volume Developer trust A stable platform feels boring. That’s success.Day 2 never freezes architecture. Introduce new workload types Add regions / clusters Enable new services Deprecate old patterns VCF must evolve without reset. VCF Day 2 = continuous operations Includes incidents, upgrades, security, scale
Validates Day 0 and Day 1 decisions Workload type becomes irrelevant Boring Day 2 is the highest compliment
Why not explore VCF Fleet Deployment or VCF Installer as platform enablers.

headers.heading: Core Categories of VCF Day 2 Tasks
Day 0 / Day 1 / Day 2 in One View

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/day-n-.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Day-N Operations/VCF Day 2 Tasks.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.title: Operations Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.description:
VCF Operations delivers the observability, analytics, and operational intelligence layer for VMware Cloud Foundation environments. It focuses on understanding system behavior, maintaining platform health, and enabling proactive operations across compute, storage, and networking—both in real time and over longer planning horizons.
Where VCF Automation answers “what should be deployed and governed?”,
VCF Operations answers “how is the platform behaving, and where are risks emerging?”VCF Operations continuously ingests telemetry, events, metrics, and logs from across the VCF stack to provide operators with actionable insights rather than raw data.Provides a holistic, continuously evaluated view of platform health across domains and components. Validates configuration consistency against VMware best practices Detects drift, misconfigurations, and version incompatibilities Surfaces health scores and risk indicators at fleet, domain, and component levels Helps operators move from reactive firefighting to preventive maintenance This provides a continuous “wellness check” for the entire VCF environment.Enables rapid root-cause analysis when issues arise. Correlates symptoms across compute, storage, and networking layers Analyzes historical trends to distinguish transient issues from systemic problems Provides guided troubleshooting workflows and impact analysis Reduces mean time to detect (MTTD) and mean time to resolution (MTTR) Instead of isolated alerts, diagnostics focus on cause-and-effect relationships.Centralizes and contextualizes logs generated across the VCF stack. Aggregates logs from infrastructure and platform components Enables search, filtering, and correlation across time and services Supports security investigations, audits, and post-incident analysis Complements metrics-based monitoring with forensic-level visibility Logs become evidence, not noise.Monitors and analyzes the health, performance, and behavior of networking components. Tracks latency, packet loss, throughput, and flow patterns Detects anomalies and deviations from normal traffic behavior Helps identify bottlenecks, misrouted traffic, and configuration issues Provides visibility across logical and physical networking layers This bridges the traditional gap between virtual networking abstractions and real network behavior.Delivers insight into capacity, performance, and reliability of storage resources. Monitors IOPS, latency, throughput, and utilization trends Predicts capacity exhaustion and performance degradation Identifies imbalanced workloads and storage hotspots Supports informed decisions around scaling and optimization Storage operations turn capacity planning from guesswork into data-driven forecasting.VCF Operations is: Observability and operational intelligence Predictive and preventive rather than purely reactive Focused on platform behavior and risk VCF Operations is not: A workload deployment or provisioning system A policy enforcement or approval engine A tenant-facing self-service layer VCF Operations is the operational nervous system of VCF It emphasizes insight, correlation, and prediction—not just monitoring It complements VCF Automation by ensuring the platform remains healthy, performant, and secure over time Its value compounds as environments scale and diversify
← Back to VCF Automation

headers.heading: What VCF Operations Is, and Is Not

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Observability and Health/Operations Management.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.title: Performance Monitoring
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.description:
Performance Monitoring within VCF Operations focuses on ensuring applications and platform services consistently receive the resources they need—while enabling rapid detection, diagnosis, and resolution of performance issues.Rather than relying solely on static thresholds or isolated metrics, performance monitoring leverages continuous telemetry and analytics to understand how workloads behave over time, identify anomalies, and surface emerging risks before they impact users or SLAs.In practical terms, it answers: Are my applications getting the resources they expect, and if not—why? Performance monitoring collects and analyzes application-level metrics from virtual machines and supporting infrastructure. CPU, memory, disk, and network utilization Latency, throughput, and contention indicators Performance baselines derived from historical behavior Correlation between application performance and infrastructure conditions This shifts the perspective from “is the host healthy?” to “is the application experiencing friction?”Advanced analytics and machine learning are applied to identify patterns and anomalies that traditional monitoring often misses. Detects abnormal behavior relative to learned baselines Correlates symptoms across compute, storage, and networking layers Highlights probable root causes rather than isolated alerts Enables faster time to resolution while avoiding unnecessary overprovisioning The result is signal over noise, especially in large or dynamic environments.Performance monitoring ensures workloads maintain reliable access to required resources. Identifies resource contention and saturation risks Surfaces inefficient resource usage and imbalance Supports proactive scaling and right-sizing decisions Helps balance performance objectives against cost efficiency This allows operators to protect performance without defaulting to over-allocation.A VCF Operations management pack is a modular integration that extends monitoring and analytics to specific infrastructure or platform components. Collects metrics, events, and alerts from integrated systems Normalizes telemetry into a common operational model Enables deep, component-aware performance analysis Supports consistent monitoring across heterogeneous environments Management packs are what allow VCF Operations to scale from generic monitoring into domain-aware performance intelligence.Performance Monitoring is: Application-aware and infrastructure-correlated Predictive and analytics-driven Focused on sustained performance and efficiency Performance Monitoring is not: Simple threshold-based alerting A standalone APM tool A workload deployment or governance mechanism Performance monitoring ensures applications continuously receive the resources they need AI-driven analytics reduce noise and accelerate root-cause analysis Management packs enable deep, system-specific insights at scale The goal is sustained performance and cost discipline—not just uptime
← Back to VCF Automation
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Observability and Health/Performance Monitoring.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.title: Workload Operations
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.description:
Workload Operations focuses on ensuring that applications—whether virtual machine–based or container-based—are available, performant, and delivering the expected end-user experience. It bridges the gap between infrastructure health and actual workload behavior, allowing operators to reason about issues in terms of applications rather than underlying components.At its core, Workload Operations answer: Is the application running correctly from the user’s point of view—and if not, where is the breakdown? Workload Operations continuously assess whether applications are functioning as intended. Tracks workload availability and responsiveness Monitors performance indicators relevant to application behavior Detects degradations before they escalate into outages Distinguishes between infrastructure noise and real workload impact This ensures operators focus on what matters to consumers, not just raw resource metrics.Beyond infrastructure signals, workload operations account for how applications are perceived by users. Correlates performance data with service responsiveness Helps identify issues that are invisible at the host or cluster level Supports prioritization of incidents based on user impact Improves alignment between platform teams and application owners In effect, it reframes operations around service outcomes, not components.
For container-based applications, VCF Operations provides native awareness of Kubernetes workloads running on the platform.
Automatic discovery of Supervisor-managed Kubernetes environments
Granular visibility into vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS) clusters Monitoring at cluster, namespace, and workload levels Correlation between container behavior and underlying infrastructure signals This tight integration eliminates blind spots that traditionally exist between virtualization and Kubernetes operations.By correlating workload-level symptoms with infrastructure-level signals, workload operations significantly shorten troubleshooting cycles. Rapid isolation of whether issues originate in compute, storage, networking, or the application layer Reduced hand-offs between infrastructure and platform teams Faster root-cause identification for mixed VM and container environments Improved mean time to resolution (MTTR) Instead of “ping-pong debugging,” operators get end-to-end context.Workload Operations is: Application-centric rather than component-centric Equally applicable to VM-based and container-based workloads Focused on availability, performance, and user impact Workload Operations is not: A deployment or CI/CD system A replacement for application-level instrumentation A tenant self-service or governance mechanism Workload Operations shift operational focus from infrastructure health to application outcomes Native integration with Supervisor and VKS enables deep visibility for Kubernetes workloads Correlated insights reduce troubleshooting time and operational friction The end goal is reliable applications with predictable user experience, not just healthy infrastructure
← Back to VCF Automation

headers.heading: What Workload Operations Is—and Is Not

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/observ.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Observability and Health/Workload Operations.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VCF Single Sign-On
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
#tenancy

Authentication in VMware Cloud Foundation provides identity and access management services to VCF Fleet components. You build your authentication design by using three main pillars: Your external Identity Provider (IdP), 
VCF Identity Broker,
and VCF Single Sign-On.
The corporate identity provider is the centralized source of digital identities for the enterprise, which provides authentication and identity assertion. You connect the corporate identity provider to VCF Fleet components by using VCF Identity Broker.
VCF Identity Broker enables a VCF Single Sign-On implementation and streamlines authentication across different 
VCF Fleet components.The table below summarizes several single sign-on models that VMware Cloud Foundation uses:
Check out VCF Operations Orchestrator to see how VCF automates workflow-based tasks at various layers of the stack.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Identity and Access/VCF Single Sign-On.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/securi.title: Security Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/securi.description:
The Security Management area of VCF Operations includes capabilities such as Security Operations, Event Auditing, and Compliance Checks. Security Operations: The Security Operations dashboard is designed to provide a comprehensive view of your security posture in VCF. Events Auditing: Event auditing provides visibility into platform interaction changes across the VCF infrastructure and insights into suspicious access events and policy violations. Compliance: Ensure compliance for the VCF infrastructure and cloud environments against optimum configurations, maintaining a consistent configuration across SDDC components, reducing organizational and business risk.
← Back to VCF Automation

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/usage,.title: VCF Business Services Console
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/usage,.description:
VCF Business Services Console are cloud service that provides the ability to manage VCF Usage, meter appliances, User Roles, and resource access.VCF Business Services Console (BSC) is the business-facing control plane for VCF that focuses on commercial governance, not infrastructure operations. It provides tenancy, subscription, entitlement, and usage visibility across organizations and projects.If vCenter answers “what is running?”, BSC answers: “Who is entitled to what, who is using it, and how should it be charged?” VCF ├── Infrastructure & Ops │ ├── vCenter / ESXi │ ├── NSX / vSAN │ └── VCF Automation │ ├── Metering │ └── Usage Meter │ └── Business Layer └── Business Services Console ├── Organizations ├── Subscriptions ├── Entitlements └── Usage visibility Audience: Platform owners, cloud business teams, service providers Not for day-to-day infrastructure operators
Defines Organizations as commercial entities Associates: Subscriptions Entitlements Usage views This is a business boundary, not a technical one. Tracks which orgs are entitled to: VCF capacity Optional components (NSX, vSAN, etc.) Aligns commercial contracts with technical consumption BSC does not provision resources — it governs access.
Consumes data from VCF Usage Meter Presents usage in: Business-friendly terms Aggregated per org / subscription Enables showback / chargeback workflows Especially relevant for: Internal private clouds with multiple business units Service providers offering VCF-based services BSC gives a single pane of glass for business accountability.BSC is governance and visibility, not execution.Think of BSC as: The billing and entitlement desk of your private cloud Not the data center. Not the scheduler. Not the automation engine. With subscription-based licensing: “Installed” ≠ “Billable” “Running” ≠ “Entitled” BSC: Bridges commercial reality and technical usage Makes private cloud operate more like a public cloud business Cloud platform owners Finance / FinOps teams Service provider admins Business unit IT leads Rarely: day-to-day SREs. VCF Business Services Console is the business control plane Manages organizations, subscriptions, and entitlements Consumes (but does not generate) usage data Complements Usage Meter and VCF Automation Essential for multi-tenant, subscription-driven VCF deployments
Why not check out VCF Operations HCX, vMotion, or VMware Live Recovery?

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/usage,.title: VCF Usage Meter
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/usage,.description:
VCF Usage Meter is the metering and reporting appliance that measures actual consumption of VCF products so usage can be reported for subscription billing, chargeback, and compliance.It answers one question: “How much VCF capacity is actually being used?”
Billing is not “what you installed” but what you consume. Usage Meter provides a vendor-supported, auditable source of truth for that consumption.VCF Environment ├── vCenter / ESX ├── NSX ├── vSAN └── (optionally) other VMware components │ ▼ VCF Usage Meter │ ├── Collects usage data ├── Normalizes & aggregates └── Exports reports → Broadcom / internal billing Deployed as: Virtual appliance Consumes: Read-only APIs Does NOT sit in the data path CPU cores (primary driver) VM counts Host counts
Enabled features (e.g., NSX, vSAN) Time-based usage (average / peak over period) It measures entitled usage, not theoretical capacity.Usage Meter connects to:
vCenter Server
NSX
vSAN It does not inspect workloads or traffic.Usage Meter is about accounting, not operations. Internal chargeback / showback Cost transparency per environment Required for accurate reporting Supports audits with defensible data “Are we consistently over-allocating?” “Which features are actually used?”
If vCenter is: “What exists and how it runs” Then Usage Meter is: “What you should be billed for” Low resource footprint Read-only access Typically one per environment (or per domain) Periodic export / reporting cadence It is intentionally boring and predictable — by design. VCF Usage Meter = billing-grade consumption measurement
Tracks real usage across vSphere, NSX, vSAN Required for subscription reporting & compliance Not involved in runtime, placement, or enforcement
You might want to check out VCF Operations HCX which makes hypercloud mobility as boring as it can get (which is a good thing).

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VCF Operations HCX
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility and migration platform built into VMware Cloud Foundation. It combines the power of VMware Hybrid Cloud Extension (HCX) with VCF’s operational tooling to simplify application migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.You can perform secure and automated migrations without requiring changes to applications or network configurations.Thus, you can place workloads based on business requirements. The platform minimizes downtime during migrations, improves scalability, and supports compliance and security throughout workload transitions.
HCX stands for Hybrid Cloud eXtension—it’s not just another name for vMotion. It’s a comprehensive application mobility platform from VMware that enables workload migration, workload rebalancing, and business continuity across data centers and clouds.VCF Operations HCX has the following capabilities: Seamless workload migration. Migrate VMs and applications in waves live or in bulk with minimal or zero downtime. Network extension. Extend networks while preserving IP addresses and topologies to maintain application connectivity. Inter-and intra-VCF mobility. Enable workload mobility within and across multiple VCF instances, including site-to-site and region-to-region migrations. Application placement optimization. Enables high-performance application mobility across different environments, making it easier to optimize workload placement based on business requirements. At its heart, VCF Operations HCX is an application mobility platform that: **Connects environments—on-premises data centers, private clouds, and public clouds—with optimized, secure network interconnectivity. Enables workload migration—live or bulk migration of virtual machines (VMs) and applications between environments with minimal downtime. Supports hybrid cloud adoption—making it easier to modernize, consolidate, or balance workloads across sites. Essentially, it extends the capabilities of VCF so that moving workloads into, out of, or around your VCF estate is seamless and automated.VCF Operations HCX automates the process of moving VMs and applications from one environment to another. This includes: Live migrations (zero or near-zero downtime) Bulk migrations for large-scale moves Cross-platform migrations (including non-vSphere sources in some scenarios) Network extension so IPs/MACs remain consistent during migration This makes migrations faster, less error-prone, and less disruptive than traditional approaches.HCX builds a secure, encrypted interconnect between sites that: Extends Layer-2 networks across sites Preserves VM networking so that workloads keep their addresses Provides optimized tunnels tailored for high-speed bulk movement Cloud adoption isn’t a one-time event — usage patterns change. HCX enables: Moving workloads based on performance needs Rebalancing for cost or compliance reasons Continuous optimization of where workloads run This is key in hybrid environments where business needs or performance requirements evolve over time.VCF Operations HCX has deeper integration with VCF: Unified management & single sign-on with other VCF components Shared licensing managed through VCF Operations Integrated planning & execution workflows with VCF Operations for Networks Easier deployment with a single unified HCX Manager appliance That means less separate manual setup and a smoother experience from discovery to execution.Imagine you’re relocating a city’s services (libraries, police stations, hospitals) to a new smart city: Traditional migration = manually moving each building piece by piece. VCF Operations HCX = building a dedicated transit corridor where services can shift live without interruption, while preserving all their connections and addresses — all orchestrated by a central operations dashboard instead of manual labor.
vMotion is VMware’s native live-migration technology for moving a running VM between ESX hosts (including memory and CPU state), usually within the same VCF Domain or cluster.HCX doesn’t replace vMotion; it leverages it as one migration method (called “HCX vMotion”) when moving workloads between HCX-connected sites. It also supports: Cold Migration: Powered-off VMs Bulk Migration: Parallel, batched workloads Replication-Assisted vMotion: Parallel live migrations via replication + vMotion So, vMotion is a component inside HCX’s larger orchestration and connectivity framework. VCF Operations HCX is VMware’s integrated workload mobility solution within VMware Cloud Foundation. It simplifies application migration and workload rebalancing across on-prem, hybrid, and multi-cloud environments. Via optimized network extension and interconnects, it preserves application connectivity and minimizes disruption. Recent integrations with VCF improve deployment, management, and operational workflows.
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.

headers.heading: HCX uses vMotion as one of its tools

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: vMotion
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
vMotion is vSphere’s live-migration mechanism that moves a running VM from one ESX host to another with no downtime.
In VCF, vMotion is foundational plumbing—it’s how higher-level services (DRS, maintenance workflows) actually move workloads.
VCF └── vSphere ├── DRS → decides *when/where* to move ├── HA → may trigger restarts (not vMotion) └── vMotion → performs the *move*
Implemented by: vSphere
Orchestrated via: vCenter Server
Consumed by: DRS, maintenance mode, admin actions DRS decides. vMotion moves. Pre-copy: VM memory is copied to the destination while the VM keeps running. Iterative sync: Dirty pages are recopied until the delta is tiny. Switchover: VM is briefly quiesced (milliseconds), CPU state flips. Resume: VM continues on the new host with the same IP/MAC. No reboot. No app restart. Shared storage access L2 network reachability Compatible CPU features (or EVC) vMotion-enabled VMkernel network with sufficient bandwidth
VCF designs these prerequisites in by default.
DRS load balancing (automatic) Host maintenance mode (drain before patching) Hardware refresh (zero-downtime) Policy remediation (after placement decisions)
You rarely “use vMotion” directly in VCF—it’s constantly in use under the hood. Not a scheduler (it doesn’t decide) Not a failover mechanism Not application-aware Not cross-site DR by itself It is transport, not policy. “VCF places workloads with vMotion” → No. DRS places; vMotion moves. “vMotion is free” → No. It consumes network and CPU headroom. “vMotion fixes capacity issues” → No. It redistributes load only. vMotion doesn’t choose destinations, and it doesn’t judge priorities—it just moves things safely when told. vMotion = zero-downtime VM movement Core building block for DRS and maintenance Always present and assumed in VCF designs Necessary—but never sufficient—by itself
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Workload Mobility and Resilience/vMotion.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.title: VMware Live Recovery
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/worklo.description:
VMware Live Recovery is VMware’s modern, unified disaster-recovery (DR) and cyber-recovery capability, designed to protect VCF-managed workloads against outages, site failures, and ransomware, with minimal downtime and minimal data loss. VMware Live Recovery = continuous protection + fast failover + clean recovery, natively aligned with VCF operations. VMware Live Recovery is not a hypervisor feature and not just storage replication.
It lives at the platform services / operations layer of VCF. Site failure Cluster outage Maintenance windows gone wrong Encrypted VMs Malicious data corruption Need for clean rollback instead of “latest replica” Near-zero RPO (seconds) Change-block tracking Continuous replication rather than periodic snapshots Automated failover / failback Application-aware recovery ordering Network remapping and IP preservation Roll back to a known-good state Avoid restoring infected replicas Immutable recovery points (depending on the backing storage) Protect workloads: on-prem → on-prem on-prem → cloud cloud → cloud Strong alignment with hybrid VCF deployments Primarily: VM workloads vSAN-backed storage
VCF-managed domains It is not: A Kubernetes-native backup system A replacement for application-level backups A secrets-or-identity-recovery tool ^ all these remain separate concerns.You can think of VCF as enforcing invariants: “Workloads must be recoverable within defined SLOs.” VMware Live Recovery is the enforcement mechanism for the resilience invariant: If a site fails → recover If data is corrupted → rewind safely If ransomware hits → recover clean, fast, and confidently VLR is
Not vMotion
Not VCF Operations HCX Not a backup product Not a Kubernetes-native DR Those solve mobility or data protection, not platform-level resilience orchestration. VMware Live Recovery is VCF’s unified DR + cyber-recovery platform Designed for low RPO, fast RTO, and clean recovery Successor mindset to SRM, built for ransomware-era threats Operates at the VCF Operations layer, not the hypervisor Focused on VM workloads, not containers or apps directly
VCF Day 0 Tasks, VCF Day 1 Tasks, or VCF Day 2 Tasks could be nice places to visit from here.

headers.heading: Where Does It Sit in the VCF Stack
