vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.title: VCF Operations
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.description:
#tenancy
VCF Operations helps your organization build, manage, operate and secure your private cloud infrastructure by deploying and maintaining its fleet-level components, providing visibility and enhanced performance across the workload and infrastructure stack, and helping your organization stay compliant with regulatory standards and organizational guidelines.VCF Operations has these functional areas:
Fleet Management Enables operational consistency and efficient resource management of the VCF infrastructure at scale.
Operations Management Provides monitoring and optimization of performance, cost and capacity, and faster troubleshooting.
Workload Operations  Ensures that critical applications are running as expected.
Performance Monitoring Ensures applications have continuous access to resources
FinOps and Capacity Helps you analyze your infrastructure expenses and optimize capacity usage.
VCF Operations HCX Provides support for migrating and interconnecting workloads within and across VCF private cloud.
Security Management Provides security management to ensure that your VCF private cloud is operationally secure. VCF Operations does not: Own tenancy boundaries Gate workload creation Enforce business approval flows Define org/project constructs Those remain in:
VCF Automation
Supervisor Upstream automation layers VCF Operations observes those constructs after the fact.Day 0 / Day 1 → VCF-A - Who can create? - What can be created? - Under what policies? Day 2 → VCF-O - Is it healthy? - Is it over/under-utilized? - Is it behaving strangely? Here is a very high-level look at VCF’s control plane:VCF (the platform) ├── VCF Automation (formerly Aria Automation) ├── VCF Operations (formerly Aria Operations) ├── Supervisor / vSphere └── Workloads Here is how things looks from each layer’s point of view:
Once a workload cluster is instantiated in a Supervisor Namespace, it has no awareness of VCF Automation constructs such as Organization or Project—Those concepts exist only at the governance layer (VCF Automation) and are not part of the runtime execution model (Supervisor).
You might want to check out Operations Management, Performance Monitoring, or Workload Operations.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/vcf-op.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.title: NSX Segment
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.description:
An NSX Segment is a logical Layer-2 network in NSX.
It is where workloads (VMs, containers) attach their NICs, just like plugging into a virtual switch—except it’s policy-driven, distributed, and decoupled from physical VLANs.
VCF ├── vSphere (compute) │ └── VMs / Pods │ └── vNIC │ └── NSX Segment (L2) │ └── Tier-1 Gateway (L3, optional) │ └── Tier-0 Gateway → Physical network └── NSX Manager (policy & control)
Defined in: NSX Manager
Enforced on: ESX hosts (distributed dataplane) Consumes: Overlay networking (GENEVE) Provides L2 connectivity between attached workloads Enables east–west traffic within the segment Acts as the policy anchor for: Distributed Firewall (DFW) DHCP (optional) MAC/IP learning and isolation NSX Segment is: “A virtual Ethernet network with cloud-native policy.” NSX Segments remove VLAN sprawl and enable fine-grained security. Pure L2 broadcast domain No routing out Common for isolated tiers L3 routing enabled North–south possible via Tier-0
Most common in VCF DFW rules are applied to vNICs on segments Security is identity-and policy-based, not subnet-based Zero-trust patterns become practical The segment is not the security boundary—the workload is. In VCF: Segments are first-class networking objects Used by: VM workloads Kubernetes (via NSX CNI)
Automation Blueprints
Lifecycle managed and validated by VCF You don’t hand-craft switch configs; you declare intent.If vSphere Port Group is: “A virtual switch tied to a VLAN” Then NSX Segment is: “A logical network with built-in policy, security, and mobility” ❌ Not a physical network ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a router ❌ Not Kubernetes-specific (but integrates cleanly) NSX Segment = logical L2 network Attaches workloads and anchors security policy
Decoupled from physical VLANs
Foundational to zero-trust networking in VCF
You can check out vSAN and CNS which are other related networking topics.

headers.heading: NSX Segment in the VCF Stack
What Does an NSX Segment Do
2. Segment Attached to a Tier-1 Gateway

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/object-model/nsx-s.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.title: NSX
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.description:
#tenancyNSX enables network connectivity, operations, and scale. It uses a software-defined approach to networking that spans data centers, clouds and application frameworks.NSX abstracts network services from the underlying hardware, enabling programmable infrastructure through APIs. You can implement policies and workflows to automate tasks like network provisioning, security enforcement, load balancing, streamlining operations, and improving efficiency.NSX provides a complete set of logical networking capabilities and services, including logical switching, routing, distributed load balancing, virtual private network (VPN), quality of service (QoS), and monitoring.Enable logical Layer 2 overlay extensions across a routed (Layer 3) fabric within and across data center boundaries.Dynamic routing between virtual networks that is performed in a distributed manner in the hypervisor kernel, and scale-out routing with active-active failover with physical routers. Static routing and dynamic routing protocols are supported, including support for IPv6.Complete data plane isolation among tenants with a separate routing table, network address translation (NAT), and edge firewall support in each VRF on the Support for bridging between VLANs configured on the physical network and NSX overlay networks, for seamless connectivity between virtual and physical workloads.Site-to-site and unmanaged VPN for cloud gateway services.By using NSX, you can move workloads between racks and data centers by decoupling them from the underlying networks.Centralized policy configuration and enforcement across multiple locations from a single pane of glass, enabling network-wide consistent policy, operational simplicity, and simplified disaster recovery architecture.Enable consistent networking and security across data center sites, and across private cloud boundaries, irrespective of underlying physical topology or cloud platform.NSX can manage the provisioning, deployment, operations and retirement of networking infrastructure and applications from a central control pane.
You can automate infrastructure operations and offload manual tasks with workflows and agile templating using tools such as VCF Automation, Terraform, and Ansible. 
VPCs provide isolated network environments within a shared infrastructure. You can use Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) constructs to provision and manage network resources to business units or project teams independently, with granular control over networking policies and resource allocation.
You might want to check out NSX Segment for a more technical overview about NSX internal, or look at NSX Manager, or NSX Edge Cluster.

headers.heading: Layer 2–Layer 7 Network Stack and Overlay Services
Self-Service Networking with VPCs and Multi-Tenancy

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.title: NSX Edge Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.description:
An NSX Edge Cluster is a pool of dedicated NSX Edge Nodes that handle north–south traffic and advanced network services (routing, NAT, load balancing, VPN, firewall at the perimeter). North–south routing Tier-0 Gateways (uplink to physical network) Tier-1 Gateways (tenant / app routing) Perimeter services NAT L4–L7 Load Balancing VPN (IPsec, L2VPN) Gateway firewalling High throughput datapath Optimized for packet forwarding
Separate from ESX host dataplane ❌ It does not run workloads
❌ It does not manage policy (that’s NSX Manager) ❌ It does not replace distributed firewall (DFW) VCF ├── vSphere Cluster (compute) │ └── Workload VMs │ └── East–West traffic (DFW on ESXi) │ ├── NSX Edge Cluster │ └── North–South traffic │ ├── Tier-0 Gateway │ └── Services (NAT, LB, VPN) │ └── NSX Manager └── Policy & control plane
ESX hosts = east–west NSX Edge Nodes = north–south Edge nodes are deployed as VMs Grouped into Edge Clusters Services can be: Active/Active (ECMP) Active/Standby
Protected by vSphere HA Scaled horizontally by adding Edge Nodes NSX Edge Cluster = NSX’s north–south dataplane It handles routing, NAT, LB, VPN, perimeter firewalling
In VCF, Edge Clusters are foundational for routed, multi-tenant designs
Why not check out NSX Segments?

headers.heading: What Does an NSX Edge Cluster Do
What NSX Edge Cluster Does not Do

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-edge-cluster.h.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.title: NSX Manager
vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.description:
NSX Manager is the central management and control plane for NSX. It defines, stores, and enforces software-defined networking and security policy (switching, routing, firewalling) across the VCF environment.
In VCF, NSX Manager is mandatory wherever NSX is used and is deployed and lifecycle-managed by VCF.
VMware Cloud Foundation ├── Management Domain │ └── NSX Manager (3-node cluster) │ └── Workload Domains └── NSX Data Plane (transport nodes) Role: Management and policy authority Not a data-path component
Consumes: vCenter inventory, clusters, hosts Policy management Segments (logical networks) Tier-0 / Tier-1 gateways (routing) Distributed Firewall (DFW) rules Control-plane orchestration Pushes intent to hosts and edges Inventory and Topology Knows which workloads live where API and UI Single source of truth for NSX state
NSX Manager is the “brain” of NSX.If NSX Manager goes down: Existing traffic continues No new changes can be made until it returns NSX Manager is typically deployed as: 3-node cluster Quorum-based
Protected by vSphere HA Loss of one node → no impact Loss of quorum → management freeze, not traffic loss VCF: Deploys NSX Manager automatically Enforces supported topologies Handles upgrades, certificates, backups Assumes NSX Manager is always present ❌ Not a router forwarding packets ❌ Not a firewall datapath ❌ Not optional in NSX-based VCF designs ❌ Not workload-aware beyond policy intent If vCenter is: “What compute exists and where?” Then NSX Manager is: “How workloads may talk to each other, and who is allowed.” NSX Manager is the control plane of NSX It defines networking and security intent Traffic keeps flowing without it, but change stops
In VCF, it is foundational and non-optional when NSX is used
Check out NSX Edge Cluster for another related networking concept.

headers.heading: NSX Manager in the VCF Stack
NSX Manager vs other NSX Components

vcf/core-runtimes/nsx/nsx-manager.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.title: CNS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.description:
CNS (Cloud Native Storage) is the vSphere capability that makes Kubernetes storage first-class and lifecycle-aware.
It bridges Kubernetes PersistentVolumes with vSphere storage (typically vSAN) so that Kubernetes, not admins, drives volume lifecycle, while vSphere retains visibility, Policy, and Governance.
VCF relies on CNS wherever Kubernetes (Supervisor or guest clusters) consumes vSphere storage.VCF ├── vSphere │ ├── vCenter Server │ │ └── CNS (storage awareness & lifecycle) │ ├── vSAN / VMFS / NFS │ └── ESXi │ └── Kubernetes ├── Supervisor Cluster └── Guest Clusters (VKS) └── PVC → PV → vSphere Volume
Implemented by: vSphere
Integrated via: vSphere CSI Driver
Observed/managed in: vCenter Server Without CNS: Kubernetes creates volumes vSphere sees “random disks” No linkage, no lifecycle alignment With CNS:
Kubernetes objects ↔ vSphere volumes are linked
vSphere understands which PVC belongs to which pod Storage policy, health, and cleanup are automatic CNS makes Kubernetes storage visible, governable, and safe in vSphere. Lifecycle mapping
PVC create/delete ↔ vSphere volume create/delete Topology awareness Knows which cluster, namespace, pod owns a volume Policy enforcement
Applies vSphere Storage Policies (SPBM) Operational visibility
Shows Kubernetes volumes in vCenter UI & APIs Kubernetes creates a PVC CSI driver requests a volume
vSphere provisions storage (vSAN) CNS records: Kubernetes metadata Volume ownership On PVC delete → CNS ensures correct cleanup
Kubernetes stays declarative; vSphere stays authoritative. CNS is always on StorageClasses map directly to vSphere policies CNS operates via CSI
Still centrally visible in vCenter Same mechanism, different consumption layers. ❌ Not a storage array ❌ Not a CSI driver itself ❌ Not Kubernetes-only ❌ Not a replacement for vSAN CNS is the glue, not the storage.If CSI is: “The driver that talks to storage” Then CNS is: “The brain that understands Kubernetes intent inside vSphere” Enables policy-driven storage for containers Prevents orphaned volumes Makes Kubernetes operationally sane for infra teams Required for supported VCF Kubernetes designs CNS = Cloud Native Storage awareness in vSphere Aligns Kubernetes volume lifecycle with vSphere Essential for Supervisor & TKG clusters in VCF- Turns storage into a first-class Kubernetes citizen
Control plane elements, like VCF Automation and VCF Operations and two possible places to jump from here.

headers.heading: Supervisor Cluster
Guest Clusters (VKS)
Why CNS Matters in VCF

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/cns.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.title: vSAN
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.description:
vSAN aggregates local or direct-attached capacity devices of all ESX hosts in a cluster and creates a single storage pool shared across all ESX hosts in the  vSAN cluster.Use vSAN as a VI administrator or storage administrator to enhance storage performance by aggregating local storage into a single shared pool across all hosts in a vSAN cluster.
You can use vSphere features that require shared storage, such as vSphere HA, vSphere vMotion, and vSphere DRS, without the need for external shared storage.vSAN provides operational consistency from edge to cloud, with complete visibility and lifecycle management of compute and storage from a single UI.You can perform consistent, VM-centric operations by using policy-based management. Within the vSAN ESA, per-VM policies increase flexibility of management, enabling compression policies, or customize data services on a per-VM basis.
Want some L2/L3 network magic? Then check out Distributed Virtual Switch.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/vsan.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.title: vSphere Client
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.description:
vSphere Client is: A web UI (HTML / JS) Running inside either ESX (embedded) or vCenter Consuming backend APIs It consumes REST and legacy SOAP / internal APIs Functionally: It is an API consumer It behaves differently depending on where it is placed: Same UI codebase: Connected to ESX → host-scoped Connected to vCenter Server → environment-scoped The UI is not “smart”: The backend defines reality.
There is exactly ONE UI name (“vSphere Client”), but it can connect to TWO different backends.
vCenter Server
ESX Hosts ## Mode 1 Browser ↓ ESX Host ↓ Embedded vSphere Client ## Mode 2 Browser ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere Client ↓ Many ESX hosts
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.

headers.heading: One UI to Rule Them All

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/access-and-int.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: vSphere, ESX, and vCenter
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
Saying “vSphere is ‘‘ESX and vCenter’’” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.Because vSphere is a platform, it is NOT a single product.Or, to put more simply: There is nothing you can curl called vSphere; similar to there is nothing that you can curl called AWS or Azure.vSphere is VMware’s virtualization platform built on ESX hosts managed by vCenter Server, together providing cluster-level services such as HA, DRS, and Kubernetes integration.But still, that term is mostly, contextually “good enough” because, in practice: You never run production vSphere without vCenter ESX alone is just a hypervisor, not a platform; and it is very limited vCenter alone does nothing
vSphere includes:
ESX is the bare-metal hypervisor.
vCenter Server provides centralized management. Platform features:
vMotion (live VM migration)
HA / DRS
Resource Pools
Distributed Virtual Switches Storage policies
Fault Tolerance
You cannot have vSphere without ESX.
You can have ESX without vCenter (but it will be very limited).
For more information about what vSphere controls and manages, you might want to see vSphere Constructs and vSphere Cluster. After that, your next step could be to check out vSphere Supervisor and see how it enables declarative management of these constructs.
Exploring vSphere Constructs might be the next logical area to navigate from here.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Core Components/Component Relationships/vSphere, ESX, and vCenter.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: ESX
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
ESX is the virtualization platform where you create and run Virtual Machines and Virtual Appliances, Kubernetes workloads, and AI/ML Workloads.  ESX is a Type-1 (bare-metal) hypervisor Runs directly on hardware Owns: CPU scheduling Memory management Device virtualization Does not coordinate clusters by itself You can run standalone ESX without vCenter, but: No clustering
No HA
No DRS
No vMotion orchestration ESX is a hypervisor, it is not a traditional Linux OS.In ESX, there is no general-purpose userland like you’d expect in Linux or Windows.ESX is a purpose-built, bare-metal hypervisor operating system whose kernel (VMKernel) directly manages hardware resources and runs virtual machines.
Exploring the relationship between vSphere, ESX, and vCenter may clarify some of of the dangling question marks, if you have any.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: vCenter Server
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
vCenter is the service through which you manage multiple hosts connected in a network pool host resources.vCenter Server runs as a Virtual Appliance (VCSA) — a prebuilt VM — on ESX.Concretely: vCenter is not bare metal It is deployed as an OVA That OVA becomes one VM (sometimes functionally “a group of services”, but still a single VM) Internally, that VM runs: A hardened Linux-based OS vCenter services Database (embedded or external, depending on scale) Physical hardware └── ESX └── vCenter Server Appliance (VM) └── vCenter services vCenter Server is the centralized control plane Manages:
ESX hosts
vSphere Clusters
Resource Pools Policies Orchestrates:
vMotion
DRS
HA Lifecycle

vCenter Server does not run workloads: it tells ESX what to do instead.vCenter Server
Connects many ESX hosts. Maintains inventory and state
Enforces cluster-level logic. Orchestrates features that require coordination.
vMotion between hosts
DRS placement decisions
Cluster HA
Supervisor Cluster (for Kubernetes / VCF) vCenter Server is a set of backend services: Inventory (hosts, clusters, VMs) State and configuration database
Scheduling logic (DRS)
HA coordination
vMotion orchestration RBAC, roles, permissions APIs (REST, SOAP)

See vSphere Client for how a UI is served around the vCenter capabilities.You might want to check:
VCSA, which is directly-related to vCenter,
or ESX, which is the Type-1 Hypervisor that everything runs on
or Distributed Virtual Switch, if you are in a networking mood.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.title: VCSA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.description:
see also: Virtual Appliance
VCSA, is an acronym for “vCenter Server Appliance”
It is a Virtual Appliance for vCenter Server

In VCF, VCSA is the central control plane for vSphere infrastructure—the brain that manages ESX hosts and clusters across domains. VCSA = vCenter, packaged as a Linux appliance VCF uses VCSA everywhere to manage compute No VCSA → no usable vSphere → no VCF Think of VCF as an orchestration stack, and VCSA as the authoritative source of truth for the compute state.Inside VCF, VCSA is responsible for:
Manages ESX hosts Forms and manages vSphere clusters Enforces cluster features:
HA
DRS
vMotion
Resource Pools Everything “higher” in the stack talks to VCSA:
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
NSX (for host/cluster attachment)
vSphere Supervisor (Kubernetes-on-vSphere) If something needs to know “what hosts exist?” or “where does this VM live?”, it asks VCSA. Integrates with SSO / identity providers Issues and validates service identities Acts as a trust anchor for many workflows VCF is domain-based, and each domain has its own VCSA. Always present Contains: VCSA
NSX Manager
SDDC Manager Manages itself and workload domains Each workload domain has: Its own VCSA
Its own NSX Isolated lifecycle and fault domains This separation is deliberate: Different upgrade cadences Different blast radii Different tenants / purposes When someone says “VCF manages vSphere” what they actually mean is “VCF automates VCSA, which in turn manages ESX” The Supervisor Cluster runs on vSphere But: VCSA creates it VCSA owns its lifecycle VCSA exposes it via vSphere APIs Kubernetes is embedded into vSphere, but VCSA remains the authority.Without VCSA: No cluster
No HA/DRS
No vSphere Supervisor No VM lifecycle No policy enforcement
VCF is powerful because it standardizes and automates many VCSAs, not because it replaces them. VCSA = vCenter, packaged as an appliance It is the compute control plane inside VCF Every domain has its own VCSA All higher-level VCF services depend on it VCF orchestrates VCSA; it does not replace it
Since VCSA is a Virtual Appliance, you might want to look into Virtual Appliance too.
You might also want to check out ESX or vCenter Server as related components.

headers.heading: 2. API surface for everything above it

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/core-component.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: DRS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description:
DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler) is the vSphere Cluster service that continuously balances CPU and memory load by automatically placing and live-migrating VMs (via vMotion) across hosts.
In VCF, DRS is foundational, not optional.
VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster ├── HA → “Can the VM run?” └── DRS → “Where should it run?”
Implemented by: vSphere
Executed via: vCenter Server Acts on: VMs inside a cluster VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated for predictable behavior.
Initial Placement – chooses the best host when a VM powers on Continuous Balancing – monitors CPU and memory pressure
Live Migration – moves VMs using vMotion Rule Enforcement – respects affinity / anti-affinity constraints
If HA answers “Can the VM run?”, DRS answers “Where should the VM run right now?”
VMware Validated Solutions assume Fully Automated DRS.DRS continuously evaluates: Host CPU utilization Host memory pressure VM demand and entitlements
Resource Pool shares and limits Affinity / anti-affinity rules When imbalance exceeds a threshold:
→ vMotion is triggered → No VM restartDRS is performance and fairness, not failure recovery.DRS can enforce rules such as: “These VMs must stay together” “These VMs must never share a host” Typical use cases: App + cache locality HA for clustered apps Licensing constraints Over-constraining rules reduces DRS effectiveness. DRS respects:
Resource Pool shares
Resource Pool reservations
Resource Pool limits DRS balances within the rules you define — it does not override governance.
In VCF, clusters are typically:Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated ├── Admission Control: On └── vMotion: Required If DRS is disabled: Initial placement degrades Load hotspots form HA restarts may fail due to poor placement ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a scaling mechanism ❌ Not application-aware ❌ Not Kubernetes scheduling DRS operates strictly at the VM + host layer.❌ Disabling DRS for “predictability” → Creates hotspots and manual ops❌ Overusing VM-Host affinity rules → Breaks automatic balancing❌ Expecting DRS to fix under-provisioning → It redistributes; it does not create capacity
DRS is the brain of a vSphere Cluster It continuously optimizes where VMs run
VCF assumes DRS is enabled and automated
HA + DRS together provide resilience + efficiency
Fault Tolerance (FT) is the next related topic to explore after DRS.

headers.heading: DRS and Resource Pools
DRS inside VCF Workload Domains

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: Fault Tolerance
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description:
Fault Tolerance (FT) is a vSphere feature that provides zero-downtime protection for a single VM by running a lockstep secondary copy of that VM on another host.If the primary host fails, the secondary immediately takes over with no reboot and no data loss.
VCF inherits FT from vSphere; it does not redefine it.
VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── Fault Tolerance (per-VM feature) ├── Primary VM └── Secondary VM (lockstep)
Implemented by: vSphere
Configured in: vCenter Server Applies to: Individual VMs (opt-in)
Executes the same CPU instructions on two VMs simultaneously Streams execution state over a dedicated FT logging network On host failure → instant switchover, no restart
HA restarts VMs. FT never restarts them.
HA: “If the server crashes, reboot it elsewhere”
DRS: “Move servers around to keep things fair” FT: “Run two brains in sync at all times” FT is about continuity, not balancing or recovery speed.FT is powerful but expensive. Limited VM sizes (CPU / memory caps) No snapshots No suspend
No Storage vMotion Requires identical CPU features across hosts Heavy network and CPU overhead Because of this, FT is typically reserved for: Legacy apps that cannot tolerate any downtime Single-instance workloads with no clustering option VCF environments usually prefer:
HA + DRS for infrastructure resilience *Application-level [[HA]] (clusters, replicas, quorum()) Kubernetes controllers for pod-level restart
Site-level DR for disasters
FT remains available, but it is not a default design assumption in VCF.FT is like live brain mirroring: effective, but costly.❌ Using FT as a substitute for application HA ❌ Enabling FT broadly “just in case” ❌ Forgetting FT network requirements ❌ Expecting FT to scale like Kubernetes replicas FT provides true zero-downtime VM failover
It is a vSphere feature, inherited by VCF High overhead and strict limits
In modern VCF designs, FT is the exception, not the rule
Let’s check out vSphere Supervisor next, since it is “essentially” everywhere.

headers.heading: Where FT lives in the VCF stack
FT vs HA vs DRS
FT in a Practical VCF World

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.title: HA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.description:
HA (High Availability*) in VCF is the vSphere-native mechanism that automatically restarts workloads when a physical host fails**.It is not a single VCF feature; rather, VCF relies on and standardizes HA across its managed infrastructure.
HA is not invented by VCF. It comes from vSphere and is enforced consistently by VCF.VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── HA (enabled at cluster level) └── VM restart on host failure
Implemented by: vSphere
Configured in: vCenter Server Consumed by: All VMs running in VCF-managed clusters
VCF ensures HA is correctly configured, validated, and lifecycle-managed as part of its opinionated design.
Detect host failure → restart affected VMs on surviving hosts
ESX hosts exchange heartbeats A host stops responding Remaining hosts declare it failed vCenter selects new hosts VMs are restarted from disk Note that VMs are restarted, not live-migrated
Physical ESX host failure Power loss to a host PSOD / host crash Host isolation scenarios Guest OS crashes Application-level failures Storage corruption Network partition inside the VM Data loss between last write and crash HA answers “Is the VM running?”, not “Is the app healthy?”
In VCF, every Workload Domain cluster is typically:
HA-enabled
DRS-enabled Validated against design rules Example:Workload Domain └── Cluster ├── HA: Enabled ├── DRS: Fully Automated └── Admission Control: Enabled
VCF expects HA to be on; disabling it usually breaks design assumptions.HA includes Admission Control, which prevents you from powering on too many VMs.Purpose: Ensure enough spare capacity exists to restart VMs after a failure. If Admission Control says “no”: Nothing is broken You are overcommitted beyond your failure tolerance This is HA doing its job, not being restrictive.VCF HA is infrastructure HA, not cloud-native app HA.❌ Turning off HA to “fit more VMs” → Silent loss of failure guarantees❌ Expecting HA to replace app clustering → Wrong layer❌ Confusing HA with zero downtime → There is always a restart HA in VCF = vSphere HA, standardized and enforced It restarts VMs after host failure It does not provide zero-downtime or app-level resilience It is a non-optional baseline for VCF design assumptions
DRS and Fault Tolerance nicely complement HA.

headers.heading: Where HA lives in the VCF stack
HA inside a VCF Workload Domain

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/c.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: Resource Pool
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description:
A Resource Pool in VCF is a vSphere construct that carves up CPU and memory capacity inside a cluster and applies Governance controls (limits, reservations, shares) over how workloads consume those resources.
VCF inherits Resource Pools from vSphere; it does not redefine them.
Think of VCF as layered plumbing:VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere (via vCenter) └── Cluster └── Resource Pool └── VM / vApp
Owned by: vSphere
Managed through: vCenter Server
Consumed by: VMs (and vApps), including those provisioned via VCF Automation
VCF Automation may target a resource pool, but does not create a new abstraction here.A Resource Pool lets you govern contention, not create capacity. Resource Pools do not add resources — they only slice and prioritize what already exists in the cluster. Think of a cluster as a water tank: The tank size = physical host capacity Resource Pools = valves Shares = which valve opens wider under pressure Reservations = minimum guaranteed flow Limits = maximum allowed flow No matter how many valves you add, the tank size never changes.
VCF itself does not require Resource Pools, but they are often used: To separate platform workloads from tenant workloads To protect management components from noisy neighbors To enforce guardrails in shared clusters Example:Cluster ├── Mgmt-RP (high shares, reservations) │ ├── vCenter │ ├── NSX Managers │ └── Tenant-RP ├── App-VMs ├── DB-VMs ❌ Overusing limits → Causes artificial throttling and unpredictable latency❌ Deeply nested pools → Shares become multiplicative and hard to reason about❌ Using pools as security boundaries → They are not isolation mechanisms ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not a billing unit ❌ Not a Kubernetes namespace ❌ Not a quota system (that’s layered above, e.g., VCF Automation)
A Resource Pool is a vSphere scheduling construct, fully inherited by VCF It controls CPU and memory contention, not ownership or tenancy
VCF Automation may reference it, but does not redefine it Use sparingly, with clear intent and shallow hierarchies
HA, DRS, and Fault Tolerance are all related contents that you might want to explore.

headers.heading: Resource Pools in the VCF Stack
What Does a Resource Pool Do
How Does VCF Use Resource Pools

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: vSphere Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description:
see also: vCenter Server, ESX, Supervisor Cluster A vSphere Cluster (or Supervisor Cluster) is a logical grouping of ESX hosts that vCenter treats as a single resource pool and failure domain. It exists only in vCenter ESX hosts do not know they are “in a cluster”. When you create a cluster in vCenter Server, you are telling: “*These ESX hosts agree to be scheduled, balanced, and failed over together.”This enables cluster-level logic, such as
DRS (Distributed Resource Scheduler):
vCenter decides which host should run which VM. When to rebalance the load.
Uses vMotion to move VMs between hosts.
HA (High Availability) Hosts run a lightweight HA agent. If a host dies: Other hosts detect it
vCenter (or preconfigured HA logic) restarts VMs elsewhere. Shared resource abstraction Instead of thinking: Host A: 64 cores Host B: 64 cores vCenter presents Cluster: 128 cores VM placement and limits are logical, not physical.A vSphere Cluster is not:Because from an operator’s perspective: Hosts act like a pool Failures are absorbed Workloads move transparently But architecturally: The cluster is an illusion created by vCenter.
A vSphere Cluster is a vCenter-defined scheduling and failure domain over multiple ESX hosts,[ Physical Servers ] ↓ ESX (many hosts) ↓ vCenter Server ↓ vSphere features and automation
Supervisor Cluster is a vSphere Cluster that you might like to look at next, since it is a core component in everything VCF.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.title: vSphere Constructs
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.description:
see also: vCenter Server, ESX A vSphere Construct is: *A first-class infrastructure object that is _natively defined, owned, and enforced by the vSphere control plane (ESX + vCenter), not by Kubernetes or higher-level automation layers.
Think of it as a primitive in vSphere’s own vocabulary. These are things that exist because vSphere exists; they are not abstractions layered on top. Virtual Machine
vCPU
vNUMA
vApp
Resource Pool Shares / Limits / Reservations
DRS rules
HA Admission Control Datastore
vSAN Object
VM disk (VMDK) Storage Policy Port Group
Distributed Virtual Switch
VM NIC
VLAN / overlay constructs Snapshot Clone
vMotion Storage vMotion
HA restart
Fault Tolerance
All of these are authoritative in vSphere and enforced by:
ESX
and vCenter Server If you want to get closer to the metal, all of these are relevant areas to explore:
VM NIC
VMDK
vApp
vCPU
vNUMA
Virtual Machine
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/o.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vApp
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
A vApp is a logical container in VMware that groups multiple VMs into a single, manageable application unit with shared lifecycle, networking, and (optionally) resource policies.It is best thought of as “an application-shaped wrapper around several VMs.”A vApp is a construct in VMware that lets you manage a set of related VMs as one application, with coordinated startup order, shared networking, and optional resource controls.vApps live and are managed in vCenter Server.vApps were created to solve a very specific problem: “How do I deploy and operate a multi-VM application as a single unit?” Before Kubernetes, before Helm, before Operators—this was VMware’s answer.vApp: OnlineStore ├── Web VM ├── API VM └── Database VM You can: Power on/off the whole application Clone or export it Track it as a single object Critical feature.You can define: DB starts first App tier next Web tier last Reverse order on shutdown This was huge in pre-container days.Inside a vApp you can: Define isolated networks Connect VMs to internal-only networks Attach uplinks at the vApp boundary It is like a “mini datacenter boundary for this application”.vApps support: OVF / OVA packaging Application-level metadata Deployment parameters (IP, hostname, etc.) This made vApps attractive for: ISVs Appliances Repeatable deployments vApp is an organizational and orchestration construct, not a runtime.vApps were ahead of their time, but eventually outpaced by containers.vApps are still relevant in:
VMware Virtual Appliances (OVA-based) Legacy multi-VM apps Demo environments Lab setups But, they are rare in modern Cloud Native stacks: Kubernetes replaced the need
VCF Automation layers supersede it GitOps models don’t map cleanly
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.

headers.heading: How vApps compare to Modern Constructs
Where vApps are still used today

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vCPU
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
In the context of vCenter Server, a vCPU (virtual CPU) is a logical processor that vCenter assigns to a Virtual Machine, abstracting and time-sharing the physical CPUs (pCPUs) of the underlying ESX hosts.You can think of it as CPU time and execution context, not a physical core.
A vCPU is a scheduling unit presented to a Virtual Machine, which the ESX scheduler maps onto physical CPU cores or hardware threads on demand.A VM with 4 vCPUs does not get 4 dedicated cores: It gets permission to run up to 4 execution threads concurrently when physical CPU time is available.A vCPU is not: a physical core pinned hardware (unless you explicitly do CPU pinning) a guaranteed slice of CPU time A vCPU is: a schedulable execution context
backed by ESX’s CPU scheduler mapped dynamically to cores or hyperthreads exposed to the guest OS as a CPU socket or core
ESX uses time-slicing + SMT awareness Multiple vCPUs can run on the same physical core at different times There is no 1:1 relationship unless: CPU affinity is configured (rare, advanced, some Telco use cases demand it) Real-time workloads are used vCenter itself does not execute workloads. It: Defines VM configuration (number of vCPUs) Enforces resource policies: CPU limits CPU reservations Shares
Coordinates placement decisions (DRS) Observes performance (CPU Ready, Co-Stop, etc.)
The actual execution and scheduling happens on ESX hosts.When you assign vCPUs, you also define topology: Sockets Cores per socket Example: 4 vCPUs as 1 socket × 4 cores or 2 sockets × 2 cores This affects: Guest OS licensing
NUMA behavior Cache locality Some applications (databases, especially)
vCenter Server lets you control this explicitly.Oversubscription is normal, expected, and intentional.In real environments: Physical cores: 32 Total vCPUs across VMs: 200+ This is normal.This will work because: Most VMs are idle most of the time
ESX schedules based on demand Problems only appear when too many vCPUs want to run at once CPU Ready Time is one of the key metrics here: vCPU wants to run but can’t get scheduled. Start small (1–2 vCPUs) Scale up, not down Avoid wide VMs unless needed Watch: CPU Ready Co-Stop (for multi-vCPU VMs) Prefer fewer vCPUs with higher utilization over many idle vCPUs vCPU = schedulable execution context, not a core
vCenter Server defines and governs, ESX executes and schedules Oversubscription is by design More vCPUs ≠ more performance Correct sizing matters more than raw allocation
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: VM NIC
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
A VM NIC (often written vNIC) is a virtualized network adapter presented to a virtual machine by the hypervisor. From the guest OS’s point of view, it behaves like a physical Ethernet card; from the host’s point of view, it’s a software object that plugs into VMware’s virtual networking stack.Effectively, it is a software Ethernet card that lives inside the VM. Appears as a standard network adapter (e.g., Intel or VMware-branded) Has: A MAC address Link state (up/down) One or more IP addresses assigned by the guest OS Drivers inside the VM talk to it just like real hardware The vNIC is backed by VMware virtual networking It connects to: A vSwitch (Standard or Distributed) A Port Group Traffic is then forwarded to: Other VMs The host The physical network via uplinks (pNICs) VMware supports multiple vNIC “models,” each with different tradeoffs:A typical path looks like this:[ VM ] | [vNIC] | [Port Group] | [vSwitch (VSS or VDS)] | [pNIC / Uplink] | [Physical Network] Port Group defines policies (VLAN, security, shaping) vSwitch is the virtual L2 switch pNICs are the host’s physical NICs Multiple vNICs per VM Separate traffic (management, data, backup)
SR-IOV VM bypasses vSwitch and talks almost directly to hardware Very high performance, less flexibility Traffic Shaping and Security Promiscuous mode MAC changes Forged transmits A VM NIC (vNIC) is a virtual Ethernet adapter attached to a VM It connects the VM to VMware’s virtual networking stack VMXNET3 is the modern, high-performance choice Networking is enforced through port groups and vSwitches Multiple vNICs, policies, and offloads make it far more flexible than physical NICs
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.

headers.heading: Common VM NIC types in VMware
How a VM NIC connects to the Network

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Object Model/Virtual Machine Primitives/VM NIC.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: VMDK
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
In VMware virtualization, VMDK stands for Virtual Machine Disk. It is the file format used by VMware to represent a virtual hard disk—the persistent storage attached to a virtual machine.A VMDK file behaves like a physical hard drive, but for a VM. From the guest OS point of view, it looks like /dev/sda, C:\, etc. From the ESX’s point of view, it’s one or more files on a datastore.VMDKs are stored on VMware datastores, which may be backed by: VMFS (block storage) NFS
vSAN Local disks Object storage (via vSAN ESA / integrations) A “VMDK” is usually not a single file: Ends in .vmdk Contains metadata: Disk size Geometry Provisioning type Backing extent file name Examples: disk-flat.vmdk disk-s001.vmdk, disk-s002.vmdk Holds the actual data blocks Snapshots and special configurations add more files.In the VMware ecosystem:
ESX handles block I/O VMDK is the disk abstraction
vCenter Server manages lifecycle Storage Policy Based Management (SPBM) governs behavior
All of this is orchestrated under VMware Cloud Foundation.
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: vNUMA
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
Let’s start with physical NUMA.NUMA stands for non-uniform memory accessNUMA is a physical server architecture used by modern multi-socket systems. Each CPU socket has: Its own local memory Faster access to that local memory Accessing memory attached to another socket is slower non-uniform here does not mean “processes access memory unevenly”; it is from a hardware perspective, and simply means “memory access latency is not the same for all memory locations”Hence: Memory access time is not uniformYou can think of it as: Two cities (CPU sockets) Each city has its own warehouse (memory) Shipping inside the city is fast Shipping between cities takes longer NUMA provides massive performance gain if locality is respected.Assume there is a workload that: Runs on CPU-0 But frequently accesses memory on CPU-1 Then, performance will drop due to latency and cache penalties. This is invisible at the OS level unless NUMA-aware.In a NUMA-aware system, CPU threads are scheduled to prefer running on CPUs that are near the memory they already use, not the other way around. All DRAM is: Equidistant (or close enough) Reached through a shared memory controller or fabric Differences exist, but: They are not tied to CPU identity They are mostly hidden from software Software does not (and cannot) reason about “which CPU core owns which memory” From the OS perspective: “Memory is one big pool” Latency variance exists, but not topologically anchored. In contrast, in NUMA, each CPU socket has its own local memory controller and DRAM; remote memory is reached via an interconnect and is slower.vNUMA is how a hypervisor exposes NUMA topology to a VM. The VM sees virtual NUMA nodes Each vNUMA node has: vCPUs Assigned memory Guest OS can schedule intelligently inside the VM vNUMA is NUMA-awareness for virtual machinesWithout vNUMA: Guest OS thinks memory is uniform Hypervisor silently shuffles memory Cache locality is lost With vNUMA: Guest OS: Allocates memory locally Schedules threads close to memory Databases, JVMs, etc., perform much better Tangential (but not directly-related-to) NUMA is SR-IOV.
SR-IOV allows one physical PCIe device (NIC, GPU, HBA) to present: One Physical Function (PF) Multiple Virtual Functions (VFs) The number of VFs an SR-IOV-enabled device can expose is fundamentally limited by the device’s hardware design, firmware, and onboard resources.SR-IOV devices expose a capability like:Total VFs supported: NThis value is: Burned into silicon Sometimes further capped by firmware Sometimes configurable downward (but not upward) Typical real-world numbers: 8 16 32 64 128 (High-end SmartNICs may go higher) You cannot exceed this, no matter what the OS or hypervisor wants.Each VF: Can be assigned directly to a VM Bypasses the hypervisor datapath When a VF is assigned: The VF is bound to the VM The VM sees it as a native PCIe device The guest driver talks directly to hardware Packets do not traverse: vSwitch vNIC vDS software datapaths
ESX does not schedule or inspect traffic This is why SR-IOV delivers: Near bare-metal latency Deterministic throughput Minimal jitter
vMotion flexibility (often) Snapshot support (often) Hypervisor mediation Some observability They solve different problems:An SR-IOV VF is physically attached to: A PCIe root complex Which belongs to one NUMA node If: VM vCPUs run on NUMA node 0 SR-IOV NIC VF is on NUMA node 1 You now have remote memory + remote I/O: Worst-case latency scenario.This is critical for performance workloads.When using SR-IOV: Align: VM vCPUs VM memory PCIe device To the same NUMA node This may require: NUMA-aware placement Host pinning Careful cluster design
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Trust Authority
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Trust Authority (vTA) is a hardware-rooted security feature that separates “who can decrypt and attest” from “who runs the workload.”It uses trusted execution and attestation so that even infrastructure administrators cannot access protected secrets or plaintext data.In VCF, vTA is an optional, high-assurance security capability, not a default baseline.VMware Cloud Foundation ├── Trust Authority Cluster (isolated) │ ├── Key Provider / Attestation Services │ └── Hardware-backed trust (TPM, TEE) │ └── Workload Domains └── Protected VMs / workloads
Implemented by: vSphere Integrated with: Key Management Interoperability Protocol (KMIP) providers
Managed through: vCenter Server Classic virtualization problem: Infrastructure admins can ultimately see everything. vTA introduces cryptographic separation of duties: Infra admins manage hosts and clusters They do NOT control keys Decryption happens only after hardware attestation This matters in: Regulated environments Confidential Computing Insider-threat models Sovereign cloud designs Trust Authority Cluster boots with TPM-backed identity Hosts and workloads are attested Only if attestation passes: Encryption keys are released Protected workloads decrypt and run If trust breaks: Keys are withheld Workloads remain encrypted / suspended Access to infrastructure ≠ access to data
Separate ESX cluster Minimal admin surface Hosts key and attestation services Uses CPU security features (e.g., SEV, TDX) Prevents memory inspection Keys never live with workload admins Often backed by HSMs vTA is the strongest isolation boundary in vSphere.Typical usage: Confidential VMs Telco and Financial Workloads Government / Sovereign Clouds Typical non-usage: General enterprise clusters Cost-sensitive environments Dev/Test VTA is deliberately heavyweight.Think of vTA as: “Even if someone owns the data center, they still cannot read the data.” It is zero-trust applied to virtualization itself. ❌ Not a secrets manager ❌ Not an identity provider ❌ Not Kubernetes confidential computing (though complementary) ❌ Not required for VCF Strongest insider-threat protection Hardware-rooted trust Clear separation of duties Additional clusters and hardware Operational complexity Limited workload compatibility vSphere Trust Authority brings confidential computing to VCF It cryptographically separates infra admins from data access Optional, niche, but extremely powerful Used when “root access is not enough” must be enforced
You might want to check out NSX, NSX Manager, and NSX Edge Clusters.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A mode / capability of a vSphere cluster Means: “This vSphere cluster has Kubernetes enabled and is running the Supervisor control plane” or less wordy: “*a vSphere cluster with Supervisor enabled”. Not a physical thing by itself Think of it as a feature flag + control plane. A vSphere Cluster with Supervisor enabled A concrete, addressable object: ESX hosts vCenter-managed cluster Supervisor control plane VMs This is what you actually connect to with kubectl In practice, people often say: “deploy this on Supervisor” “connect to the Supervisor” “namespace on Supervisor” What they mean is: “the Kubernetes API exposed by the Supervisor-enabled vSphere cluster” So colloquially: Supervisor ≈ Supervisor Cluster But technically: Supervisor = the Kubernetes capability Supervisor Cluster = the vSphere cluster running it
You might want to check vSphere Supervisor to dive deeper into the Supervisor internals, or vSphere Supervisor Components to see core components that make up vSphere Supervisor.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VM Workload and Pod Workload
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
In VCF, a workload is: A unit of compute that consumes CPU, memory, storage, and networking, and is subject to lifecycle, policy, and governance. VCF doesn’t care what the workload is at a philosophical level. It cares about: How it is instantiated How it is isolated How it is scheduled How it is governed Which control plane owns it one virtual machine per workloadA VM Workload is a traditional virtual machine: Runs on ESX Has its own guest OS Is managed by vCenter Uses vSphere Constructss directly
vCenter Server is the authoritative control plane VCF Automation wraps vCenter, but does not replace it CPU / memory allocated per VM Strong isolation via hypervisor boundaries Overcommitment controlled at ESX level Create VM Power on/off Snapshot Clone Patch guest OS Backup VM image VM policies Placement rules Affinity / anti-affinity HA / DRS Backup & DR policies many disposable units forming a service.
A Pod Workload is a Kubernetes Pod running on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster.
A pod on the vSphere Supervisor Cluster is not a traditional Kubernetes pod. It is a vSphere Pod—Kubernetes-shaped, but vSphere-implemented.Key point:
A Pod Workload (vSphere Pod) is not a VM pretending to be a container.
vSphere Pods are VMs implementing container semantics, not containers implemented as VMs.
A vSphere Pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose execution unit is a micro-VM, where the VM boundary replaces the Linux container boundary. The VM is the isolation primitive The Pod is the semantic primitive The container image is payload, not a process model So the VM is not “pretending to be a container”—it is implementing the Pod abstraction using a VM instead of a process. Pod (Kubernetes API object) └─ Backed by └─ Ultra-lightweight VM └─ ESX └─ Hardware It is: A Kubernetes-native unit Scheduled by Kubernetes Governed by Kubernetes APIs
Backed by vSphere under the hood
Kubernetes API (Supervisor Cluster) is authoritative
vCenter supplies infrastructure, not lifecycle semantics
VCF Automation governs Kubernetes intent, not individual pods CPU / memory requested via Kubernetes requests and limits Scheduler decides placement Isolation via: Namespaces RBAC Pod security Declarative (YAML) Reconciliation-based Pods are ephemeral Restart ≠ failure Replacement is normal Namespace-level quotas Admission control Image policies Network policies VM workloads → legacy, stateful, pet-like systems Pod workloads (vSphere Pods) → cloud-native, stateless, cattle-like systems VCF’s value is: Running both on the same physical infrastructure, with unified policy and automation, without forcing one model onto the other. Trying to manage pods like VMs breaks Kubernetes. Trying to manage VMs like pods breaks operational reality.
VCF keeps them separate but coordinated.
A vSphere Pod (Pod Workload) in VCF is a Kubernetes-native execution unit scheduled and governed by the vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes control plane, consuming vSphere resources indirectly through Kubernetes abstractions—unlike a VM workload, which is a hypervisor-managed, OS-bearing unit directly governed by vCenter. “Pod workload” ≠ “small VM” Pod Workloads are Kubernetes-first, not vSphere-first VMs are stateful machines Pods are replaceable execution instances
VCF supports both because enterprises need both
As another platform extension, you might want to look in to vSphere Trust Authority.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Architecture and Core Concepts/VM Workload and Pod Workload.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Pod
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A vSphere Pod is a Kubernetes Pod whose sandbox runs inside a lightweight VM (via ESX]), not inside a container runtime on a shared Linux node.A vSphere Pod is the VMware implementation of a Kubernetes Pod, running as a lightweight virtual machine instead of a traditional container runtime.Each vSphere Pod: Runs inside its own virtual machine Has a dedicated Linux kernel Provides strong isolation similar to a VM Is optimized for fast startup and low overhead In other words, a vSphere Pod combines the security and isolation of a VM with the developer experience of containers.So: API semantics → Kubernetes
Runtime semantics → vSphere / VM Traditional Kubernetes Pods: Share a Linux kernel Rely on namespaces + cgroups Are fast and efficient But have weaker isolation (from a hypervisor POV) vSphere Pods were created to: Give VM-grade isolation While keeping Pod-level developer UX For multi-tenant / regulated environments This matters a lot for: Service providers Telco Regulated enterprise workloads “Pods from different customers must never share a kernel” Strong Isolation Each vSphere Pod runs in its own VM with a dedicated kernel, providing isolation comparable to a full virtual machine. Precise Resource Allocation CPU, memory, and storage are allocated exactly as specified for the workload. Efficient Scheduling
vSphere Distributed Resource Scheduler (DRS) places vSphere Pods on appropriate hosts based on available resources. High Performance The lightweight VM model preserves fast startup times while avoiding the “noisy neighbor” problem common in shared-kernel container environments. Operational Visibility Administrators can monitor and manage vSphere Pods using standard vSphere tools and workflows. vSphere Pods are compatible with the Open Container Initiative (OCI) specification.They can run OCI-compliant container images, provided the container image supports the target environment.
For a vSphere Pod to run, a Supervisor Namespace must be created on the Supervisor Cluster.

vSphere Pods rely on NSX networking.Key characteristics:
Networking is provided through the vSphere Supervisor
Pod networking is isolated and managed through NSX constructs Traffic management, routing, and security policies are enforced at the infrastructure level
Each ESX host runs a component called Spherelet. Spherelet: Acts as the kubelet for vSphere Pods Integrates directly with the ESX host Manages pod lifecycle operations (start, stop, monitor) Communicates with the Supervisor control plane
Spherelet allows ESX to participate as a node in the Kubernetes control plane without running a traditional Linux OS.vSphere Pods use multiple storage types depending on usage: Ephemeral VMDKs Used for temporary container storage.
Persistent Volume VMDKs Backed by vSphere storage policies and used for persistent data.
Image Cache VMDKs
Used to cache container images locally on ESX hosts. Storage policies define placement and performance characteristics.
Storage policies are assigned at the vSphere Namespace level.
Persistent volumes are provisioned through the vSphere Supervisor using CNS. Regular Kubernetes:Node (Linux) └── kubelet ├── Pod A ├── Pod B └── Pod C vSphere Pods:ESXi ├── Pod-VM A ├── Pod-VM B └── Pod-VM C No shared container runtime No shared kubelet per “node” Each pod is scheduled directly by vSphere Kubernetes still thinks it’s scheduling Pods — but vSphere translates that into VM placement.So in vSphereland, “One Pod ~= Tiny VM”
Kubernetes: Decides which pod should run vSphere: Decides where the pod-VM runs Enforces CPU, memory, NUMA, HA, DRS This is what “Kubernetes-native mode” really looks like under the hood. From the Pod’s perspective: It has an IP It mounts volumes It exposes ports Under the hood: Networking is NSX-backed Storage is datastore-policy-backe Attach/detach happens at VM granularity Again: Pod UX, VM machinery. Despite the VM runtime, vSphere Pods still use: Pod specs Containers Init containers ConfigMaps Volume mounts Pod lifecycle (create/delete/restart) Kubernetes Services (with some constraints) So developers mostly don’t care—and that is by design. Regular Pod → process in a shared OS vSphere Pod → process in its own micro-VM Or: Regular K8s → Linux container model vSphere Pods → “micro-VM container” model Essentially: vSphere Pods are not regular Kubernetes Pods They are Pod-shaped workloads backed by per-Pod VMs Kubernetes API semantics remain intact Runtime isolation is hypervisor-level This is intentional and central to Supervisor’s design vSphere Pods are VM-backed Kubernetes pods with strong isolation.
They run on ESX hosts using Spherelet and Supervisor integration. They support OCI-compatible containers.
Storage, networking, and scheduling are all managed through vSphere Supervisor. vSphere Pods provide a secure, enterprise-grade alternative to traditional container runtimes.
VM Workload and Pod Workload compares and contrasts VM Workloads and vSphere Pods.

headers.heading: Scheduling is Co-Owned By K8s and vSphere

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Adding Security Policies to a Supervisor Namespace
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A Supervisor that uses NSX networking supports network security policies defined through a SecurityPolicy Custom Resource (CRD).
These policies allow you to enforce network-level controls for workloads running on the Supervisor, including Supervisor Pods and virtual machines, by leveraging NSX’s distributed firewall capabilities.As a DevOps user, you can define and apply a SecurityPolicy CRD to enforce network security rules within a Supervisor namespace.Security policies apply to:
vSphere Pods
VMs running in the Supervisor (including VKS cluster nodes) Other workloads within the same namespace
Access to a Supervisor Namespace Permissions to apply Kubernetes custom resources Create a YAML file that defines the desired network security rules using the SecurityPolicy CRD.Apply the policy to the target namespace using kubectl:kubectl apply -f policy-name.yaml This action instructs the NSX Operator to translate the policy into NSX distributed firewall rules.You can inspect the applied policy using standard Kubernetes commands.kubectl get securitypolicy policy-name kubectl describe securitypolicy policy-name Security policies applied through Kubernetes are also visible in the NSX Manager UI.From the NSX interface, administrators can: View applied firewall rules Monitor enforcement status Troubleshoot traffic flows
VCF provides network security for vSphere Pods through SecurityPolicy CRDs. Policies are applied at the namespace level.
Enforcement is handled by NSX, not Kubernetes itself. Policies protect traffic between vSphere Pods, VMs, and external networks.
Management is possible via both kubectl and the NSX UI.
← Back to “Supervisor Namespace”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Deploy a Confidential vSphere Pod
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
You can run confidential vSphere Pods on a vSphere Supervisor cluster. These pods use hardware-backed memory encryption to protect guest memory from being accessed by the hypervisor or other privileged components.This capability is powered by AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization–Encrypted State (SEV-ES).A confidential vSphere Pod is a Kubernetes Pod that runs inside a virtual machine configured with SEV-ES: This ensures that: Memory contents are encrypted CPU register state is protected The hypervisor cannot read or tamper with guest memory This is especially useful for workloads that require strong isolation guarantees, such as handling sensitive data or running regulated workloads.To enable confidential vSphere Pods, the following requirements must be met:
The ESX host must run on hardware that supports AMD SEV-ES.
ESX 7.0 Update 2 or later is required. SEV-ES must be enabled in the system BIOS.When enabling SEV-ES, configure the following: Minimum SEV non-ES ASID count This value must be set to: number of SEV-ES VMs + number of confidential vSphere Pods + 1 Example: 100 SEV-ES VMs 128 confidential vSphere Pods → Minimum value = 229 The maximum allowed value is typically 500, depending on hardware. To deploy a confidential pod, you enable SEV-ES at the pod specification level.Create a YAML manifest with the following key elements: Enable confidential pod support via annotation Explicitly set memory requests and limits (they must match) apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: photon-pod namespace: my-podvm-ns annotations: vmware/confidential-pod: enabled spec: restartPolicy: Never containers: - name: photon image: wcp-docker-ci.artifactory.eng.vmware.com/vmware/photon:1.0 command: ["/bin/sh"] args: ["-c", "while true; do echo hello, world!; sleep 1; done"] resources: requests: memory: "512Mi" limits: memory: "512Mi" Memory requests and limits must be identical for confidential pods. Apply the manifest:kubectl apply -f <yaml-file>.yaml Once submitted:
The Scheduler selects an ESX host that supports SEV-ES If no compatible host is available, the Pod remains unscheduled If scheduled successfully, the Pod runs with encrypted memory You can verify the pod deployment using:kubectl describe pod <pod-name> From the vSphere side, administrators can see the pod listed with:Encryption Mode: Confidential Compute Confidential vSphere Pods use AMD SEV-ES to protect memory contents. Encryption is enforced at the hardware level and is transparent to workloads. The feature requires: Compatible hardware ESX 7.0 U2 or later BIOS configuration for SEV-ES Configuration is done declaratively using Kubernetes YAML. The Supervisor ensures scheduling only onto capable hosts.
You might want to learn move about vSphere Pods.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Control and Consumption/Deploy a Confidential vSphere Pod.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor Namespace
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
#tenancy
A Supervisor Namespace (vSphere Namespace) defines the resource and security boundary within which workloads—such as vSphere Pods, virtual machines, and VKS clusters—run on a vSphere Supervisor.A namespace is the fundamental construct that binds together: Resource allocation Access control Workload isolation Policy enforcement
All workloads deployed through the Supervisor operate within a Supervisor Namespace (vSphere Namespace).A Supervisor Namespace: Defines where workloads can run Controls how much compute, memory, and storage they can consume Establishes administrative and security boundaries
Acts as the bridge between vSphere infrastructure and Kubernetes workloads
Namespaces are created and managed by Organization Administrators, not by Kubernetes users.When a Supervisor Namespace is created:
A corresponding Resource Pool is created in vSphere CPU, memory, and storage limits can be defined Quotas apply to all workloads within the namespace Limits are enforced at the infrastructure layer
If the vSphere Supervisor spans multiple vSphere clusters (zones), the namespace’s resource allocation is distributed across all participating clusters.Example: If a namespace is assigned 300 MHz CPU across a three-zone Supervisor: Each cluster contributes 100 MHz Scheduling is balanced across zones Access to a Supervisor Namespace is controlled through:
vCenter Single Sign-On (SSO)
External identity providers (OIDC) Administrators assign permissions to users or groups, defining what operations they can perform inside the namespace.This access model governs: Who can deploy workloads Who can view or modify resources Who can manage storage and policies A Supervisor Namespace can host:
vSphere Pods (VM-backed Kubernetes pods)
Virtual Machines
Supervisor Services
VKS cluster components All workloads deployed within a namespace inherit its resource constraints and access rules.A Supervisor Namespace is not the same as a Kubernetes namespace, even though it appears similar at first glance.A Supervisor Namespace contains Kubernetes namespaces, but is not itself one.
Organization Administrator creates a namespace in the Supervisor.
vSphere allocates backing resources and policies. Namespace becomes visible to Kubernetes users. Workloads can be deployed using standard Kubernetes tooling. Kubernetes users cannot create or delete vSphere namespaces.
Namespace lifecycle is owned by vSphere Supervisor, not Kubernetes. Namespace limits cannot be overridden from inside the cluster.
Namespace names are unique per Supervisor Cluster, not globally. The same namespace name may exist on multiple Supervisors.
A namespace belongs to exactly one Project.
Projects belong to a single Organization. Example:Organization: AcmeCorp ├── Project: Retail │ ├── Namespace: prod │ └── Namespace: stage └── Project: Logistics └── Namespace: prod Here, prod appears multiple times but in different Supervisor contexts.
A Project is a governance construct used to group and manage namespaces.
Projects define ownership and intent They map to one or more Supervisor Namespaces They are not visible inside Kubernetes
They exist only in the VCF Automation control plane Projects allow administrators to: Apply policies Enforce quotas Track ownership Control access Supervisor Namespaces are Kubernetes-compatible, but not Kubernetes-native. They look and behave like Kubernetes namespaces to workloads, but their lifecycle, limits, and permissions are governed entirely by vSphere. Supervisor Namespaces are the execution boundary for workloads.
They are created and managed by vSphere Supervisor, not Kubernetes. They enforce compute, storage, and security limits. Kubernetes operates inside these boundaries.
Projects and Organizations exist above namespaces to provide Governance.
Supervisor Namespaces are unique per Supervisor Cluster and not globally unique. You might want to check out:
Adding Security Policies to a Supervisor Namespace
Kubectl in Supervisor Cluster
Deploy a Confidential vSphere Pod

headers.heading: What Runs Inside a Supervisor Namespace

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS Cluster Storage
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
VKS clusters, like other workloads running in a Supervisor Namespace, require persistent storage.Persistent storage for VKS clusters is provided through integration with vSphere storage services, using storage policies and CSI-based provisioning.To provide persistent storage to VKS clusters, a vSphere administrator defines storage policies that describe required storage characteristics (such as performance, availability, and placement rules).These storage policies are then: Assigned to a vSphere Namespace Exposed to VKS clusters deployed within that namespace The storage policies determine: Which datastores can be used How volumes are provisioned How placement and availability rules are enforced Based on the assigned storage policies:
The vSphere Supervisor automatically creates corresponding Kubernetes StorageClasses These StorageClasses are made available inside the VKS cluster Each storage policy results in two StorageClass variants: One with Immediate volume binding One with WaitForFirstConsumer volume binding This allows DevOps teams to choose the appropriate provisioning behavior based on workload requirements.VKS clusters integrate with vSphere storage using Paravirtual CSI (pvCSI). pvCSI is a modified version of the standard vSphere CNS-CSI driver It runs inside the VKS cluster It handles all storage-related operations initiated from the cluster The pvCSI driver does not communicate directly with vCenter or CNS. Instead: The pvCSI driver forwards storage requests to the Supervisor The Supervisor routes the request to CNS (Cloud Native Storage)
CNS performs the actual storage operation in vSphere Unlike CNS-CSI, pvCSI: Does not require vCenter credentials Operates using a service account within the namespace Relies on the Supervisor for secure mediation
The following sequence describes how a persistent volume is created in a VKS cluster: A DevOps engineer creates a PersistentVolumeClaim (PVC) in the VKS cluster. The request is received by the pvCSI driver. pvCSI forwards the request to the Supervisor. The Supervisor invokes the CNS API in vCenter to create the volume. Once the volume is created, the information propagates back through the Supervisor. The PVC and corresponding PV appear as Bound in both: The VKS cluster The Supervisor view This ensures consistent visibility and lifecycle tracking across all layers. VKS clusters rely on vSphere storage policies for persistent storage. Storage policies determine where and how volumes are provisioned. The Supervisor mediates all storage operations between VKS and vSphere. pvCSI enables secure, credential-free storage operations from inside the cluster. Storage resources appear consistently in both the VKS cluster and Supervisor views.
← Back to “VKS”

headers.heading: How VKS Clusters Integrate with vSphere Storage

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.sourcePath: VCF/Core Runtimes/vSphere/Platform Extensions/vSphere Supervisor/Supervisor Internals and Platform Integration/Kubernetes Runtimes/VKS/Platform Integration/VKS Cluster Storage.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: VKS
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
VKS is essentially the evolution of what was previously known as Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service (TKGs). “What was formerly known as Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service (TKGs) is now unified under a single, intuitive name: vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS).” VKS is: Upstream Kubernetes + VMware’s opinionated lifecycle, security, and infrastructure integration. Runs on vSphere Worker nodes are VMs
Created and managed via vSphere Supervisor Tightly integrated with:
vSphere networking (NSX / VDS)
vSphere storage (vSAN, CNS) vSphere IAM / RBAC boundaries
Inside the Guest Cluster: Kubernetes sees: Namespaces RBAC CRDs Workloads It does not see: Organizations Projects Approval flows Business tenancy Those live outside the cluster, enforced by:
vSphere
vSphere Supervisor
Automation layers (i.e., VCF Automation) This is similar to saying “a Docker container does not know which Jira project paid for the VM it runs on”.vSphere / ESX └── Supervisor Cluster └── Supervisor Namespace └── TKG Workload Cluster (guest cluster) ├── Kubernetes API ├── Nodes = VMs └── Apps / Pods
VKS exposes three layers of controllers to manage the lifecycle of a VKS cluster.
VKS provisions clusters that include the components necessary to integrate with the underlying vSphere Namespace resources. These components include: A Cloud Provider Plug-in that integrates with the Supervisor
Integration with VMware Cloud Native Storage (CNS) for persistent volumes Persistent volume requests from a VKS cluster are passed to the Supervisor, which handles storage provisioning.The Cluster API provides declarative, Kubernetes-style APIs for: Creating clusters Configuring clusters Managing cluster lifecycle Inputs to the Cluster API include: A resource describing the cluster itself Resources describing the virtual machines that make up the cluster Resources describing cluster add-ons The Virtual Machine Service provides a declarative, Kubernetes-style API for managing virtual machines and associated vSphere resources.Key concepts include: Virtual Machine Classes, which define reusable hardware configurations Lifecycle management of control plane and worker node VMs that host a VKS cluster The components that run inside a VKS cluster fall into four functional areas: Authentication Webhook A webhook running inside the cluster that validates user authentication tokens. Container Storage Interface (CSI) Plugin A paravirtualized CSI driver that integrates with CNS through the Supervisor. Container Network Interface (CNI) Plugin Provides pod networking capabilities. Cloud Provider Implementation Supports creation and management of Kubernetes LoadBalancer services. The VKS API is used to provision and manage VKS clusters. It is a declarative API accessed using kubectl and YAML manifests.You can download the VMware-enhanced kubectl binary from the Supervisor API endpoint.With the declarative model: You define the desired state (number of nodes, VM sizes, Kubernetes version, storage, etc.) VKS reconciles the actual state to match the desired state To manage a cluster: Define the cluster configuration in YAML. Apply it using kubectl. Update the YAML to modify the cluster over time.
VKS Cluster Networking
VKS Cluster Storage
What is a VKS Cluster dives deeper into VKS Clusters.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Guest Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
#tenancyIn VMware Cloud Foundation, a Guest Cluster (workload cluster) is a cluster dedicated to running tenant workloads—VMs or Kubernetes-backed workloads—as opposed to running the platform itself.
It lives inside a Workload Domain (VI Domain) and is where actual business applications execute.
Guest Clusters run applications; Management Clusters run the cloud.

Once a VKS Guest Cluster (also known as “Workload Cluster”) is bound to a Supervisor Namespace:
✅ The cluster knows which Supervisor Namespace it lives in ❌ It has no intrinsic knowledge of:
Organization
Project
Automation constructs Approval flows Business tenancy
^ all of these concepts stop at the **VCF Automation boundary.
When a guest cluster is bound to a Supervisor Namespace, we are talking about a VKS workload cluster created by the vSphere Supervisor.That implies: The cluster is created via Supervisor APIs
It is vSphere Namespaces-scoped
It is lifecycle-managed by vSphere
It runs on ESX using VM-based worker nodes VCF Platform │ ├── Management Domain │ └── Management Cluster (platform services only) │ └── Workload Domain (VI Domain) ├── Guest Cluster A ← tenant workloads ├── Guest Cluster B ← tenant workloads └── Guest Cluster C ← tenant workloads
A Workload Domain can contain multiple Guest Clusters Each cluster is an operational and failure boundary
Tenants never see the Management Cluster, but they consume resources from Guest Clusters Traditional virtual machines App servers, databases, legacy systems
Managed via vCenter
Governed via VCF Automation (orgs, projects, policies)
Supervisor-backed workloads
PodVM-based workloads
Supervisor Namespaces mapped to Projects The cluster itself is workload-agnostic; policy determines what lands there.This split is critical:
Tenants use vSphere Cluster-managed VKS cluster bound to Projects
Organization Administrators operate clusters This is where: CPU, memory, storage are consumed Network traffic flows Availability and performance matter most Each Guest Cluster provides: Fault isolation Upgrade isolation Security boundaries A problem in one cluster should not affect others.Clusters are upgraded:
Under SDDC Manager control In a controlled, validated sequence Independently of other clusters (within constraints) It is not: A management plane
A place for SDDC Manager or NSX Managers A tenant abstraction by itself A free-for-all environment A Guest Cluster is shared infrastructure, not a tenant.There is an important nuance here: Tenancy does not equal cluster Multiple tenants can share: The same Guest Cluster While remaining isolated via:
Organizations
Projects
Namespaces
NSX Microsegmentation Guest Clusters are capacity and fault boundaries, not business boundaries. Strong fault isolation Predictable lifecycle Flexible placement strategies Supports mixed workload types More moving parts Requires capacity planning Requires clear cluster placement policy
VCF optimizes for enterprise-scale control, not minimal topology. Guest Clusters are where applications run
They live inside Workload (VI) Domains
They are operated by Organization Administrators They can host VM and Kubernetes workloads They are shared but strongly governed
Supervisor Cluster complements Guest Cluster. You might also want to explore vSphere Supervisor. Or check Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster for a nuanced discussion of the terminology.
