vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Components
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Supervisor has the following components:
Supervisor control plane VM. You can select to deploy the  Supervisor with either one or three control plane VMs. For control plane HA, three VMs are recommended. The three  Supervisor control plane VMs are load balanced as each one of them has its own IP address.
VKS and Cluster API (CAPI). Modules running on the Supervisor and enable the provisioning and management of VKS clusters.
Virtual Machine Service. A module that is responsible for deploying and running stand-alone VMs and VMs that make up VKS clusters.
Spherelet. An additional process called Spherelet is created on each host. It is a kubelet that is ported natively to ESX and allows the ESX host to become part of the Kubernetes cluster.
Container Runtime Executive (CRX) component. CRX is similar to a VM from the perspective of hostd and vCenter. CRX includes a paravirtualized Linux kernel that works together with the hypervisor. CRX uses the same hardware virtualization techniques as VMs and it has a VM boundary around it. A direct boot technique is used, which allows the Linux guest of CRX to initiate the main init process without passing through kernel initialization. This allows  vSphere Pods to boot nearly as fast as containers.
← Back to “vSphere Supervisor”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Inventory
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
The vSphere Supervisor Inventory is a representation of the  Supervisor folder and its associated resources.
vSphere configures separate Supervisor folders for each Supervisor and all the associated resources. The namespaces and control plane VMs are mapped under the respective Supervisor folder isolating them from the resources of other Supervisors, even though names of namespaces must be unique within vCenter.
The  vSphere Pods within each namespace are segregated into a folder called “vSphere Pods”. This ensures their isolation from other VMs and VKS Clusters that are in the same namespace and allows distinct and precise privilege allocation.
Each Namespace folder includes all workload entities created under it, such as VMs deployed through VM Service and VKS
clusters (Guest Clusters). Additionally, each Namespace
folder contains a subfolder named vSphere Pods which contains all the vSphere Pods associated with the namespace. 
Since Pod VMs primarily serve infrastructure purposes, the  vSphere Pods folder is configured with restrictive permissions to prevent users from performing any direct operations on the pods.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Security
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
#tenancy
vSphere Supervisor leverages vSphere security features and provisions VKS clusters that are secure by default.
vSphere Supervisor is an add-on module to vSphere that is able to leverage the security features that are built into vCenter and ESX.
The Supervisor encrypts all secrets stored in the database (etcd). The secrets are encrypted via a local encryption key file, which is provided at boot by vCenter. The decryption key is stored in memory (tempfs) on the Supervisor nodes and on disk in encrypted form within vCenter database. The key is available in clear text to the root users of each system.  All etcd connections are authenticated with certificates that are generated at installation and rotated during upgrades. 
In vSphere Supervisor, you can run run confidential vSphere Pods on compatible systems. You can create confidential  vSphere Pods by adding Secure Encrypted Virtualization-Encrypted State (SEV-ES) as a security enhancement.
A VKS cluster is secure by default. Restrictive Pod Security Admission is configured in VKS Clusters. If developers need to run privileged pods or root containers, at a minimum, a cluster administrator must create a RoleBinding that grants the necessary access 
VKS cluster has tenancy. As a result, there is no privilege escalation avenue for cluster operators or users: The authentication token used to access a VKS cluster is scoped such that the token cannot be used to access the vSphere Supervisor or other VKS clusters. This prevents cluster operators, or individuals who might try to compromise a cluster, from using their root-level access to capture a vSphere Administrator's token when they log in to a VKS cluster.
← Back to “vSphere Supervisor”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor Storage
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
vSphere Supervisor components, applications, and workloads need to store and retrieve data. Some applications and objects might use transient fast storage, while others require storage that persists.A vSphere Zone is a fault domain that can fail independently from another zones. 
vSphere Supervisor supports different storage topologies for zones. These topologies define how datastores are attached to ESX hosts and how they behave during zone failures.
A zonal datastore is local to a single vSphere Zone. It is attached to all the ESX hosts that are part of the underlying cluster. It can replicate data to provide higher availability within the zone. Its availability depends on the zone. If the zone goes down, the zonal datastore also goes down. Examples of a zonal datastore include: non-stretched vSAN, non-stretched vSAN storage cluster, non-stretched VMFS or NFS external storage.
A cross-zonal datastore spans multiple vSphere Zones. It is attached to ESX hosts from all the zones it covers. It can be stretched storage, for example, stretched vSAN, or non-stretched storage that pools hosts from multiple zones, for example, non-stretched vSAN storage cluster. It typically replicates data across zones. It stays available if one of the zones goes down. Examples of a cross-zonal datastore: stretched vSAN, stretched vSAN storage cluster, metro storage cluster, non-stretched vSAN or vSAN storage cluster deployed from hosts across multiple zones.
vSphere Supervisor uses storage policies to integrate with storage available in your vSphere environment. The policies represent datastores and manage storage placement of such components and objects as control plane VMs, vSphere Pod ephemeral disks, and container images. You might also need policies for storage placement of persistent volumes and VM content libraries. If you use 
VKS clusters, the storage policies also dictate how the VKS cluster nodes are deployed.
Storage policies support any shared datastores in your environment, such as VMFS, NFS, vSAN, and vSAN ESA.
Depending on your vSphere storage environment and the needs of DevOps, you can create several storage policies for different classes of storage. When you enable a vSphere Supervisor and set up vSphere Namespaces, you can assign different storage policies to be used by various objects, components, and workloads.
For example, if a vSphere Pod mounts three types of virtual disks and your vSphere storage environment has three classes of datastores, Bronze, Silver, and Gold, you can create storage policies for all datastores. You can then use the Bronze datastore for ephemeral and container image virtual disks, and use the Silver and Gold datastores for persistent volume virtual disks.

Image Service, an ESX component, is responsible for pulling container images from the image registry and transforming them into virtual disks to run inside the pod.
Certain Kubernetes workloads that DevOps run on a namespace require persistent storage to store data permanently.
Persistent storage can be used by vSphere Pods, VKS clusters, VMs, and other workloads you run on the namespace. To make persistent storage available to the DevOps team, the vSphere administrator creates storage policies that describe different storage requirements and classes of services. The administrator then assigns storage policies and configures storage limits at a namespace level.

vSphere Supervisor uses several components to integrate with vSphere storage.
The CNS component resides in vCenter Server. It is an extension of vCenter management that implements provisioning and lifecycle operations for persistent volumes.When provisioning persistent volumes, the component interacts with the vSphere First Class Disk functionality to create virtual disks that back the volumes. In addition, the CNS server component communicates with the Storage Policy Based Management to guarantee a required level of service to the disks.
The CNS also performs query operations that allow vSphere administrators to manage and monitor persistent volumes and their backing storage objects through vCenter.
← Back to “vSphere Supervisor”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: vSphere Supervisor
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
#tenancy
vSphere Supervisor is a control plane built in vSphere that integrates desired state and a single consistent API directly in the hypervisor.
vSphere Supervisor enables native deployment and management of Kubernetes clusters, declarative virtual machines, and  vSphere Pods alongside traditional workloads. It transforms vSphere to an extendable platform by providing a declarative API for self-service provisioning of modern infrastructure services in a resource boundaries enabled by vSphere Namespaces
The vSphere Supervisor lives as a set of Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts, instantiated, wired, and governed by vCenter Server.
vSphere Supervisor:
Runs on: ESX
Created and managed by: vCenter Server Implemented as: Kubernetes control-plane VMs
Distributed across ESX hosts
Backed by vSAN / datastores
Networked via NSX (or VDS in simpler setups)
When you “enable Supervisor” in vCenter Server:
vCenter Server: Creates a special-purpose Kubernetes cluster Instantiates its control plane as VMs Pins it tightly to: Cluster membership Networking Storage Treats it as part of the infrastructure, not a tenant workload So the Supervisor is: Not a workload cluster Not user-managed Kubernetes Not a vSphere product you install
It is an infrastructure service owned by vCenter.Physical Hosts └─ ESX └─ vCenter Server (control plane) └─ Supervisor Cluster (Kubernetes control plane VMs) ├─ Supervisor Namespaces ├─ vSphere Pods └─ Guest / Workload Clusters
The vSphere Supervisor is a Kubernetes control plane deployed as system-managed VMs on ESX, whose lifecycle is owned entirely by vCenter Server and whose purpose is to expose Kubernetes semantics directly on vSphere infrastructure.
The vSphere Supervisor physically lives as a vCenter-managed Kubernetes control-plane VMs running on ESX hosts inside a vSphere Cluster. vSphere Supervisor is the foundation of VCF consumption and can be enabled during workload domain creation or directly in vCenter.
It transforms vSphere Clusters into modern application platforms by embedding a platform-level Kubernetes control plane directly into ESX hosts, exposing a unified declarative API surface.
This integration allows end users to provision and manage workloads, including VMs, containers via vSphere Pods, full Kubernetes clusters through VKS, OCI image registries, and data services through a consistent API interface.
vSphere Supervisor maintains enterprise-grade Governance, security, and operational consistency through vCenter, VCF Operations, and VCF Automation.
vSphere Supervisor's namespaces provide the foundation for multi-tenancy, enabling GitOps-based workflows, and delivering cloud-like self-service in private data centers.Kubernetes didn’t replace VMs. It replaced application scheduling semantics.VMware’s bet was:
"Instead of forcing Kubernetes to run on top of vSphere,
we will make Kubernetes a native execution mode of vSphere."
Supervisor is that bet made concrete. vSphere = substrate Supervisor = Kubernetes-native personality of vSphere VCF Automation = enterprise automation layer on top
vSphere Supervisor is vSphere running in a special Kubernetes-enabled mode. VCF Automation consumes what vSphere Supervisor exposes.
It is vSphere running in special Kubernetes-enabled mode.
VCF Automation consumes what Supervisor exposes.
You can think of Supervisor as vSphere with Kubernetes fused into its control plane.

When you enable Supervisor on a vSphere Cluster, you are activating a capability inside vSphere.
Supervisor runs inside ESX.
Uses vCenter as the control plane.
Creates Supervisor Namespaces. Exposes Kubernetes APIs, backed by native vSphere primitives. So conceptually, Supervisor is vSphere operating in "Kubernetes-native mode".
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces.

If classic vSphere is "run VMs", vSphere Supervisor is "Run anything (VMs, Pods, services)" with the same primitives.

Supervisor runs on ESX. It enables Kubernetes semantics backed by vSphere primitives.
VCF Automation is optional and sits above Supervisor.
Supervisor Namespaces look like Kubernetes namespace on purpose.vSphere (authoritative substrate) └── Supervisor ├── Kubernetes API (authoritative for some things) └── vSphere API/UI (authoritative for others) Kubernetes manifest → vSphere policy enforcement. Create VMs via VirtualMachine CRDs (VM Operator) Create Pods / Deployments Attach storage Attach networks (within guardrails) PVCs backed by vSphere storage policies Datastore selection via StorageClasses Policy-based placement Declare “I need this secret” Injector materializes it VCF Secret Service enforces access
Pods/VMs attach to NSX-backed segments Load balancers exposed via K8s Service abstractions You don’t manage NSX topology in YAML, but you consume it declaratively.
Infrastructure topology Tenancy and Governance constructs (Organization, Projects, Quoatas at Provider level, Approval, Chargeback) Those live in VCF Automation / vSphere UI, not Kubernetes.
So: vSphere Supervisor exposes a Kubernetes-native API surface for workload consumption (pods, VMs, storage, networking), while infrastructure topology, tenancy, and governance remain vSphere-and VCF Automation-controlled.

A vSphere Supervisor extends the vCenter inventory by introducing additional objects that represent Kubernetes-based workloads and their supporting infrastructure. Within the vCenter inventory, a Supervisor exposes and manages the following objects:
vSphere Namespaces represent logical application environments within the Supervisor. They define where workloads can run and what resources they can consume.Each namespace: Represents an isolated execution boundary Is backed by a dedicated resource pool Is governed by quotas and policies Is associated with specific users and permissions
For every vSphere Namespace, the Supervisor creates a corresponding resource pool.
In a single-cluster Supervisor, one Resource Pool is created per namespace. In a multi-zone (multi-cluster) Supervisor:
A Resource Pool is created in each participating cluster. Resource consumption is distributed across all clusters in the zone.
These Resource Pools enforce CPU and memory limits defined at the namespace level.
Each vSphere Namespace can contain multiple types of workloads:
vSphere Pods Lightweight VM-based pods managed by the Supervisor.
Supervisor Services Platform services deployed into the Supervisor environment.
VKS Clusters Kubernetes clusters provisioned and managed by VKS.
Virtual Machines Traditional VMs deployed directly into the namespace. Namespaces also encapsulate: Network configuration and connectivity Storage policies and persistent volumes Access to shared or dedicated datastores All networking and storage enforcement is handled by the underlying vSphere and NSX infrastructure.Each namespace includes role-based access control assignments that determine: Which users or groups can access the namespace What actions they can perform (deploy, modify, delete) Which resources they can consume Permissions are enforced by vCenter and integrated identity providers.`` ┌────────────────────────────┐ │ VCF Automation (ex-vRA) │ ← lifecycle, blueprints, polic ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere Supervisor │ ← Kubernetes-native control plane ├────────────────────────────┤ │ vSphere (ESX + vCenter) │ ← compute, storage, networking ├────────────────────────────┤ │ Hardware │ └────────────────────────────┘ Supervisor: Exposes Kubernetes + VM APIs Owns runtime enforcement VCF Automation: Consumes Supervisor APIs Provides self-service, governance, orchestration Supervisor enables capabilities VCF Automation operationalizes them
The next topic of interest would be Supervisor Services, that lists the platform-level extensions that vSphere Supervisor has.
Alternatively, you can check out vSphere Supervisor Deployment Options for various small-to-large-scale deployment topologies.Also, for a deeper dive into vSphere Supervisor you can check out:
vSphere Supervisor Components
vSphere Supervisor Networking
vSphere Supervisor Storage
vSphere Supervisor Security
vSphere Supervisor Inventory

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.title: vSphere
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.description:
At its core, vSphere is a compute, storage, and network abstraction layer: A distributed operating system for data centers.It manages large collections of infrastructure, such as CPUs, storage, networking, GPUs, and DPUs as a seamless and dynamic operating environment, and also manages the complexity of a data center.  It virtualizes physical infrastructure into managed CPU, storage, and networking resources.vSphere ├── ESX (data plane) ├── vCenter Server (control plane) └── Integrated services (HA, DRS, vMotion, etc.) vSphere is a distributed system that provides the following:The two core components of VMware vSphere are ESX and vCenter.
Whereas vSphere Client is the Web UI that interacts with the APIs of vSphere components.vSphere is a product contract, not a system.
ESX and vCenter are the systems that implement that contract.Here is how vSphere facilitates LCM:
Lifecycle management via pre-staging ESX images.
Near-zero-downtime live patching for ESX.
vSphere as a platform, manages workload performance in several dimensions: With its GPU support, vSphere improves workload performance for modern AI workloads
DRS enables automatic load balancing of resources allocated to workloads in a vSphere Cluster. Storage DRS optimizes VM data placement as the VM is created and used over time. Moving workloads seamlessly across the fabric, and ensuring things are always ship-shape, is what vSphere excels at:
High Availability with vSphere automatically restarts your VMs following physical machine failure.
Fault Tolerance provides continuous availability of any application in the event of a hardware failure with no data loss or downtime.
vMotion enables live migration of virtual machines with no disruption to users or loss of service, eliminating the need to schedule application downtime for planned server maintenance. Storage vMotion avoids downtime for planned storage maintenance. At vSphere security is by default, not an afterthought:
Identity Federation with Microsoft Entra ID, ADFS and Okta. Virtual Machine Encryption: Data-at-rest encryption for virtual machine data and disks.
vSphere Trust Authority: Remote attestation for sensitive workloads. Yesn’t.Saying “vSphere is ‘ESX and vCenter’.” is colloquially common, but technically incomplete.
See vSphere, ESX, and vCenter for a more nuanced analysis.
You might also want to check vSphere Constructs for an idea of what vSphere directly controls, and what capabilities it has.
You might want to check out vCenter Server, one of the core components that makes vSphere, vSphere.
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/vsphere.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.title: VCF Fleet Deployment
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.description:
There are several different way you can deploy a VCF Fleet, each with its own benefits and liabilities.


This model is ideal for organizations seeking a streamlined and scalable approach to deploying within a single availability zone or region. The design provides centralized management, enabling a unified framework for managing instances and vCenters through a single VCF Operations instance.
This is typically the first (and robust) starting point for deploying the first VCF Instance, with the flexibility to expand to multiple instances while maintaining centralized operations and automation.
This is an ideal choice for organizations that require robust protection against site-wide failures and the ability to recover critical workloads in the event of a disaster.By building upon the former deployment design, this approach integrates disaster recovery capabilities to ensure business continuity.
It leverages VMware's advanced tools and technologies, such as VMware Live Recovery, to enable seamless failover and failback between sites or regions. This design ensures that critical workloads are replicated and protected, minimizing downtime and data loss during unexpected events.Additionally, it supports flexible deployment models, including Single-Rack and Multi-Rack configurations, to meet diverse infrastructure needs.

VCF Operations utilizes replication or backup and restore mechanisms to protect components at a secondary site, while 
VCF Automation relies on backup and restore processes for recovery at the secondary site.

This is another Fleet Deployment topology with Fault Domains and Disaster Recovery, combining Disaster Recovery and High Availability capabilities.
You might want to switch gears and check out VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs.
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-fleet.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.title: VCF Installer
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.description:
VCF Installer is the one-time (or rare-use) bootstrap and bring-up tool for VMware Cloud Foundation.
VCF Installer’s sole purpose is to stand up the very first VCF environment and hand control over to SDDC Manager.
If SDDC Manager is the factory control system, VCF Installer is the factory construction crew that builds the factory in the first place.
VCF Installer exists to answer a very specific question: “Given raw hardware, how do I get to a fully functional VCF Management Domain with SDDC Manager running?” Once that answer is executed successfully, VCF Installer is done.VCF Installer is responsible for: Validating hardware readiness Validating network configuration Validating DNS / NTP / IPAM Validating credentials and certificates Orchestrating the initial deployment of:
ESX on hosts
vCenter Server
NSX
SDDC Manager itself
Management Domain components
This is Day-0 only work.Before anything is deployed, VCF Installer runs extensive prechecks, including: Hardware compatibility (HCL alignment) Network reachability MTU consistency IP pool correctness Time synchronization DNS forward/reverse lookup Credential access Think of it as a fail-fast safety gate: Better to stop early than build a broken cloud.VCF Installer typically operates with: Structured input (JSON / guided wizard) Explicit topology definitions Explicit IP assignments You declare what you want, and the installer executes a deterministic build.There is no concept of “incremental evolution” here: That belongs to SDDC Manager.It is not: A lifecycle manager A long-running control plane A tenant or consumption interface A policy engine An operations tool After bring-up: It is not used daily It does not manage upgrades It does not manage workload domains
Those responsibilities move entirely to the SDDC Manager.Once installation completes:
SDDC Manager becomes the authoritative owner VCF Installer steps out of the picture You can think of it as: VCF Installer creates SDDC Manager; SDDC Manager creates and manages everything else. A natural question is: “Why not just use SDDC Manager from the start?”Because: SDDC Manager itself must be deployed That deployment requires validated sequencing That sequencing must run before SDDC Manager exists VCF Installer solves this bootstrapping paradox. VCF Installer → kubeadm init
SDDC Manager → Kubernetes control plane (after init)
VCF Automation → Higher-level UX / APIs for consumers You don’t run kubeadm init every day, and you don’t run VCF Installer every day either. VCF Installer is a Day-0 tool It bootstraps the Management Domain
It deploys the SDDC Manager itself It performs strict prechecks and validation After success, it is effectively retired
Why not look into VCF Fleet Deployment?

headers.heading: Relationship to SDDC Manager

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-installer/vcf-insta.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.title: Gated SDK
vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.description:
VCF Gated SDK is a RESTful SDK around everything VCF.The VCF Gated SDK refers to the VMware Cloud Foundation Software Development Kit that is not publicly downloadable without authentication: You need to be an authorized VMware/Broadcom customer or partner to access it.So, “Gated” here means governed access, not technical limitation.In practice, “gated” means: You must log in to the Broadcom Developer Portal with valid credentials. Access is typically tied to an active support contract or partner agreement. The SDK download link is hidden until your account is verified for entitlement. VCF Gated SDK provides Java and Python libraries, API bindings, utilities, and sample code to automate and integrate with VMware Cloud Foundation. Contains proprietary VMware/Broadcom code. Ensures only licensed customers/partners can use it. Helps control distribution of sensitive API bindings and internal tooling. VCF is not a generic API platform; it is a validated system. Some APIs: Control core lifecycle Mutate global topology Bypass normal UI guardrails Can easily create unsupported states Exposing these APIs broadly would: Fragment platform behavior Break upgrade guarantees Explode support matrices So VMware/Broadcom chooses controlled exposure instead of full openness.Gated SDKs often include APIs that: Drive SDDC Manager internal workflows Orchestrate LCM sequencing Mutate domain-level state machines Access pre-GA or evolving models Bypass tenant-safe abstractions These are platform-builder APIs, not tenant or end-user APIs.A Gated SDK usually implies one or more of the following: Explicit enablement flag Contractual agreement Limited documentation access No backward-compatibility guarantees Direct escalation path to engineering Strong expectations of platform literacy You are expected to know what you are doing.A Gated SDK is official, but not democratized.It is not: Unsupported A hack A private backdoor A “use at your own risk” API It is supported; but with conditions.If you see something described as a Gated SDK, it usually signals: “This is powerful” “This can break invariants” “This is for platform-level integration” “You need approval and discipline” In other words: This is not a convenience API — it is a responsibility API. A Gated SDK is an official but restricted VCF SDK It protects lifecycle safety and supportability It is intended for platform builders, not tenants Access implies higher expectations and accountability It exists to balance power vs stability
You might want to explore other core VCF concepts from here.

headers.heading: Why Gated SDKs Exist in VCF

vcf/vcf-enablers/gated-sdk.html.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.title: VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs
vcf/vcf-enablers/vcf-sdks,-apis,-and-cli.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, “VCF SDK APIs and CLIs” are programmable control surfaces that expose VCF capabilities for automation, integration, and at-scale operations. They sit above the infrastructure components (vCenter, NSX, vSAN) and below higher-level portals, giving you deterministic, supportable ways to drive the platform.┌──────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ Portals / UIs │ │ - VCF Automation UI │ │ - SDDC Manager UI │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ SDK APIs & CLIs ← YOU ARE HERE │ │ - REST APIs │ │ - Official CLIs │ │ - Language SDKs (where provided) │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Platform Control Planes │ │ - SDDC Manager │ │ - VCF Automation │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Product APIs │ │ - vCenter / NSX / vSAN │ └──────────────────────────────────────────────┘
VCF APIs abstract platform intent (*domains, lifecycle, tenancy**), not raw hypervisor knobs.SDDC Manager REST APIs expose everything SDDC Manager knows and controls: Bring-up and expansion
Workload Domain lifecycle Host add/remove
Cluster creation End-to-end upgrades (LCM) Inventory, versions, and health These APIs are the authoritative way to automate VCF without breaking supportability. If it changes VCF topology or lifecycle, it goes through SDDC Manager APIs. CI/CD pipelines Infrastructure-as-Code tools
Day-2 automation frameworks Internal platforms and runbooks
These are about consumption and Governance.APIs for tenant-facing operations such as:
Organizations and Projects Policies and approvals
Blueprints / templates Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes-backed services) These APIs sit closer to business intent than infrastructure detail. SDDC Manager APIs → Build and maintain the cloud VCF Automation APIs → Consume the cloud These are both human and also script friendly.Used for: Diagnostics Operational workflows Automation-friendly scripting Break-glass scenarios It is a thin wrapper over SDDC Manager APIs, with guardrails.This is: A faster iteration than REST during ops An easier integration into shell scripts Provides consistent auth and context handling CLIs are not separate systems — they are API clients.These are language bindings.Where available, VMware/Broadcom provides SDKs that wrap REST APIs in native language constructs: Object models Typed requests/responses Auth helpers Pagination, retries, error handling These SDKs are ideal when: You are building a platform or product You need maintainable, testable code Shell scripts are no longer enough They do not:
Replace vCenter or NSX APIs Provide low-level tuning knobs Allow unsupported lifecycle paths Let you bypass validation logic
This is by design. VCF optimizes for predictability and supportability over raw flexibility. Git declares desired domains / versions Pipeline calls SDDC Manager APIs Platform converges safely Internal UI talks to VCF Automation APIs End users never see infrastructure details Health checks Controlled upgrades Capacity expansion All API-driven, no UI clicks. VCF SDK APIs are the supported automation surface SDDC Manager APIs control lifecycle and topology VCF Automation APIs control consumption and governance CLIs are just API clients Using these APIs preserves VCF invariants and supportability
Since it’s related to APIs, you might want to check out what a Gated SDK is.

vcf/about-vcf.html.description:
VCF is a full-stack Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) platform that delivers software-defined compute, storage, networking, security, and management.
Integrated automation enables a self-service platform to deploy VMs and containers for developer agility. Hardened platform offering built-in resilience, scaling, and clustering for non-stop operations.
It provides automation and orchestration to simplify Day 0, Day 1, and Day 2 tasks. It simplifies full stack deployment.
The purpose of VCF is to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.VMware Cloud Foundation is a unified private-cloud platform that combines the scale and agility of public cloud with security and performance of private cloud. delivering increased productivity and lower Total Cost of Ownership (TCO).VCF consists of the following parts:These are the heavy-lifters of VCF.

vcf/vmware-cloud-foundation.html.title: VMware Cloud Foundation
vcf/vmware-cloud-foundation.html.description:
VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) is a unified platform to design, plan, deploy, and manage your SDDC by using automation capabilities.That is one of the core tenents of VCF, and thus, it requires clarification before anything else.In VCF-speak, the phrase “a workload is a workload” is not a tautology—it’s a deliberate abstraction boundary.It means that VCF intentionally collapses many very different execution models into a single management concept, and refuses to care about their internal form unless it must.Below is the precise meaning, layered from philosophy, to architecture, to consequences.From VCF’s point of view, a workload is simply “something that consumes resources and is governed by policy.”It is not:
a VM a Container
a Pod VM
a Kubernetes pod
a Guest Cluster a Helm release Those are implementation details.VCF asks only: Where does it run? Who owns it? What resources does it consume? What policies apply? What lifecycle rules govern it? If those questions can be answered, VCF is satisfied.VCF exists above:
ESX
vSphere Clusters
vSphere Supervisor Kubernetes
VKS
VMs Containers If VCF tried to manage each kind of workload differently, it would: explode in complexity duplicate logic couple business policy to runtime mechanics So instead, VCF defines: Workload = Policy + Placement + Lifecycle + Resources Everything else is delegated downward.All of the following are equally valid workloads in VCF:VCF deliberately does not rank or privilege any of these.In VCF, a workload is anything that consumes platform resources and is subject to platform policy—its internal shape is intentionally irrelevant. VCF intentionally erases runtime distinctions Governance > implementation
Supervisor is the abstraction bridge If two things consume resources and obey policy, VCF treats them identically
vSphere Supervisor makes it possible.
vSphere Supervisor converts:
Pods to lightweight VMs
Kubernetes objects to vSphere-managed entities
Namespaces to policy and tenancy units From below, everything is Kubernetes.
From above, everything is vSphere resources. VCF sits above Supervisor, so it sees:
Resource Pools
Namespaces Quotas
Policies The kind or form of the workload becomes irrelevant.VCF does not care: whether the workload uses containerd or not
whether it’s a PodVM or classic VM whether it runs Go, Java, or Bash whether it was deployed via Helm, kubectl, or Terraform whether it is “cloud-native” or “legacy” Those are runtime-layer concerns, not platform-layer concerns. A power grid doesn’t care if you plug in a toaster or a server rack—only how much power you draw and what safety rules apply. This is why statements like these are true: “Pod workloads are not special.” “VM workloads are not special.” “Guest clusters are just workloads.” “Infrastructure doesn’t care about your app model.” So, you don’t fight against the platform to fit the workload in; you design the workload to fit the platform’s (opinionated) invariants.To internalize VCF, don’t think in: Pods vs VMs Containers vs Processes Control Planes vs Data Planes
Instead, think in Governance: Who owns this? What are its limits? How is it created and destroyed? How does it fail? How is it audited? Don’t anchor your designs to what runs. Anchor them to how they are governed.If this does not make sense initially, give it some time and revisit this page once you navigate this website further. I assure you it will eventually click.
For now, let’s keep a mental note of this, and dive deeper into the VCF rabbit hole.

headers.heading: A Workload is a Workload is a Workload
But, Why Does VCF Need This Abstraction

Although I conducted an extensive research to keep things consistent and factually accurate, due to the fast-evolving nature of VCF, the content on this site may be incomplete, outdated, or incorrect. THIS IS NOT OFFICIAL DOCUMENTATION. For authoritative and up-to-date information, please refer to the official VMware Cloud Foundation Documentation. This site is not affiliated with, endorsed by, or sponsored by Broadcom, Inc. VMware, VMware Cloud Foundation, and related marks are trademarks of Broadcom, Inc., or its subsidiaries. ^ That part taken care of, let’s get this rolling, shall we?Although its features degrade gracefully, this website is best experienced on a desktop browser (instead of a mobile browser), where you can navigate the graph view, and pin articles.It is specifically designed to give a more IDE-like experience.
This knowledge base is organized around mental models, not product marketing or step-by-step tutorials.If you are new, I recommend starting with one of the paths below, depending on what you are trying to understand.
If you are a visual learner, The Big Picture should possibly be the first thing to look at before diving any deeper: It nicely outlines how various VCF components and concepts link together.
Also, the concept of tenancy is a fundamental part of VCF, and it touches everything: I have tagged anything that directly or indirectly ties to tenancy with the #tenancy tag. Just tap on the #tenancy tag, and you will see list of relevant pages filtered on the navigation section.If you want to understand what VCF is and how its major pieces fit together:
→ VMware Cloud Foundation
→ VCF Concepts
→ Tenancy in VCFThis path focuses on structure, roles, and boundaries rather than implementation details.If you are interested in what actually runs and where workloads live:
→ vSphere
→ vSphere Supervisor
→ VKS
This path explains the execution model, including VMs, Pods, Supervisor Namespaces, and Guest Clusters.If you are trying to understand who controls what and how lifecycle and operations are handled:
→ VCF Automation
→ VCF OperationsThis path is useful for architects, platform engineers, and operators.If your focus is on guardrails rather than features:
→ Governance
→ STIG
→ VMware Validated Solutions
→ VMware CloudThis path covers cross-cutting concepts that influence design and operations.This content of this site is intentionally organized semantically, rather than taxonomically. So you will likely find the “graph view” (on the right) more useful than the folder navigation (on the left).Hope you enjoy the ride,
Volkan.

#tenancyIn VMware Cloud Foundation, the Management Cluster is the foundational cluster that runs the platform itself. It hosts the management plane—the services that build, operate, upgrade, and secure the rest of the cloud.Put simply: If the Management Cluster is down, you can’t manage the cloud—only the workloads keep running.
The Management Cluster is part of the Management Domain (a special Workload Domain). It is created first during Day-0 bring-up and is non-optional.Typical components include:
SDDC Manager
vCenter Server (management vCenter)
NSX Managers
vSAN management services These components do not belong to the tenants. They belong to the platform.It runs the services that: Define topology Enforce lifecycle sequencing Validate upgrades Maintain inventory and state All VCF lifecycle operations (create domain, expand cluster, upgrade stack) are coordinated from here.Tenant workloads do not run here (by design): No tenant VMs No tenant Kubernetes workloads No customer apps This protects: Stability Security Upgrade safety It is not: A tenant cluster A workload execution environment A shared resource pool for apps Optional or replaceable Treating it like a general-purpose cluster is a serious anti-pattern.This separation ensures: Predictable upgrades (no tenant interference) Clear blast-radius control Strong security boundaries Operational sanity at scale It’s the same pattern used by: Kubernetes (control plane vs worker nodes) Public clouds (provider plane vs customer plane) Management Cluster → Kubernetes control plane nodes Guest Clusters → Kubernetes worker nodes SDDC Manager → Cluster lifecycle operator You wouldn’t run apps on the Kubernetes control plane; same rule applies here. Management Cluster is typically: Small (minimum viable size) Highly available Strictly protected If it fails: Existing workloads keep running You lose management, scaling, and upgrades until restored The Management Cluster runs the cloud, not the workloads
It is part of the Management Domain
It hosts SDDC Manager, vCenter Server, NSX Managers It is isolated, mandatory, and high-blast-radius Treat it as sacred infrastructure
You can check out Guest Cluster or Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster for the next set of items to explore.Management Cluster“VCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Architectural Constructs/VCF Topology/Workload Cluster.md” could not be found.Create new noteSwap file...RemoveVCF/Concepts/Design and Abstractions/Architectural Constructs/VCF Topology/Workload Cluster.md
A VCF Domain is a core VMware Cloud Foundation platform construct.
It is defined and lifecycle-managed by VCF itself (via SDDC Manager).
VCF Automation consumes it for tenant self-service and provisioning.
VCF Operations observes it for monitoring, health, and capacity.
A VCF Domain is an isolated SDDC unit inside VCF with its own full stack:Each domain is independently lifecycle-managed (upgrade cadence, patch windows, scaling).
A VCF Domain in a VCF Instance consists of the following components:
One vCenter instance.
One or more vSphere Clusters with vSphere HA and vSphere DRS enabled.
At least one vSphere Distributed Switches per cluster for system traffic and NSX Segments for workloads.
Dedicated NSX Manager instance, either specifically for the VCF Domain or shared between VCF Domains, for configuring and implementing software-defined networking.
Optional: One or more NSX Edge Clusters, added after you create the Workload Domain, that connects the workloads in the Workload Domain for logical switching, logical dynamic routing, and load balancing. One or more shared storage allocations as principal or supplemental storage. There are two types of VCF Domains:
Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process.
Workload Domain runs consumer workloads on Day 2.
Management Domain and Workload Domain gives further context about VCF Domains.
You might also want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.VCF Domain![[workload-domain-b8d5ddd7-899b-4c34-8947-4acbd57f8f72.webp]
The Management Domain is created during the deployment or convergence process by the VCF Installer. It contains the management components of the VCF Instance and, for the first VCF Instance, VCF Operations and VCF Automation.In addition to the components that are common for each VCF Domain, the management domain includes the 
SDDC Manager Appliance and the Fleet Management Appliance, that adds workflows for infrastructure management automation to the VCF Operations instance for the VCF Fleet. Management Domain: is created first hosts VCF Control Plane components:
SDDC Manager
vCenter
NSX Manager
VCF Operations
VCF Automation
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.Management Domain

You create Workload Domains in VCF Operations to run consumer workloads.
For the first workload domain in your environment, VCF Operations deploys a vCenter instance and an NSX Manager instance in the Management Domain. For each additional workload domain, VCF Operations deploys an additional vCenter instance.New Workload Domains can share the same NSX Manager cluster with an existing Workload Domain or you can deploy a new NSX Manager cluster.
Workload domains cannot use the NSX Manager cluster for the Management Domain.A Workload Domain (or VI (virtual infrastructure) Workload Domain)
is created after Management Domain hosts customer workloads Typical separation: Prod vs non-prod Regulated vs unregulated Performance-sensitive vs general A VCF Domain is to VCF what a Kubernetes cluster is to Kubernetes-based platforms.It gives you: Failure domain isolation Security boundary Upgrade blast-radius control Operational independence Without VCF Domains, everything would be patched, upgraded, and potentially broken together.
In VCF Automation: A VCF Domain is a backing infrastructure boundary It is mapped to:
Organizations
Projects
Supervisor Namespaces VCF Automation never creates or upgrades domain: It only consumes them.
In VCF Operations: A VCF Domain is an observed object Used for: Capacity planning Health scoring Performance analytics Alerting Operations has zero authority over its lifecycle. VCF Domain is a foundational VCF concept Defined and lifecycle-managed by SDDC Manager Not a VCF Automation concept Not a VCF Operations concept BUT both products depend on it, yet neither owns it Primary purpose: isolation, lifecycle control, and scalability
You might want to check out VMware Cloud Foundation’s fleet and domain model by looking at VCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF Domains.Workload Domain
VCF management components are the platform control-plane services responsible for lifecycle management, networking, security, observability, and automation of the entire VCF instance, and are deployed exclusively in the Management Domain.
Here are the management components of VCF:
vCenter Server Inventory Cluster logic Resource scheduling API surface for everything else
ESX hosts (management cluster) Run the Management VMs Often capacity-isolated
NSX (NSX Manager + control plane) Networking for management workloads Overlay, routing, firewalling Required even if workload domains use different topologies
SDDC Manager Lifecycle orchestration Domain creation Upgrade coordination Configuration drift control These are management components even though they feel “optional”:
VCF Operations (formerly vRealize / Aria Operations) Telemetry ingestion Capacity planning Health modeling Alert correlation VCF Operations for Logs (if deployed) Centralized logging Audit & forensic workflows
These belong in the Management Domain because: They observe everything They are trusted with cross-domain data They are not tenant-scoped
VCF Automation (formerly vRealize / Aria Automation)
Tenant abstraction (Organization / Project) Approval flows Policy enforcement
Blueprint execution Self-service APIs Even though it models consumer behavior, it is still a management component because: It enforces platform policy It brokers infrastructure authority It is not itself a tenant workload Often overlooked, but these are part of the management plane too: Identity Integration AD / LDAP
OIDC (vIDB, external IdP) Certificates Internal PKI Trust distribution Secrets and credentials Platform credentials Not tenant secrets These may not be a single product, but they are a functional plane of the management domain.A good litmus test: If a tenant can delete it without breaking the cloud, it is not a management component.
Other topological constructs such as Workload Cluster, Management Cluster, or VCF Edge are all good options to dive from here.VCF Management ComponentsVCF InstanceVCF InstanceVCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF DomainsVCF Fleet, VCF Instance, and VCF DomainsVCF FleetVCF FleetAdministrative Roles in VCFAdministrative Roles in VCFTenants in SupervisorTenants in SupervisorvSphere SupervisorvSphere SupervisorESXESXvSphere ClustervSphere ClustervCenter ServervCenter ServerVKSVKSSupervisor NamespaceSupervisor NamespacevSphere, ESX, and vCentervSphere, ESX, and vCenterHAHA

Fault Tolerance (FT) is a vSphere feature that provides zero-downtime protection for a single VM by running a lockstep secondary copy of that VM on another host.If the primary host fails, the secondary immediately takes over with no reboot and no data loss.
VCF inherits FT from vSphere; it does not redefine it.
VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── Cluster └── Fault Tolerance (per-VM feature) ├── Primary VM └── Secondary VM (lockstep)
Implemented by: vSphere
Configured in: vCenter Server Applies to: Individual VMs (opt-in)
Executes the same CPU instructions on two VMs simultaneously Streams execution state over a dedicated FT logging network On host failure → instant switchover, no restart
HA restarts VMs. FT never restarts them.
HA: “If the server crashes, reboot it elsewhere”
DRS: “Move servers around to keep things fair” FT: “Run two brains in sync at all times” FT is about continuity, not balancing or recovery speed.FT is powerful but expensive. Limited VM sizes (CPU / memory caps) No snapshots No suspend
No Storage vMotion Requires identical CPU features across hosts Heavy network and CPU overhead Because of this, FT is typically reserved for: Legacy apps that cannot tolerate any downtime Single-instance workloads with no clustering option VCF environments usually prefer:
HA + DRS for infrastructure resilience *Application-level [[HA]] (clusters, replicas, quorum()) Kubernetes controllers for pod-level restart
Site-level DR for disasters
FT remains available, but it is not a default design assumption in VCF.FT is like live brain mirroring: effective, but costly.❌ Using FT as a substitute for application HA ❌ Enabling FT broadly “just in case” ❌ Forgetting FT network requirements ❌ Expecting FT to scale like Kubernetes replicas FT provides true zero-downtime VM failover
It is a vSphere feature, inherited by VCF High overhead and strict limits
In modern VCF designs, FT is the exception, not the rule
Let’s check out vSphere Supervisor next, since it is “essentially” everywhere.Fault ToleranceDRSDRSIaaSIaaS
In VMware Cloud Foundation, “VCF SDK APIs and CLIs” are programmable control surfaces that expose VCF capabilities for automation, integration, and at-scale operations. They sit above the infrastructure components (vCenter, NSX, vSAN) and below higher-level portals, giving you deterministic, supportable ways to drive the platform.┌──────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ Portals / UIs │ │ - VCF Automation UI │ │ - SDDC Manager UI │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ SDK APIs & CLIs ← YOU ARE HERE │ │ - REST APIs │ │ - Official CLIs │ │ - Language SDKs (where provided) │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Platform Control Planes │ │ - SDDC Manager │ │ - VCF Automation │ ├──────────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ Product APIs │ │ - vCenter / NSX / vSAN │ └──────────────────────────────────────────────┘
VCF APIs abstract platform intent (*domains, lifecycle, tenancy**), not raw hypervisor knobs.SDDC Manager REST APIs expose everything SDDC Manager knows and controls: Bring-up and expansion
Workload Domain lifecycle Host add/remove
Cluster creation End-to-end upgrades (LCM) Inventory, versions, and health These APIs are the authoritative way to automate VCF without breaking supportability. If it changes VCF topology or lifecycle, it goes through SDDC Manager APIs. CI/CD pipelines Infrastructure-as-Code tools
Day-2 automation frameworks Internal platforms and runbooks
These are about consumption and Governance.APIs for tenant-facing operations such as:
Organizations and Projects Policies and approvals
Blueprints / templates Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes-backed services) These APIs sit closer to business intent than infrastructure detail. SDDC Manager APIs → Build and maintain the cloud VCF Automation APIs → Consume the cloud These are both human and also script friendly.Used for: Diagnostics Operational workflows Automation-friendly scripting Break-glass scenarios It is a thin wrapper over SDDC Manager APIs, with guardrails.This is: A faster iteration than REST during ops An easier integration into shell scripts Provides consistent auth and context handling CLIs are not separate systems — they are API clients.These are language bindings.Where available, VMware/Broadcom provides SDKs that wrap REST APIs in native language constructs: Object models Typed requests/responses Auth helpers Pagination, retries, error handling These SDKs are ideal when: You are building a platform or product You need maintainable, testable code Shell scripts are no longer enough They do not:
Replace vCenter or NSX APIs Provide low-level tuning knobs Allow unsupported lifecycle paths Let you bypass validation logic
This is by design. VCF optimizes for predictability and supportability over raw flexibility. Git declares desired domains / versions Pipeline calls SDDC Manager APIs Platform converges safely Internal UI talks to VCF Automation APIs End users never see infrastructure details Health checks Controlled upgrades Capacity expansion All API-driven, no UI clicks. VCF SDK APIs are the supported automation surface SDDC Manager APIs control lifecycle and topology VCF Automation APIs control consumption and governance CLIs are just API clients Using these APIs preserves VCF invariants and supportability
Since it’s related to APIs, you might want to check out what a Gated SDK is.VCF SDKs, APIs, and CLIs

VCF Installer is the one-time (or rare-use) bootstrap and bring-up tool for VMware Cloud Foundation.
VCF Installer’s sole purpose is to stand up the very first VCF environment and hand control over to SDDC Manager.
If SDDC Manager is the factory control system, VCF Installer is the factory construction crew that builds the factory in the first place.
VCF Installer exists to answer a very specific question: “Given raw hardware, how do I get to a fully functional VCF Management Domain with SDDC Manager running?” Once that answer is executed successfully, VCF Installer is done.VCF Installer is responsible for: Validating hardware readiness Validating network configuration Validating DNS / NTP / IPAM Validating credentials and certificates Orchestrating the initial deployment of:
ESX on hosts
vCenter Server
NSX
SDDC Manager itself
Management Domain components
This is Day-0 only work.Before anything is deployed, VCF Installer runs extensive prechecks, including: Hardware compatibility (HCL alignment) Network reachability MTU consistency IP pool correctness Time synchronization DNS forward/reverse lookup Credential access Think of it as a fail-fast safety gate: Better to stop early than build a broken cloud.VCF Installer typically operates with: Structured input (JSON / guided wizard) Explicit topology definitions Explicit IP assignments You declare what you want, and the installer executes a deterministic build.There is no concept of “incremental evolution” here: That belongs to SDDC Manager.It is not: A lifecycle manager A long-running control plane A tenant or consumption interface A policy engine An operations tool After bring-up: It is not used daily It does not manage upgrades It does not manage workload domains
Those responsibilities move entirely to the SDDC Manager.Once installation completes:
SDDC Manager becomes the authoritative owner VCF Installer steps out of the picture You can think of it as: VCF Installer creates SDDC Manager; SDDC Manager creates and manages everything else. A natural question is: “Why not just use SDDC Manager from the start?”Because: SDDC Manager itself must be deployed That deployment requires validated sequencing That sequencing must run before SDDC Manager exists VCF Installer solves this bootstrapping paradox. VCF Installer → kubeadm init
SDDC Manager → Kubernetes control plane (after init)
VCF Automation → Higher-level UX / APIs for consumers You don’t run kubeadm init every day, and you don’t run VCF Installer every day either. VCF Installer is a Day-0 tool It bootstraps the Management Domain
It deploys the SDDC Manager itself It performs strict prechecks and validation After success, it is effectively retired
Why not look into VCF Fleet Deployment?VCF InstallerVCF Operations OrchestratorVCF Operations OrchestratorSupervisor ClusterSupervisor Cluster

about-me/my-mental-model.html.title: My Mental Model
about-me/my-mental-model.html.description:
I think of mental models as compression algorithms for reality.A mental model is an internal, simplified representation of how something works in the real world. It’s the framework the mind uses to understand, predict, and decide—often without conscious awareness.It is a map, not the territory.In my view, a mental model is: A conceptual structure in the mind Built from experience, learning, and assumptions Used to explain cause → effect and anticipate outcomes It answers questions like: “If I do X, what will probably happen?” “Why did that fail?” “What matters here—and what doesn’t?” Imagine driving in a foreign city. The actual city is reality: complex, messy, and full of detail Your mental model is a rough subway map in your head That map: Omits small streets Distorts distances Focuses only on what helps you get from A → B It is useful precisely because it ignores detail—even if it’s inaccurate in places.That is what this (mostly) directed acyclic graph of documents (with occasional—intentional—loops) is trying to establish for VMware Cloud Foundation: A navigable mental map, not an exhaustive representation of reality.The goal is not to describe everything, but to surface the abstractions that help me (and you, dear reader) reason correctly.Mental models exist because the human brain cannot process full reality in real time.Mental models: Reduce cognitive load Enable faster decisions Allow generalization from experience A single concept can be viewed through multiple overlapping mental models.For example, a database can be seen as: A storage engine A consistency system A failure domain A political boundary (ownership and control) Each model is incomplete on its own. Taken together, they are powerful. This document intentionally favors some mental models over others—not because they are “more correct,” but because they are more useful for the problems at hand.
← Back to Index

vcf/concepts/background-and-context/iaas.title: IaaS
vcf/concepts/background-and-context/iaas.description:
IaaS (infrastructure as a service) is a cloud computing model where you rent fundamental IT infrastructure—instead of owning and managing physical hardware.IaaS provides fundamental computing resources where the consumer can deploy and run arbitrary software, including operating systems and applications.In plain terms: IaaS = someone else runs the data center; you control the machines. The cloud provider gives you raw building blocks: Compute → virtual machines (VMs) Storage → block, object, file storage Networking → virtual networks, IPs, load balancers, firewalls You decide: Which OS to run How to configure the machine What software to install How to secure and scale it Analogy: Owning hardware → buying a house IaaS → renting an empty apartment (walls and plumbing are there; furniture and rules are up to you) Amazon Web Services → EC2 Microsoft Azure → Virtual Machines Google Cloud → Compute Engine All of these give you VMs, networks, and storage—but no application opinion.Example: IaaS → “Give me a Linux box” PaaS → “Run my app” SaaS → “Just let me use the app” Maximum control and flexibility Works for legacy apps Fine-grained networking & security Familiar mental model for infra engineers You manage OS patching and security Higher operational burden Easier to misconfigure Less opinionated guardrails vSphere-style VM workloads map very naturally to IaaS VCF abstracts hardware, but still exposes infra
Kubernetes-on-VCF starts moving you away from pure IaaS toward PaaS-like models
That’s why a workload is a workload is a workload: From the platform’s perspective, VMs and pods are both just scheduled consumers of infrastructure. IaaS = rented infrastructure You control the OS and above Most flexible, most responsibility Foundation layer beneath PaaS and SaaS Conceptually closest to traditional virtualization
From here, going back to the beginning and exploring VMware Cloud Foundation with an understanding of what IaaS is, is not a bad choice.

headers.heading: How IaaS compares to PaaS and SaaS

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.title: Policy
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.description:
#tenancy

A Policy in VCF is a Governance Rule that defines what is allowed, constrained, or enforced across infrastructure and workloads.
It exists across multiple layers of VCF, but it becomes a first-class, user-visible construct in VCF Automation.
If you think of VMware Cloud Foundation as a city: Infrastructure → roads, power, zoning Policies → zoning laws, speed limits, building codes
VCF Automation → city planning office that enforces them before you build
VCF Operations → inspectors that check compliance after things exist
These are foundational, implicit, and exist below VCF Automation, often enforced automatically.Examples: Storage policies (SPBM): RAID, availability, performance tiers
Network policies: NSX security groups, microsegmentation rules
Host policies: DRS, HA, admission control These are:
Defined in vSphere / NSX Consumed transparently by higher layers Not tenant-facing by default This is usually what people mean when they say “policy”.This is where Policy becomes a named, explicit, governable object.
In VCF Automation, policies define constraints and guardrails for consumers.Examples: Who can deploy what Where workloads can land What sizes, images, or networks are allowed Lease durations and approval requirements Typical policy categories: Placement policies: Which clusters, regions, zones Sizing policies: CPU, memory, storage limits Image policies: Approved OS images only Network policies: allowed networks / isolation Approval policies: manual gates for certain actions Lease policies: TTL and reclamation rules These policies are evaluated before provisioning.
In VCF Automation, policies are usually scoped to:
- Organizations
- or ProjectsThey act as guardrails, not implementation detailsExample: “In Project Prod, only Gold storage, max 16 vCPU, and approval required.” This is where policy intersects with consumption abstraction.
In **VCF Operations, policy ≠ enforcement.VCF Operations uses policy indirectly.
In VCF Operations: Policies become: Alerts Compliance checks Drift detection Optimization rules
VCF Operations answers: “Is reality still compliant with the policy?”
VCF Automation answers: “Should this action be allowed at all, in the first place?”
A Policy in VMware Cloud Foundation is a governance rule, not a single product feature
VCF Automation is where policies are: Explicit Named Scoped Evaluated before action
VCF Operations observes and reports compliance Infrastructure layers actually enforce the low-level mechanics
STIG can be an interesting topic that can complement policies.
You might also want to check out VCF Roles and Permissions.
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.title: Policy as Code
vcf/concepts/governance-and-compliance/p.description:
#tenancy
Policy as Code (PaC) in VMware Cloud Foundation means defining, enforcing, and validating cloud governance rules using version-controlled code, rather than ad-hoc UI settings or manual procedures. Policies become executable, testable artifacts that are evaluated automatically as part of provisioning, configuration, and ongoing operations.
PaC is “guardrails expressed in code” that continuously shape what is allowed in your VPC.
Policy as Code is not a single product in VCF—it is a cross-cutting pattern implemented across multiple layers:This is where PaC is most explicit and visible.
Policies are applied to:
Organizations
Projects
Blueprints Deployments Examples: Who can deploy what Which regions, clusters, or storage types are allowed Maximum CPU / memory / cost Required approvals before deployment Policies are: Evaluated before provisioning Enforced during lifecycle actions Stored and versioned
At the Kubernetes layer (vSphere Supervisor + Guest Clusters):
Policies are expressed using tools like Open Policy Agent) Enforced as admission controls Prevent non-compliant workloads from being created Examples: Pods must not run as root Images must come from approved registries Network policies are mandatory Resource limits must be defined This is PaC in its purest form: Declarative rules evaluated at runtime.VCF PaC complements Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines: Policies validate IaC plans before apply Prevent drift and unsafe configurations Align infra provisioning with governance rules Who can deploy Where they can deploy What resources they can consume Encryption requirements Network isolation Image provenance
STIG / CIS alignment Resource quotas Budget limits Placement constraints Approval Workflows Lease durations Auto-decommission rules Without Policy as Code “Please remember not to deploy large VMs in prod.” With Policy as Code “Deployments violating this rule are automatically rejected.” PaC the difference between: Guidelines vs guarantees Human memory vs machine enforcement Audit after the fact vs prevention by design
From VMware’s perspective, PaC is critical because VCF serves: Regulated industries (telco, finance, gov) Multi-tenant private clouds Platform teams supporting many consumers So, Policy as Code enables: Consistency at scale
Auditable Governance Safe self-service Policy as Code in VCF = governance expressed as executable rules Most visible in VCF Automation, but spans infra, Kubernetes, and security Enables guardrails, not gates Essential for multi-tenant, regulated private clouds A foundational concept, not a single feature
STIG might be a related concept to explore from this point.

headers.heading: Where Does PaC Live in VCF
What Does the Policy Code Govern

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: User Roles
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
#tenancy
Roles assigned to users and groups are an essential part to identity and access management in VCF Automation.
You can leverage identity providers with Organizations to enable single sign-on to provision users and groups. Once the users and groups are added to the Organization, they must be assigned roles to enable specific permissions and access to different features within  VCF Automation.
VCF Automation has several levels of user roles. These different levels control access to the Organization, the Projects that produce or consume the Blueprints, Catalog Items, access to IaaS Services, and the ability for users to use or see individual parts of the user interface. These different levels give Organization Administrators different tools to apply any level of granularity that is required by their operational needs.
Here are the predefined user roles in **VCF Automation. You can visit each link to see more details about them. Organization Roles
Organization Administrator
Organization User
Organization Auditor Project Roles
Project Administrator
Project Auditor
Project Advanced User
Project User **Supervisor Roles
Supervisor Administrator
Defer to Identity Provider User permissions can also be determined based on information received from the identity provider for the Organization.
Organization Management could be a good area to explore after getting acquainted with the user roles here. Additionally, you can find a more detailed listing of what permissions these roles have in VCF Roles and Permissions.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.title: Virtual Machine
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/v.description:
A virtual machine (VM) is a software-defined computer that behaves like a physical machine but runs on top of a virtualization layer rather than directly on hardware.You can think of it as a full computer implemented in software.Each VM: Has its own CPU, memory, disk, and network Runs its own operating system Is isolated from other VMs Believes it owns real hardware (even though it doesn’t) The key component is the hypervisor.The hypervisor: Intercepts CPU instructions Schedules CPU time Maps virtual memory → physical memory Virtualizes I/O (disk, NIC, GPU, etc.) From the VM’s perspective: “I am running on bare metal.” From reality: “You are one of many guests sharing a host.” A VM is not just an OS. It consists of: Virtual hardware vCPU(s) vRAM Virtual disk(s) Virtual NIC(s) Firmware BIOS or UEFI Operating system Linux, Windows, BSD, etc. Applications Databases, web servers, middleware, etc. Even though the term VM is generic, VCF treats the VM as a first-class workload unit: A VM is: A managed workload Governed by policies Scheduled onto clusters Subject to lifecycle operations (create, move, snapshot, delete) VCF doesn’t care why the VM exists It cares how to place, secure, move, and operate it A VM is a full computer implemented in software It runs an OS and applications like a physical machine The hypervisor provides isolation and resource sharing VMs remain foundational—even in modern cloud platforms In VCF, a VM is a core workload primitive, not a legacy artifact
You might want to check out Inventory Objects such as Resource Pools or vSphere Clusters.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: What is a VKS Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
A VKS cluster is a Kubernetes cluster that is built and supported by VMware and that runs application workloads.VKS clusters are part of a vSphere Kubernetes Service (VKS) deployment. You use VKS cluster management to manage VKS clusters. Their lifecycle, however, is handled by the native vSphere Supervisor APIs.A VKS cluster is a Kubernetes cluster provisioned and managed through VKS.Characteristics:
Built on vSphere
Managed via the vSphere Supervisor
Created and governed through VCF Automation Runs standard Kubernetes workloads
VKS clusters are where actual workloads execute, but they do not contain awareness of organizational hierarchy (i.e. they don’t know about Organizations, Projects, or Supervisor Namespaces).VKS provides self-service lifecycle management of Kubernetes workload clusters.VKS is an implementation of the open-source Cluster API project, which defines a set of custom resources and controllers used to manage the lifecycle of Kubernetes clusters.
VKS is a component of the vSphere Supervisor. The Supervisor acts as a source of compute resources that can be registered with VCF Automation.
System administrators allocate Supervisor resources to organizations in VCF Automation. The Supervisor itself does not belong to any organization.
Project Administrators request Supervisor Namespaces for their projects, and VCF Automation allocates the appropriate namespaces to match those requests.
A single vSphere Supervisor can provide resources to multiple VCF Automation organizations.
Within a single organization, Supervisor Namespaces can be moved between projects.
To function properly, VKS cluster management relies on a set of agents and extensions that run in every VKS cluster.
When a VKS cluster is attached to VKS Cluster Management, the vSphere Supervisor auto-attach service installs: Required extensions Cluster resource definitions Agent components on each node The agent configuration includes: The VKS cluster management endpoint The container image registry used by the cluster Proxy configuration details The overall health of a cluster is determined by aggregating the health of its nodes and components. Healthy All nodes and components are healthy, and a heartbeat is received every minute. Unhealthy One or more of the following are unhealthy: One or more control plane nodes One or more cluster components Warning A cluster enters a warning state when: One or more worker nodes are unhealthy or unknown, or One or more nodes (control plane or worker) report a warning condition Unknown The cluster is marked as unknown if: One or more control plane nodes are in an unknown state, or No heartbeat has been received for more than three minutes Node health is derived from the NodeReady condition and other node-level signals such as: MemoryPressure DiskPressure OutOfDisk The node’s health state is evaluated as follows: NodeReady is True All other conditions are healthy NodeReady is False, or NodeReady is True, but more than half of the other conditions are unhealthy NodeReady is True Fewer than half of the other conditions are unhealthy NodeReady is neither True nor False, or No heartbeat has been received from the node for more than three minutes
VKS cluster management monitors the health of the following control plane components: kube-apiserver scheduler controller-manager etcd components (etcd-0, etcd-1, etcd-2, etc.) Each component periodically reports its health status. Healthy The last reported health condition is True. Unhealthy The last reported health condition is False. Unknown The last reported health condition is neither True nor False, or no heartbeat has been received for more than three minutes. Below is a clean, consistently structured, and de-duplicated version of your content. Nothing new is introduced; this is purely a clarity and organization pass so the conceptual layers are easy to understand and reference.VKS (vSphere Kubernetes Service) provides managed Kubernetes clusters running on vSphere. It operates within the VCF Automation framework and relies on the Supervisor to provision and manage resources.VKS cluster management introduces a hierarchical model that separates:
Control-plane governance (VCF Automation)
Cluster lifecycle management (VKS)
Runtime execution (vSphere Supervisor + Kubernetes) VKS cluster management organizes resources using the following hierarchy:
Organization
Project
VKS Cluster
Kubernetes Namespaces (inside the cluster, these are NOT Supervisor Namespaces)
This hierarchy exists in the VCF Automation control plane, not inside Kubernetes itself.Each VKS cluster contains standard Kubernetes namespaces: These are normal Kubernetes namespaces Managed using kubectl Used for application isolation and RBAC within the cluster
These namespaces are not the same as Supervisor Namespaces or VCF Automation Projects.
A Supervisor Namespace exists at the Supervisor layer and is used to: Allocate CPU, memory, and storage Bind resource pools to consumers Host VKS cluster resources Important distinctions:
Supervisor Namespaces are not Kubernetes namespaces (*but they are queries using kubectl, so they —look like– Kubernetes namespaces) They are managed through the Supervisor API
They serve as the execution boundary for VKS clusters VCF Automation defines intent. VKS enforces that intent. Kubernetes executes the result. The organizational model exists above Kubernetes and never becomes part of the Kubernetes API surface.
Management Cluster and Guest Cluster are two directly-related areas to explore.
You might also want to check VKS Cluster Storage and VKS Cluster Networking.

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/administrati.title: Administrative Roles in VCF
vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/administrati.description:
#tenancy
In VMware Cloud Foundation, Platform Admin and Tenant Admin are useful conceptual terms, but not official role names in VCF.VCF defines explicit, documented roles such as:
Organization Administrator
Project Administrator (and related Auditor / User roles) This page uses Platform Admin as a conceptual responsibility boundary, and Organization / Project Administrator as the official tenant-facing roles defined by VCF.The distinction is intentional and fundamental.
VCF separates infrastructure ownership from consumption governance: platform infrastructure is operated outside VCF Automation, while Organization Administrators and Project Administrators govern what runs within tenant boundaries.
Organization Administrator has Tenant-level authority.
An Organization Administrator represents the tenant boundary in VCF Automation.They manage: Organization-level configuration Tenant users and role assignments Organization-wide quotas and policies Governance within the organization They cannot: Modify platform topology Upgrade core infrastructure Affect other organizations Bypass platform guardrails
The Project Administrator is a Project-scoped operational authority.
A Project Administrator manages consumption and operations within a single Project, which maps to one (typical, but can be more than one) Supervisor Namespace.
The Project Administrator can create Projects, assign users and groups, and allocate quotas to restrict the configurations available to the tenants. |
By creating Projects, you can isolate security and networking objects across tenants in a single NSX deployment. Project Administrators manage: Project users and access Workload provisioning (VMs, Kubernetes clusters, services) Project-scoped quotas and approvals Day-to-day operational policies Their authority is strictly bounded by:
The Organization Platform-defined constraints Without this separation: Tenants could break upgrade paths Platform consistency would erode Supportability would collapse One tenant could impact others VCF deliberately trades tenant flexibility for platform predictability, safety, and lifecycle integrity. Organization Administrator is the true tenant administrator in VCF 9 Project Administrator governs consumption within a tenant The separation protects multi-tenancy, lifecycle management, and supportability This boundary is foundational to VCF’s architecture
VCF Roles and Permissions is the logical follow-up to this section, which dives into more details of predefined roles and privileges in **VMware Cloud Foundation.

headers.heading: What Organization and Project Administrators Own

vcf/concepts/tenancy-in-vcf/administrati.author: Volkan Özçelik
