vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VCF Operations Orchestrator workflows run according to a logical flow of events.When you run a workflow, each schema element in the workflow runs according to the following sequence. The workflow binds the workflow token variables and input parameters to the input parameters of the schema element. The schema element runs. The output parameters of the schema element are copied to the workflow token variables and workflow output parameters. The workflow token variables and workflow output parameters are stored in the database. The next schema element starts running. This sequence repeats for each schema element until the end of the workflow.
When a workflow runs, each schema element is a check point. After each schema element runs, VCF Operations Orchestrator stores workflow token variables in the database, and the next schema element starts running.If the workflow stops unexpectedly, the next time the Orchestrator Server restarts, the currently active schema element runs again, and the workflow continues from the start of the schema element that was running when the interruption occurred.
That being said, VCF Operations Orchestrator does not implement transaction management or a rollback function.The workflow ends if the current active schema element is an end element.After the workflow reaches an end element, other workflows or applications can use the output parameters of the workflow.
You might like to check out Fleet Management or VMware Data Services Manager, or VMware Skyline as they tangentially relate to workflows.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VCF Operations Orchestrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VCF Operations Orchestrator provides a library of workflows that perform common management tasks. VCF Operations Orchestrator also provides libraries of the individual actions that the workflows perform.Workflows combine actions, decisions, and results that, when performed in a particular order, finish a specific task or a specific process in a virtual environment.
Workflows perform tasks such as provisioning virtual machines, backing up, performing regular maintenance, sending emails, performing SSH operations, managing the physical infrastructure, and other general utility operations. Workflows accept inputs according to their function.
You can create Workflows that run according to defined schedules, or that run if certain anticipated events occur.Information can be provided by you, by other users, by another workflow or action, or by an external process such as a Web service call from an application.
Workflows perform some validation and filtering of information before they run.
Workflows can be chained. That is, they can call upon other workflows. For example, you can have workflow that calls up another workflow to create a new virtual machine.You create workflows by using the VCF Operations Orchestrator’s integrated development environment (IDE), that provides access to the workflow library and the ability to run workflows on the workflow engine.The workflow engine can also take objects from external libraries that you plug in to the VCF Operations Orchestrator. This allows you to customize processes or implement functions that third-party applications provide.
Why not check out, Workflows, or maybe Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows?
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/VCF Operations Orchestrator.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Workflow
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Workflows consist of a schema, workflow variables, and input and output parameters.The workflow schema is the main component of a workflow as it defines all the workflow elements and the logical connections between them. The workflow variables and parameters are the properties that workflows use to transfer data.

In VMware Cloud Foundation, there isn’t a single “workflow engine” owned by only one product. Different parts of VCF create/execute different kinds of workflows:
VCF Automation is the place where you typically design and run “day-1” style workflows tied to requests (catalog items, provisioning, configuration, approvals, extensibility, etc.). Its value prop explicitly includes orchestration and extensibility.
Under the hood, these workflows commonly leverage an Orchestrator (formerly vRealize Orchestrator) integrated/embedded with the automation stack. It is executed by VCF Operations Orchestrator which is a part of the VCF Operations stack.
VCF Operations is primarily the ops brain: monitoring, alerting, capacity, compliance, etc.. It can run actions (and sometimes chain remediation) in response to alerts.
Actual workflow automation is done through VCF Operations Orchestrator, which is explicitly described as a “workflow automation solution” and can create and run workflows.
VCF Operations Orchestrator saves a workflow token every time a workflow runs, recording the details of that specific workflow run.Workflows receive input parameters and generate output parameters when they run.Most workflows require a certain set of input parameters to run. An input parameter is an argument that the workflow processes when it runs. The user, an application, another workflow, or an action passes input parameters to a workflow for the workflow to process when it runs.For example, if a workflow resets a virtual machine, the workflow requires the name of the virtual machine as an input parameter.A workflow's output parameters represent the result from the workflow run. Output parameters can change when a workflow or a workflow element runs. During a workflow run, the workflow can receive the output parameters of other workflows as input parameters.For example, if a workflow creates a snapshot of a virtual machine, the output parameter for the workflow is the resulting snapshot.Workflow elements process data that they receive as input parameters, and set the resulting data as workflow variables or output parameters.Read-only workflow variables act as global constants for a workflow. Writable variables act as a workflow’s global variables.You can use variables to transfer data between the elements of a workflow.You can obtain variables in the following ways: Define variables when you create a workflow. Set the output parameter of a workflow element as a workflow variable. Inherit variables from a configuration element. A workflow schema is a graphical representation that shows the workflow as a flow diagram of interconnected workflow elements. The workflow schema is the most important element of a workflow as it determines its logic.When users run a workflow, they provide the values for the input parameters of the workflow in the workflow presentation.A workflow token represents a workflow that is running or has finished running.A workflow is an abstract description of a process that defines a generic sequence of steps and a generic set of required input parameters. When you run a workflow with a set of input parameters, you receive an instance of this abstract workflow that behaves according to the specific input parameters you give it. This specific instance of a finished or a running workflow is called a workflow token.Workflow Token Attributes are the specific parameters with which a workflow token runs.The workflow token attributes are an aggregation of the workflow's global variables and the specific input and output parameters with which you run the workflow token.
Next, you might want to look into Running VCF Operations Orchestrator Workflows, or you can check out VCF Operations Orchestrator.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Workflow Management/Workflow.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Supervisor Administrator
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
#tenancy
In VMware Cloud Foundation, Supervisor Administrator is a new, platform-level role introduced to formalize control over the Supervisor Cluster itself, and it sits orthogonally to— not above or below—the traditional Organization / Project roles.
Supervisor Administrator manages the platform that hosts tenants, while Organization Administrator manages the tenants themselves, and Project Administrator manages what runs inside those tenants. VCF separates responsibilities cleanly into three distinct administrative planes, each with its own roles:→ “How the Kubernetes substrate itself is operated”This is where the Supervisor Cluster lives.→ “Who consumes the infrastructure and how”
This is where Organizations, Projects, and quotas live.→ “What runs on top of it”
This is where Kubernetes workloads, namespaces, and apps live.
Scope: Supervisor Cluster (platform level)Primary responsibility:
Operates and governs the Supervisor Cluster itself Manages cluster-level capabilities that all tenants depend on Typical responsibilities:
Configure and manage Supervisor Cluster lifecycle Control Supervisor services (e.g., Kubernetes control plane, CSI, CNI, storage integrations)
Define which Organizations can exist
Enable or disable platform features available to Organizations Maintain host, networking, and storage alignment required for Kubernetes workloads Supervisor Administrator does not manage application workloads or tenant namespaces.From the Supervisor Administrator’s point of view: “I run the Kubernetes platform that everyone else builds on.”
Organization Administrator is the tenant-level authority.
Scope: Organization (tenant boundary)Role type: Consumer / tenant administratorResponsibilities:
Create and manage Projects Assign users to projects and roles Define quotas and usage limits Control access within their organization Govern how their organization consumes platform capacity They do not manage the Supervisor Cluster itself.
From the Organization Administrator’s perspective: “I manage my organization’s slice of the platform.”
Project Administrator has workload-level control over the project they have access to.
Scope: Single Project within an OrganizationResponsibilities: Manage Kubernetes workloads (clusters, namespaces, services) Manage users within the project Configure project-level policies and resources
They operate inside boundaries defined by the Organization Admin and enforced by the Supervisor.
From Project Administrator’s point of view: “I manage workloads, not the platform.” Supervisor Administrator │ ├── Organization Administrator │ ├── Project Administrator │ │ └── Application / Workload Operators │ └── Project Users │ └── (Multiple Organizations) Supervisor Admin ≠ Super Org Admin They operate at different abstraction layers Historically, roles like this were blurry or implicit (vSphere Admin, Cloud Admin, etc.).VCF introduces clear separation of concerns:This aligns VCF with cloud provider models (for, i.e., AWS control plane vs account admins).
← Back to User Roles

headers.heading: The Three Different Control Planes in VCF

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Cloud Services Console
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Cloud Services Console is VMware’s SaaS control plane for identity, organizations, subscriptions, and service access across VMware cloud offerings.
If vCenter answers “what is running?”, CSC answers: “Who are you, what are you entitled to, and which VMware services can you access?”
VMware SaaS Layer └── Cloud Services Console (CSC) ├── Identity and Org management ├── Subscriptions & entitlements └── Access to VMware cloud services On-prem / Private Cloud └── VCF ├── vSphere / NSX / vSAN └── SDDC Manager CSC: Runs as: VMware-hosted SaaS Audience: Org owners, platform leads, service-provider admins Does not touch datapaths or place workloads Defines Organizations Manages users, roles, and access Integrates with enterprise IdPs (SSO)
This is business identity, not vCenter RBAC. Shows what your org is entitled to: VCF subscriptions Optional VMware services Central place to view contracts → services CSC does not meter usage—that’s elsewhere.From CSC you access: Support portals VMware cloud SaaS Management consoles (where applicable) CSC is the front door, not the engine room.CSC ≠ BSC CSC is VMware-global; BSC is VCF-specific. CSC knows about your subscriptions
VCF consumes those entitlements CSC does not: Provision domains Run LCM Enforce quotas Observe performance
That work stays on-prem with VCF components. Not part of the VCF runtime Not an ops or automation tool Not a billing/metering engine Not a tenant boundary for workloads If VCF is: “Your private cloud platform” Then CSC is: “Your VMware account and service access hub” Cloud Services Console = SaaS identity and entitlement layer Global across VMware services
Adjacent to VCF, not embedded in it
Often confused with VCF Business Services Console—they serve different roles Why not check out Day-N Operations:
VCF Day 0 Tasks
VCF Day 1 Tasks
VCF Day 2 Tasks

How Does CSC and VCF Relate

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: Fleet Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
Fleet management in VMware Cloud Foundation is the centralized, policy-driven governance of many infrastructure instances (hosts, clusters, domains, appliances) across their entire lifecycle—from onboarding and entitlement to upgrades, credentials, certificates, configuration drift, and metadata.A fleet typically includes:
Multiple Workload Domains
Multiple vCenter Servers
NSX Managers & NSX Edge Clusters
ESX hosts (often hundreds or thousands)
Supporting appliances (SDDC Manager, vSAN, etc.) Fleet management answers: “How do we keep all of these consistent, compliant, secure, and up-to-date over years?” Central license inventory Assignment to:
vCenter / ESX
NSX
vSAN Alignment with subscription usage
SDDC Manager
VCF Usage Meter
VCF Business Services Console Licenses are fleet-level entitlements, not per-host snowflakes. VCF ensures: No silent overuse No orphaned entitlements Auditable usage
SDDC Manager
Bring-up (VCF Day 0 Tasks)
Patching and upgrades (VCF Day 2 Tasks) Version skew prevention
Compatibility matrices (vSphere, NSX, firmware) VCF Ensures: Upgrades are coordinated across domains Versions are locked as a bill of materials Drift is actively prevented You upgrade the fleet, not “a vCenter here and there.”
vCenter SSO External IdPs (AD / LDAP / OIDC) Role-based access (RBAC)
VCF Automation Organizations and Projects VCF Ensures Consistent role models Central auth sources Separation of duties across domains IAM is federated but standardized across the fleet. No bespoke admin models per domain.
vCenter Server
ESX hosts
NSX Managers & VCF Edges Internal APIs Trust relationships Certifacate Challenges: Certificate sprawl Expiration risk Manual rotation = outage risk VCF Ensures: Centralized visibility via SDDC Manager Supported rotation workflows Integration with enterprise CAs Certificates are fleet-scale secrets, not local files. Appliance passwords Service accounts Inter-component credentials Bootstrap secrets Reality Password rotation must be: Coordinated Non-disruptive Auditable VCF: Tracks credentials centrally Rotates safely Prevents “unknown admin password” scenarios This is operational hygiene at scale. Cluster settings (HA, DRS, admission control) NSX transport & policies Storage policies Network constructs Domain-level invariants Configuration is declared once and enforced everywhere. VCF: Applies opinionated defaults Detects unsupported deviations Blocks actions that would break fleet integrity Automation targeting Chargeback / showback Compliance classification Ownership & environment labeling Tags provide metadata across the entire fleet. Tags provide horizontal metadata across: Domains Clusters VMs Datastores “The control plane’s labeling system for infrastructure objects.” Without tags, automation becomes brittle.Fleet Management in VCF ├── SDDC Manager │ ├── Lifecycle (LCM) │ ├── Credentials │ ├── Certificates │ ├── Configuration invariants │ ├── Business Layer │ ├── Usage Meter │ └── Business Services Console │ ├── Identity & Access │ ├── vCenter SSO │ └── External IdP │ └── Metadata └── Tags & policies Fleet management is the core value proposition of VCF It spans license, lifecycle, identity, secrets, certs, config, and metadata Centralization + opinionation is the feature, not a limitation VCF treats infrastructure as a long-lived, governed fleet, not pets
You might want to check VMware Data Services Manager.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Managing the Cloud/Fleet Management.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VMware Data Services Manager
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VMware Data Services Manager (DSM) is a Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) control plane that lets platform teams offer databases as a managed service on top of VCF infrastructure—while keeping infrastructure, security, and lifecycle control centralized.
DSM answers: “How do we provide self-service databases without giving users raw VM access?” VCF ├── vSphere / vSAN / NSX ├── SDDC Manager (infra lifecycle) │ └── VMware Data Services Manager ├── Control Plane (policies, APIs, UI) └── Data Plane └── Database VMs (Postgres, MySQL, etc.) DSM: Runs on: VCF infrastructure
Consumes: vSphere, NSX, storage policies Exposes: A database service interface to users DSM is above infrastructure, below applications. Provision databases in minutes Automated: Day-0 setup Day-1 operations Day-2 patching and upgrades Consistent configurations every time No more hand-built “special” DB VMs. Platform team controls: VM templates Storage policies Network placement Backup and security posture Application teams control: DB provisioning Scaling (within limits) Credentials (scoped)
This maps cleanly to enterprise governance models.Databases are deployed with: Approved VM shapes Approved storage classes
Approved NSX Segments
Approved HA / backup models Users pick “what”, not “how”.DSM automates: Database-aware backups Snapshots Restore workflows Optional replication patterns This is database lifecycle, not just VM lifecycle.DSM targets enterprises modernizing gradually, not cloud-native purists.This distinction is important. SDDC Manager:
Patches ESX, NSX, vCenter DSM: Patches databases Manages DB templates Controls DB version drift They are complementary, not overlapping.If VCF is: “Infrastructure as a managed fleet” Then DSM is: “Databases as a managed service on that fleet” Comparable to: AWS RDS (conceptually) Azure SQL (conceptually) …but on-prem / private cloud, with enterprise control.Enterprises want: Self-service databases Fewer snowflake DB VMs Safer operations Faster delivery Without:
Giving developers vCenter access Losing compliance control Rewriting everything for Kubernetes DSM provides the perfect middle ground. VMware Data Services Manager = DBaaS control plane Runs on, but is not part of, VCF core Enforces policy, separation of duties, and lifecycle automation Best for VM-based enterprise databases Optional, but powerful for platform teams
Maybe you might want to check out Cloud Services Console too.

headers.heading: Where Does DSM Fit in VCF

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Managing the Cloud/VMware Data Services Manager.md

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.title: VMware Skyline
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.description:
VMware Skyline is a proactive support and health intelligence service that continuously analyzes your VMware environment and surfaces: Configuration risks Known issues Upgrade blockers Security advisories Best-practice deviations It answers: “What is likely to break, and what should I fix before it does?”
VCF Environment ├── vCenter / ESXi ├── NSX ├── vSAN ├── SDDC Manager │ └── Skyline ├── Telemetry collection ├── Health & risk analysis └── Proactive recommendations Skyline observes the fleet — it does not control it. Skyline is VCF-adjacent, not VCF-core.
In VCF: Skyline supports:
vSphere
NSX
vSAN
SDDC Manager Skyline findings are especially valuable for: LCM readiness Upgrade prechecks Fleet hygiene Skyline correlates your environment against: Known VMware issues Field advisories Support KB patterns This is knowledge you cannot replicate locally.Before you run LCM in VCF: Skyline can flag: Unsupported configs Known bad upgrade paths Latent drift issues You can think of it as: “Support’s brain looking at your fleet before you upgrade.” Skyline shines when:
You have many domains
You have many vCenters You want a single risk posture view
This aligns naturally with VCF Fleet management.Skyline is insight, not control.Skyline is the supportability lens.If SDDC Manager is: “The mechanic that performs maintenance” Then Skyline is: “The service engineer who tells you what will fail next month.” VMware Skyline Provides proactive, VCF-global intelligence Is best viewed as a support copilot for VCF fleets Is especially valuable for LCM and large environments
VMware Data Services Manager and Cloud Services Console are other adjacent tools that you might want to explore.

headers.heading: Where Skyline Sits Relative to VCF

vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-operations/platfo.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Operations/Platform Operations and Services/Platform Services and Management/Managing the Cloud/VMware Skyline.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.title: Supervisor Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.description:
See also: vSphere ClusterYes’nt.
A vSphere Cluster and a Supervisor Cluster are not the same thing. However, they are so tightly-related in a Supervisor-enabled Namespace, you can “colloquially” say that they are the same.Yet, they sit at different abstraction layers.This is the base construct.A vSphere Cluster is a classic virtualization construct: A group of [[ESX] hosts
Managed by vCenter Provides: [DRS] (scheduling) [HA] (failover) Resource Pooling (CPU / memory) Shared storage and networking However, vSphere Cluster alone does not imply Any Kubernetes Any namespaces Any tenants Any container workloads You can run only VMs, forever, and never enable anything Kubernetes-related.This is the layer on top.A Supervisor Cluster is not a separate cluster of hosts.It is:
A Kubernetes control plane embedded into a vSphere Cluster
When you enable the Supervisor feature on vSphere:
vSphere deploys Kubernetes control plane VMs
ESX hosts become Kubernetes worker nodes vSphere exposes:
Supervisor Namespaces
Pod Workloads
Guest Clusters (e.g., VKS)
vSphere becomes Kubernetes-aware
The key point is: The same ESX hosts of the same vSphere Cluster are used, but now they serve two schedulers**:
vSphere (VMs) Kubernetes (pods / guest clusters) So the formal relationship is: A Supervisor Cluster is a capability of a vSphere Cluster, not a different cluster type. But, it walks like a duck, talks like a duck, and it surely is a very-sophisticated duck: Operationally, and practically, it is the same thing.
A Supervisor Cluster is a Kubernetes control plane that runs on and transforms a vSphere Cluster into a Kubernetes-aware platform.For the ontology-enthusiasts out there:This matters a lot. vSphere cluster failure → everything dies
Supervisor control plane failure → VMs keep running Although subtle, this distinction becomes very important when discussing: Security boundaries Upgrade paths Failure isolation Scheduling semantics
VCF Automation mappings
In a Supervisor-enabled vSphere, the Supervisor Cluster and the vSphere Cluster are co-resident and inseparable operationally, but they remain distinct architectural constructs with different control planes and failure domains.
Guest Cluster complements Supervisor Cluster. You might also want to explore vSphere Supervisor. Or check Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster for a nuanced discussion of the terminology.

headers.heading: Is It the Same Thing as **vSphere Cluster

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/object-model/i.author: Volkan Özçelik

vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.title: Project Management
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.description:
#tenancy
Projects in VCF Automation Organizations provide a logical grouping of users and the infrastructure that they are assigned.
Projects are used to represent real world teams which are in charge of development or operations. Each Project has one or more namespaces assigned to it. Each namespace is an envelope of resources where applications can be deployed. Access controls for Projects are governed by pre-defined roles.
 Organization Administrators can create and attach one or more namespaces to a project. Administrators can also delete a namespace at any time, which dissociates the namespace from the project. 
Every Organization comes with a default project. The default project doesn’t have users or namespaces. The Organization Administrator can change the name, description of the default project, and add users and namespaces to the default project.
 A namespace class is a template that is used to create namespaces. All components of a namespace, including limits on CPU, memory, and storage utilization, VM classes and storage classes, and content libraries can be defined as a reusable template. Namespace classes are created and maintained by Organization Administrators.
 Infrastructure quota assigned to an organization can be subdivided and assigned to project teams in the form of namespaces]. Namespaces are isolated resource pools in which resources like VMs, VKS clusters, and volumes can be provisioned. Organization Administrators can override the resource limits specified in a namespace class during namespace creation.
 The resource limits of a namespace can be satisfied from capacity in one or more vSphere zones. When creating a namespace, Organization Administrators can select which zones the namespace can use. Namespaces count towards the organization quota. The sum total of resource limits of all created namespaces cannot exceed the organization quota.How many projects and namespaces you create depends on your organization needs.
Projects: Multiple projects are used when isolation boundaries between project teams are required. Only project members can access deployments and resources available to a project. Fewer projects are desired when isolation requirements can be traded off for a simpler operating model.
Namespaces: Multiple namespaces are used when strict resource limits are needed for each application. Namespaces are logical constructs that can be used to define application boundaries. Each application can be deployed on a namespace with prescribed resource limits for CPU, memory, and storage. For instance, a group of VMs and VKS clusters that make up an application can be logically grouped together in a namespace.
User Roles is the next logical place to explore after here. Or you can check out Organization Management.
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.author: Volkan Özçelik
vcf/control-planes/vcf-automation/tenanc.sourcePath: VCF/Control Planes/VCF Automation/Tenancy and Access Control/Organization Management/Project Management.md

vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/distributed-virtu.title: Distributed Virtual Switch
vcf/core-runtimes/vsan/distributed-virtu.description:
In VMware Cloud Foundation, a Distributed Virtual Switch (DVS) is the standard, centralized virtual networking fabric used across ESX hosts in a Workload Domain.
Distributed Virtual Switch is a cluster-wide virtual switch that provides consistent networking configuration across all ESX hosts. It centralizes network policy (port groups, uplinks, security, QoS) instead of configuring each host individually.VCF standardizes on VDS as the baseline virtual networking fabric.

In VCF, a Distributed Virtual Switch is the mandatory, centrally managed L2 networking fabric that ensures every ESX host behaves identically so that VCF Automation, lifecycle management, and NSX can work reliably at scale.DVS provides consistent networking configuration, policy enforcement, and operational control at scale—something VCF depends on to behave predictably.DVS can be seen as:
One logical network switch that spans many ESX hosts, configured once, and applied everywhere.
Instead of configuring networking host-by-host, you configure it centrally, and every participating ESX host follows that definition.VCF is opinionated and automated. Networking must be: Deterministic Centrally managed
Compatible with lifecycle automation Consistent across hosts and clusters That’s why VCF mandates DVS (not standard vSwitches) for system and workload networking.
ESX hosts do not own the switch config — vCenter does. VMware Cloud Foundation └── vSphere └── vCenter Server └── vSphere Distributed Switch (VDS) ├── ESXi Host A ├── ESXi Host B └── ESXi Host C └── Port Groups → VM vNICs Centralized L2 switching Consistent port group configuration NIC teaming & uplinks Traffic shaping, security, VLAN tagging Host lifecycle safety (no per-host drift) “One virtual switch, shared by the whole cluster.” A Distributed Port Group defines: VLAN ID(s) Security policies (promiscuous mode, MAC changes) Traffic shaping Teaming / failover VM vNICs attach to port groups, not directly to the switch. ❌ Not a router (no L3)
❌ Not an NSX Segment ❌ Not a tenant boundary ❌ Not optional in VCF VCF automation (bring-up, scaling, patching, upgrades) assumes:A standard vSwitch breaks all of this because it is host-local and imperative.
In VCF:
Management Domain has a predefined VDS
Workload Domains get their own VDS
NSX transport zones bind to VDS uplinks Lifecycle (patching, expansion) assumes VDS presence
You rarely “design” VDS in VCF—it is opinionated and enforced.Typical VCF DVS port groups include: Management
vMotion
vSAN
NSX Host TEPs VM networks (VLAN-backed)
Supervisor / Kubernetes traffic (when applicable) VCF may create multiple DVS instances, for example: One for system domain One per workload domain
DVS ≠ NSX DVS provides L2 switching NSX builds overlay networking (Geneve tunnels, logical segments) on top of DVS You can have:
DVS without NSX (VLAN-backed networking)
However, NSX requires DVS underneath So DVS is the foundational substrate, not the SDN layer. DVS = underlay L2 switch NSX = overlay (L3) networking NSX creates overlay segments Overlay traffic is encapsulated (GENEVE) Encapsulated packets ride over VDS uplinks NSX does not replace VDS—it depends on it. If DVS is:
“A shared Ethernet switch for ESX hosts”
Then NSX Segment is: “A logical network built on top of that switch.” Different layers, different jobs. DVS is a control-plane object
ESX caches its config locally, but authority lives in vCenter If vCenter is temporarily unavailable Traffic keeps flowing You just can’t change switch config VCF LCM expects DVS invariants Port groups, uplinks, MTU, and teaming must match what SDDC Manager expects DVS is not optional in VCF VDS is the foundational virtual switch in VCF It is owned by vCenter, not hosts It enables automation, scale, and consistency Provides centralized, cluster-wide L2 networking
NSX depends on it, but it is not NSX itself NSX overlays run on top of VDS, not instead of it Standard vSwitches are fundamentally incompatible with VCF’s design goals
Diving into ESX might be the next logical step from here. Or maybe CNS (Cloud Native Storage), could be something fun to explore.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Kubectl in Supervisor Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
Connected to Supervisor Cluster:kubectl config use-context <supervisor-context> kubectl get ns NAME STATUS AGE default Active kube-system Active kube-public Active kube-node-lease Active my-team-a Active my-team-b Active Here, there is no such thing as a “regular Kubernetes namespace” in the tenant sense. The namespace here: Cannot be created freely. Map to vSphere inventory objects. Quotas, storage, and networking are externally-enforced. Connected to a guest clusterkubectl get ns kubectl create ns foo kubectl delete ns foo All of these will work as expected.
Supervisor Namespaces → owns the cluster.
Guest Cluster namespace → normal Kubernetes semantics. # check Supervisor-specific APIs kubectl api-resources | grep -i vm virtualmachines vmoperator.vmware.com # look at the nodes kubectl get nodes -o wide # look for VM Operator kubectl get pods -A | grep vmoperator Supervisor cluster nodes typically show:
ESX-backed control-plane VMs. Special node labels VM Operator components Guest clusters look like: Standard Linux nodes kubelet-managed lifecycle No VM Operator CRDs. In a Supervisor cluster, tenant namespaces are Kubernetes namespaces whose lifecycle, limits, and security are owned by vSphere. In a guest cluster, namespaces are owned entirely by Kubernetes.
← Back to “Supervisor Namespace”

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Management Cluster
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
#tenancyIn VMware Cloud Foundation, the Management Cluster is the foundational cluster that runs the platform itself. It hosts the management plane—the services that build, operate, upgrade, and secure the rest of the cloud.Put simply: If the Management Cluster is down, you can’t manage the cloud—only the workloads keep running.
The Management Cluster is part of the Management Domain (a special Workload Domain). It is created first during Day-0 bring-up and is non-optional.Typical components include:
SDDC Manager
vCenter Server (management vCenter)
NSX Managers
vSAN management services These components do not belong to the tenants. They belong to the platform.It runs the services that: Define topology Enforce lifecycle sequencing Validate upgrades Maintain inventory and state All VCF lifecycle operations (create domain, expand cluster, upgrade stack) are coordinated from here.Tenant workloads do not run here (by design): No tenant VMs No tenant Kubernetes workloads No customer apps This protects: Stability Security Upgrade safety It is not: A tenant cluster A workload execution environment A shared resource pool for apps Optional or replaceable Treating it like a general-purpose cluster is a serious anti-pattern.This separation ensures: Predictable upgrades (no tenant interference) Clear blast-radius control Strong security boundaries Operational sanity at scale It’s the same pattern used by: Kubernetes (control plane vs worker nodes) Public clouds (provider plane vs customer plane) Management Cluster → Kubernetes control plane nodes Guest Clusters → Kubernetes worker nodes SDDC Manager → Cluster lifecycle operator You wouldn’t run apps on the Kubernetes control plane; same rule applies here. Management Cluster is typically: Small (minimum viable size) Highly available Strictly protected If it fails: Existing workloads keep running You lose management, scaling, and upgrades until restored The Management Cluster runs the cloud, not the workloads
It is part of the Management Domain
It hosts SDDC Manager, vCenter Server, NSX Managers It is isolated, mandatory, and high-blast-radius Treat it as sacred infrastructure
You can check out Guest Cluster or Supervisor and Supervisor Cluster for the next set of items to explore.

vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.title: Supervisor Services
vcf/core-runtimes/vsphere/platform-exten.description:
Supervisor Services are platform-level extensions for the vSphere Supervisor that provide cloud-native infrastructure capabilities by packaging functionality as Kubernetes Operators and service bundles that run on the Supervisor Cluster.These services enable foundational capabilities such as Kubernetes consumption, storage services, registry operations, DNS management, ingress controllers, and more— all integrated directly into the vSphere control plane.Supervisor Services are:
Installed and managed per Supervisor Cluster Controlled by platform administrators Versioned and upgradeable independently
Consumed by tenants or platform components
In addition to core production Supervisor Services, there is a Supervisor Services Labs Catalog that includes experimental or community services which can be installed on Supervisor Clusters but are not yet part of the core catalog. Labs services are typically not supported at the same guarantee level as core Supervisor Services and may be subject to change. Formerly known as the Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service Provides APIs to create and manage Kubernetes clusters Enables declarative Kubernetes lifecycle management via Supervisor APIs. UI component for resource consumption inside Namespaces Displays resources in the vSphere Client UI under Workload Management Improves namespace Kubernetes consumption UX Framework for stateful services using vSAN Enables highly available object and block storage services for cloud-native workloads Integrates Velero with Supervisor Kubernetes Enables backup/restore of Kubernetes resources and volumes Natively integrated into Supervisor cluster workflows Leverages cert-manager primitives Issues certificates for workloads running on Supervisor or tenant clusters Helps with workload TLS termination and secure communication Adds a container registry within the Supervisor cluster Supports image scanning, signing, and lifecycle policies Works with ingress and DNS services for external access Ingress Controller (Contour): Provides ingress routing and load balancing for Kubernetes workloads Integrates with Envoy for traffic proxying ExternalDNS: Automatically updates DNS records based on exposed service endpoints Connects to external DNS providers for dynamic record management Supervisor Management Proxy: Facilitates communication between management and workload networks when isolated Ensures Supervisor components can reach required management endpoints NSX Management Proxy: Previously used for similar connectivity needs but is now deprecated in favor of Supervisor Management Proxy Enables native Supervisor APIs to expose data services to tenants Integrates the Data Services Manager (DSM) with Supervisor Cluster workload consumption paths Secret Store Service: Native secret storage capabilities for Kubernetes workloads ArgoCD Service: Provides a GitOps delivery model for application deployments Useful for declarative automation and continuous deployment workflows Supervisor Services are the core platform building blocks that make vSphere Supervisor extensible and cloud-capable. These services cover Kubernetes lifecycle, storage, registry, ingress, DNS, certificate management, backup, data services consumption, secrets, and more. They are installed per Supervisor Cluster, managed by platform administrators, and consumed by tenant workloads or automation layers like VCF Automation. There is also a Labs Catalog for experimental or early-stage Supervisor Services.

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.
